name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the report by Geoffroy Didier, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on representative actions for the protection of the common interests of consumers (09573/1/2020 – C9-0355/2020 – 2018/0089(COD)) (A9-0224/2020). Members are informed that no requestable speeches will be given during this part-session and that blue card questions will not be accepted. I would also like to point out that the speeches can be spoken remotely from the liaison offices of the Member States.

name: Geoffroy DIDIER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, who is familiar with this subject, Commissioner Reynders, ladies and gentlemen, while I am happy to start this debate with you this morning, I am particularly pleased to have managed to fight a noble battle for better consumer protection over the past two and a half years. Why did this directive come about? Scandals as resounding as dieselgate or the justified cancellation of flights by Ryanair had convinced the European Commission, we remember, to legislate, thus presenting a draft directive. It was April 11, 2018. Two and a half years later, after numerous meetings and negotiations and many compromises and, let us say, twists and turns, we are all now able to offer a new concrete right to European citizens: that of allowing them to join forces to seek redress if they suffered harm as a result of the illegal practice of a multinational. Until now, we knew that, in the face of airlines, large banks or large industrial companies, a single consumer was not acting in court, because justice is a long, costly and uncertain process. Until now, too, these class actions were only possible in some European countries: nearly a dozen States did not have them and, above all, it was impossible to bring an action in a country other than his own and thus to associate with other European consumers. With this European-wide class action, it is therefore a change of ambition and a change of dimension that we are proposing to all the citizens of the European Union. This result is the result of long struggles for each political group to agree to leave its ideological comfort zone. Everyone understood that we all had to gain from finding a balanced solution that is both more protective of consumers and, I stress, sufficiently secure for the lives of businesses that need it. Nothing was won in advance, for many of the received ideas were conveyed and dictated by seemingly contradictory and often traditional interests that had to be accepted to be shaken up in the face of the new demands. I would like here this morning to thank every political group, without exception, for finding the path of unity to reach a solution of which Parliament, I say, can be proud. It is this right balance that we have also been able to impose at the trilogue meetings and which finally gives full force to this reform. Everyone wins, the consumer comes first. The full compensation will go back to him, contrary to the excesses of the American system, which we did not want. Whether it is the user of a washing machine, a financial product, a website or an airline, every aggrieved European consumer will be able, through these class actions, to be better defended, better compensated and, ultimately, better protected. Companies also win: they will be protected from abusive or slanderous delaying remedies by a significant number of conditions that we have demanded that will ensure the transparency of financing and the absence of conflicts of interest of qualified entities. Hedge funds and law firms will not be able, for example, to sue themselves and be a party to the lawsuit, as the action is reserved for licensed and recognized consumer associations. Europe, finally, is winning at a time when people are, sometimes rightly, blaming the European Union for imposing a number of standards and constraints. It demonstrates here that it knows how to adapt to new needs and above all that it is able to offer new rights to citizens. This is economic progress, legal progress, but above all a political progress that we must all take ownership of and that we can all claim. I would like to thank the European Commission: in particular, of course, Commissioner Reynders, but also all his teams who have worked hard. I would like to thank the Council and in particular the Croatian Presidency, with which we have concluded negotiations, my colleagues in Parliament, the shadow rapporteurs, including you, Heidi Hautala, the teams of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the various political groups, whether at the Level of Members or at the level of collaborators, for their intense and constant cooperation on this issue. For, if you adopt it this evening, I hope, in the greatest possible majority, this reform will become an important reform of this mandate, but above all a strong added value of Europe in the daily lives of its citizens.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Rapporteur for the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Madam President, first of all, let me thank both the rapporteur of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the entire Negotiating Team of the European Parliament.  While I have not really made any secret of my disappointment with the results since the end of the trialogue, the fact remains that, after years of treading, we will finally have at least some, if limited, instrument for collectively protecting consumer rights. We may not like the so-called division between domestic and cross-border disputes or the long transposition period, but we need to take the result as a first step. When dieselgate broke out, we had nothing in our hands. We are currently experiencing the worst pandemic in at least a century, and a new instrument will certainly come in handy. Virtually daily, newspaper pages report on non-refunds to clients for cancelled flights as a result of epidemiological measures or fraud in the sale of inferior protective equipment. I hope that, precisely at this very moment in the daily massive violation of consumer rights, the value of what we have negotiated here will be shown. Colleagues, thank you for your cooperation and I hope for the smooth approval of the directive tabled and in rapid transposition in the Member States.

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let me thank you for the opportunity this morning to exchange with you on the Directive on Representative Actions. Above all, I would like to thank Mr Geoffroy Didier and the shadow rapporteurs of the Committee on Legal Affairs, but also all the players involved in the European Parliament, including the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, for their work during the inter-institutional negotiations, especially since the work took place during the Croatian Presidency under difficult conditions in view of the confinement. The Representative Actions Directive is an operational response by the European Union to violations of consumer rights. The latter are often deprived in the face of certain professionals who resort to illegal business practices. We all have Dieselgate in mind, to name just one example. The situation created by the COVID-19 pandemic has further highlighted the challenges faced by consumers who wish to assert their rights. I am thinking here of massive cancellations of flights and package trips without respecting the right to refund: we talked about this again last night during our debates on the consumer agenda and on Mr David Cormand's report. The adoption of this directive is therefore more necessary than ever. It will enable all European consumers to finally have this powerful tool for the protection of their rights, which is the class action.  The text on which the co-legislators agreed is balanced, whether it is the operation of the system, the control of the financing of representative actions in order to avoid conflicts of interest, support for qualified entities to ensure the effectiveness of the procedure or the various guarantees related to the cost of representative action in reparation. The scope of the text is broad enough to cover violations of consumer rights in a wide range of areas, well beyond the traditional scope of consumer protection. These include energy, telecommunications, data protection, financial services or medical devices. The procedural modalities provided are able to ensure the effectiveness of the mechanism, while respecting the procedural autonomy of the Member States. In addition, the directive provides important safeguards for professionals at all levels of the procedure. Thus, the text ensures that their right to defend is respected and the risk of abusive litigation avoided. I would like to thank the European Parliament once again for its strong commitment to consumers throughout this process. We can welcome this great achievement, which will help European consumers to assert their rights effectively.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: au nom du groupe PPE. Madame la Présidente, Monsieur le Commissaire, chers coll gues, tout d'abord, vous l'avez mentionné, Monsieur le Commissaire, notre coll gue Geoffroy Didier a fait un excellent travail et je m'en félicite. C'est vraiment respectable. Mais, chers coll gues, le résultat ne correspond pas du tout ce dont nous avons discuté here. Tant donné qu'il ne s'agit pas d'une harmonisation maximum, cet outil va apporter 27 solutions différentes et je ne peux pas m'en féliciter, Monsieur le Commissaire. Je l'ai toujours dit: ce n'est pas seulement votre faute, c'est le contenu qui est insuffisant. Ladies and gentlemen, Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is I would like to do that. Of course, there is a political drive to more class action, to more collective law enforcement. The European Parliament has not been able to oppose this in the long term. However, we have not achieved the objectives that we formulated at the beginning– including on the part of the Commission – that we create a single European model to which all the courts of the Member States, to which all the legal systems of the Member States belong in a uniform manner, have not been achieved. And in that respect, Commissioner, all the fine words are too much. It will not be possible for you, even with the best of intentions and the greatest commitment, to persuade 27 Member State governments to find a single solution. It will simply not be possible, and it will of course lead to smaller Member States such as Malta or Cyprus creating incentives for American law firms to establish themselves there, of course, through favourable tax tricks, so that appropriate law firms can establish themselves there. It will lead to different procedural issues being dealt with differently in the Member States, and it will lead precisely to the confusion in Europe that we have always wanted to avoid and which already exists in the United States today – all at the expense that ultimately the consumers, not the businesses, will have to bear.  That is why, with all due respect for the really difficult work, I believe that, unfortunately, the great goal we had has not been achieved.

name: Lara WOLTERS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I am more positive about the result that we achieved than Mr Schwab, because, when Facebook users were duped by the illicit data harvesting, they could not start a joint case with other EU citizens against Cambridge Analytica. When hundreds of thousands of consumers were defrauded by Volkswagen in the Dieselgate scandal, US and Australian citizens could seek compensation together, but this was not the case for EU citizens. Earlier this year, the European Court of Justice ruled that a German woman couldn’t claim compensation over faulty breast implants because the company that made them was only liable in France. And today marks an end to all that. Our new rules mean that you can join with other people from your own country and from across Europe to fight for collective compensation. Consumers that have suffered harm will no longer have to wait years because different legal actions are ongoing, but instead benefit from one single procedure. That’s a major step forward. I’m also pleased that scarce resources won’t prevent justice for consumers. We are encouraging public funding for consumer organisations and calling for the cost of access to justice to be reduced. In spite of fierce lobbying and resistance from national and industry interests, if your rights as a passenger on a train or plane are violated, for instance in the case of delays or poor service, you can start a collective lawsuit too.  So today we are taking a crucial step, but of course there is more work to do. In the long run, I think that collective redress should be available to all victims of harm at the hands of EU companies, whether or not those victims are EU citizens. I think that, in the future, collective redress should also be available to citizens, regardless of whether they are consumers or not, because why can someone who owns a Volkswagen seek compensation, but not someone who owns a bike and is forced to inhale diesel fumes at every traffic light? And I’m speaking from experience here. But those are all questions for the future. For now, I want to warmly thank the rapporteur and our negotiation team for good cooperation and for our excellent result. This new law will enhance consumer protection, improve access to justice and hold companies to account where needed.

name: Liesje SCHREINEMACHER
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, unfortunately, it sometimes happens that your flight is cancelled, you are forced to make additional purchases within your mobile subscription, or that you buy a car that emits far more CO2 than is legally allowed. We've all been aggrieved consumers, but what do you do if the producer or seller doesn't meet you? Then how do you get it right?  Going to court on your own doesn't just get a lot of hassle. It also takes time and you often have less left over than the original damage. But most of the time, you're not alone. And that matters, because research shows that almost 80% of consumers would be more likely to go to court if they could do it together with other consumers in the same position. That is why the new directive is good news for representative actions. Whether it is misuse of your personal data, negligent financial services or unsafe products, it will soon be possible in every Member State for consumers to be represented by the Consumer Association or another organisation and to jointly make a claim to a company that has caused them damage.  After 30 years of discussion, this is not only important profit for consumers, but also for businesses. While most European companies, of course, adhere to European consumer rules, these new rules are also a good stick behind the door for companies that do not take it so closely. So it improves the level playing field in Europe. In addition, abuse of these cases is countered by the fact that we have formulated a number of requirements that parties wishing to start a case must comply with.  The directive is therefore a win-win that directly contributes to the position of consumers and companies. In this way, regardless of which Member State you live in, it will be easier for all consumers in Europe to be compensated for their damages and we will face unfair competition. I would also like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, unity is strength: this adage is particularly true in consumer law. When consumers are harmed by a large company, they often feel helpless to claim their rights. This directive aims to help them obtain justice by providing them with a European collective action mechanism. The directive calls on each Member State to designate qualified not-for-profit entities that will be responsible for bringing legal actions before national courts on behalf of aggrieved consumers. These qualified entities will therefore have the merit of breaking the loneliness of consumers by grouping them into collective actions, thus turning their initial weakness into strength. The directive is flexible because it allows each state to choose both associations and public bodies. In addition, it respects national systems of collective action when they already exist, as has been the case in France since the law of 17 March 2014. When successful, the class action will require the condemned company to offer aggrieved consumers the type of compensation best suited to their case: compensation, repair, replacement, price reduction, contract resolution or reimbursement of the price paid. This new mechanism is therefore a great step forward for consumer protection because it will repair, more effectively than today, the serial damage caused by large companies such as those caused by Volkswagen in the Dieselgate scandal.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: for the ECR Group. – Madam President, collective actions, that is, those in which a large group of consumers jointly sue companies, used to be used only in minimum countries and had a reputation for artificial litigation in the rest of the world, the most famous example being the US. In recent years, however, this practice has spread to an increasing number of countries. Seventeen, twenty-five major economies allow collective action to proceed. Most of these procedures have been introduced in the last twenty years. I believe that this success of collective actions is based on the fact that they are an effective complement to direct regulation in the area of consumer protection. I therefore support this proposal.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, a company that spies on everything: its workers, its trade union representatives, its detractors, the slightest gestures, the people frequented, the messages exchanged on social networks and the most intimate private life. This is not taken from George Orwell's 1984 novel; it happens every day today within Amazon. We already knew that Amazon was destroying the environment, attacking social rights and practicing tax evasion. We now know, from a vast investigation published by the American newspaper VICE, that Amazon directly uses a spy company to monitor all those who question its omnipotence, from trade unionists to Greenpeace and Greta Thunberg, to yellow vests in France. Everything is systematically recorded, assessed and categorized according to five levels of risk, from moderate to critical. The mere fact that two CGT trade unionists distributed leaflets in front of a warehouse on 10 March 2020 was reported. With one goal: to intimidate, deter, to suppress any dissent of the empire. An Amazon empire whose profits have tripled since the beginning of the year to benefit its boss, Jeff Bezos, who swims in an ocean of wealth unmatched by nearly $200 billion. So to recognize today, through class actions, the right of consumers to join forces to obtain redress is a first victory, which we welcome. However, the European Union is not just a market and citizens are not just consumers. The example of Amazon demonstrates the urgent need to expand citizens' shields beyond the scope of consumption to establish a real duty of corporate vigilance and protect fundamental rights, workers' rights and the environment. Indeed, society as a whole could file a complaint against Amazon: the workers they operate, the associations they spy on, the small business they destroy and the public services they dry up by practicing tax evasion. This intervention may be worth me, and certainly, a report from the spies working for Amazon, but let the message get through: millions of citizens are also scrutinizing you and demanding accountability.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! Five years ago, a historic environmental and consumer scandal went into the public eye. Volkswagen had installed multi-million-million worth of cheating software in their cars, so it looked as if the cars were more environmentally friendly than they were. When I mention this matter now, it is because in many ways it serves as a backdrop to the legislation we are now about to adopt. The dieselgate scandal was a scandal in itself, but it also made it clear that we had a gap in the EU legal system. Consumers were not able to bring a joint class action in Germany, but instead had to do so nationally in their own countries. Of course, that should not be the case.  The internal market must not only benefit businesses, it must also benefit consumers. There is a need to ensure effective legal protection when companies cheat. That is why I am also pleased that an agreement on collective action for European consumers has been successfully reached. The more consumers who unite behind an indictment, the stronger they will be in the trial.  Not everything is perfect in this agreement, but I nevertheless think it is important to be happy with it, and I would like to highlight two things. One is that it is good that we have finally succeeded in introducing a principle that the loser pays. Large class actions are often very expensive and therefore it is only reasonable that it is the losing party who pays. Secondly, I am very pleased that we have a European Consumer Ombudsman. Such a body would ensure independence in the supervision of consumers' rights.  I do not necessarily believe that this can prevent a new Dieselgate scandal, but it does provide consumers with better opportunities to collectively defend their rights if they were to be let down again by companies. So I support the legislation, even if there are a few weaknesses in it.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The system of collective actions is not really a system that is historically anchored in the European-continental European legal system. The system comes from the Anglican case law, as we know.  Therefore, in Europe, where Roman law has been received – at least in continental Europe – nothing like it is enshrined in a legal order. As a lawyer, one is, of course, particularly sceptical about this matter. Of course, we do not know whether this can also result in meaningful interlocking at the end of the day and at the end of this implementation. However, in the case of collective actions, I can say for myself that I think it makes perfect sense to enshrine them, because it primarily serves the consumer.  We usually have a very counterweight situation here. On the one hand, we have consumers, whose market power is rather low, and on the other hand, large companies, which have great market power, naturally also have enough capital to fight any legal disputes. I therefore believe that, in any case, this should be implemented. We must not forget the opt-in system, which means that an association action can only be filed if there is also a mandate for it from the person concerned.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. It is good news that we are discussing today the completion of the Directive on representative actions and the possibility for consumers in all Member States to pursue collective redress. The adoption of this right is important and awaited by thousands of Eu citizens, because, as the experience of recent years has shown, collective infringements of consumer rights continue to occur in many Member States, mainly through degression, aggressive marketing or other unlawful commercial practices.  In Poland, from where I am a member, there has been a high-profile recent case of massive breaches of consumer rights consisting in the unfair provision of mortgages indexed to a foreign currency or the frequent practice of selling products of under-quality. Thousands of citizens have suffered from these operations, and they have often caused human dramas and misfortunes.  In this context, I believe that the European Parliament should strongly support the solutions provided for in this directive, as they will make an important contribution to improving the level of protection of consumer rights. In addition, they will ensure the efficiency of procedures through the urgent handling of infringements and avoid situations where high legal costs could become an obstacle to collectively asserting the protection of consumer rights.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this directive is an example of the power and impact of EU law. A new tool will be created in EU law and, at the same time, in the law of EU Member States to improve consumer rights. Consumer organisations and independent authorities are given the right to represent and defend consumers' rights in court. This is particularly important if a large number of consumers are affected, but it may not be so large in financial terms that many consumers would be prepared to bring the matter to court on their own. There's strength in the group! This directive has emerged in response to a real need. Volkswagen's emissions scam left many car owners in a position where compensation should have been claimed directly from the Volkswagen Group. Volkswagen wasn't even the only car manufacturer that rigged car emissions. The EU's message is clear: the trampling of consumer rights is not accepted, and if there are no means of tackling, they will be created if necessary. I think this is just the beginning. In future, a class action would also allow victims of forced labour or trafficking in human beings, for example, to claim their rights as a group from a company that has committed human rights violations. That is something we should look into in the future. I am very pleased to have had the opportunity to participate in the legislative process from start to finish. The legislation was prepared in a good spirit. I would like to warmly thank the rapporteur, Geoffroy Didier, and all my colleagues, both here in Parliament and in the Commission and in the Council. I urge everyone to vote in favour of this progressive legislation.

name: Didier Reynders
text: membre de la Commission. – Monsieur le Président, Mesdames, Messieurs, je tiens à nouveau à vous remercier pour le débat que nous avons eu ce matin et pour votre soutien, dès le départ, à cette initiative. Une fois formellement adoptée et mise en œuvre, la directive relative aux actions représentatives offrira une protection solide aux consommateurs européens. Elle améliorera considérablement la mise en œuvre concrète des règles de protection des consommateurs dans toute l’Europe et pourrait ouvrir la voie à d’autres initiatives visant à améliorer l’accès à la justice dans d’autres domaines. Avec cette directive, nous envoyons un signal clair aux citoyens européens: l’Union européenne protège leurs intérêts et notamment leurs droits en tant que consommateur et l’accès à la justice. The directive creates a procedural mechanism of collective redress. It needs to respect the principle of procedural autonomy of the Member States, and their legal traditions. The objective was to allow the new mechanisms to be integrated as smoothly as possible in their national rules of civil procedure. On the other hand, the directive harmonises key aspects of the procedure ensuring a common denominator across the EU, in terms of both rights and safeguards. About the level of harmonisation, I want to add that with this directive the Commission always had the objective of preserving well-functioning national systems which can have different forms of collective redress. Member States can maintain existing systems and introduce new ones. The directive introduces a specific model of representative actions where qualified entities can seek injunctive and redress measures. Member States that already have representative actions have the choice to transpose this mechanism separately from the existing mechanism or to modify existing mechanisms to match the directive’s requirements.  When modifying existing mechanisms Member States have to introduce the missing elements, especially new elements that relate to cross-border actions. Importantly, the mutual recognition of qualified entities from other Member States should ensure for the purpose of cross-border actions under the conditions listed in the directive that this builds on the model already introduced by the Injunctions Directive.  Other features of the directive concerning, for example, the funding of actions or limitation periods may also require some modifications in Member States. However, the directive is not overly prescriptive. It provides the main elements of a general procedural framework but leaves the details to the national system in order to make the mechanism workable in practice. It is therefore likely that Member States only have to make a minimum of changes to their existing systems, and of course the Commission will assist the Member States throughout the transposition process, notably with dedicated workshops. Je voudrais conclure, Monsieur le Président, en remerciant une nouvelle fois le Parlement européen pour son engagement dans ce dossier et pour le débat que nous avons encore tenu ce matin. Je me réjouis de poursuivre notre excellente coopération dans les dossiers de protection des consommateurs, notamment dans la mise en œuvre du récent Agenda du consommateur, dont nous avons eu l’occasion de débattre hier soir. De plus, comme je l’ai évoqué hier, nous poursuivrons aussi nos actions pour changer le comportement des entreprises à travers l’initiative sur la gouvernance durable que la Commission présentera l’année prochaine.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The debate is closed. I would like to inform you that no proposal to reject the Council's position and no amendments have been tabled in accordance with Articles 67 and 68 of our Rules of Procedure. The proposed act is therefore deemed to have been adopted. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – Parliament should support all legislation that will strengthen consumer rights in the European Union. They should also be implemented as soon as possible. This is what the well-being of our citizens demands, because they are all consumers. At present, consumers can only join forces to fight for their rights in some EU Member States, and in cases involving more than one country, this is practically impossible. The new collective redress rules would give consumers in all Member States the right to fight collective redress, but would also introduce safeguards to prevent abuse of this procedure. Particular attention should be paid to ensuring that the new provisions allow, in addition to general consumer laws, collective redress in cases where infringements are committed in areas such as data protection, financial services, travel and tourism, energy, telecommunications, environment and health, air and rail passenger rights. Most importantly, collective redress should be possible in all EU countries by allowing consumer organisations to represent citizens with the right to claim damages. This is important because uniform rules should apply equally to consumers in all Member States. The new directive will then make sense and will play its protective role vis-à-vis each consumer, regardless of their place of residence, purchases or purchases of services.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Clare Daly's report on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union – Annual Report for 2018 and 2019 (2019/2199(INI)) (A9—0226/2020). I would like to remind Members once again, as usual, that, in view of the Corona pandemic and the special measures we have had to take, there are no spontaneous speeches in all the debates of this part-session and that no blue cards can be accepted. In addition, calls from Parliament's liaison offices in the various Member States are being prepared, as recently introduced to enable more Members to take part in the debate, including through speeches.

name: Clare DALY
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, in moving this report, I’d like to acknowledge the huge interest in it. We had over 600 complex and often contradictory amendments, so it hasn’t been an easy process. I’d like especially to thank my own magnificent team, Megan, Lide and Eadaoin. I’d like to thank the Secretariat of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and the staff in all of the political groups for their patience and professionalism. There’s no doubt about it. The Charter is an important document which contains rights which, if implemented, would allow all citizens to achieve their full potential and lead a dignified life. But we have to be honest about it: we’re a million miles away from that situation. Awareness of the Charter is low, there’s a total lack of integration in economic and political priorities, and even worse, in a whole number of Member States, fundamental rights are being attacked and undermined. So this report was an opportunity to step back, look at what’s going on and ask ourselves why. I’m very glad that we managed to hold on to a strong economic and social rights section at the start because, while fundamental rights are absolute in theory, if you don’t have a stable roof over your head or access to education or healthcare, well then you can only dream about having your rights protected. I’m glad that the report acknowledges the impact on inequality of cuts in public expenditure, but I’m sorry we couldn’t call it by its right name: austerity. I’m glad about the points about sexual and reproductive rights, about the pushbacks and the criminalisation of humanitarian action. But while acknowledging that, I deeply regret the weakness in this report because of our failure to come together and call out abuses and name countries – a shyness which is not replicated when we talk about countries outside of the EU. We have the absurdity now of a fundamental rights report where we’re not allowed to mention a country, not even in the body of the text, not even in a footnote if it comes from the Council of Europe and it has the name of a country in its title. Colleagues, this is utter madness. George Orwell said, ‘if liberty means anything at all, it means the right to tell people what they do not want to hear’. It is obvious that there are people in here who do not want to hear about Catalonia, and I am not surprised because it is an indictment on the Spanish State and the EU. But it’s a good example of the problem with this report because, instead of calling it out, as the Council of Europe has, we have a fundamental rights report that deals with freedom of expression, where the explanatory statement has been expunged for having the audacity to mention the fact that there are parliamentarians in prison with sentences of over 10 years for organising a democratic plebiscite. I’m sorry now but, if that doesn’t equal what the report condemns as the use of a judicial system for political purposes to silence an opposition, well I don’t know what does. But the big Groups didn’t want that. They couldn’t handle the truth so, after the committee vote, nine months after the explanatory statement was published, this statement, which was never voted upon, had to be banned. And you know I feel a bit like the author of The Joy of Sex, a book that was banned in Ireland and that no one had ever heard of until it was banned, and then everybody wanted it. So an explanatory statement that normally nobody ever cares about we’ve reproduced already as a booklet in English and in Spanish, and it’s currently being translated into Catalan. So thanks very much for that one. So fundamental rights should transcend self—interest and political game-playing. They should be the great equaliser, no matter who you are or what country you are. If we ignore that, it only leads us into a cul-de-sac of a fundamental rights report that deals with whistle-blowers and freedom of the press, but fails to mention Julian Assange and the dangerous precedent if the Trump Administration succeeds in its efforts to extradite him to the US and face 175 years in a high-security prison for journalism in the EU. The biggest press-freedom case of our generation and we are silent. I voted on this report going to plenary in the hope that sense would prevail and it would be improved here and issues like that put back. But if it’s not, I have no hesitation in voting against this report because it’s better that we would have no report than a weak or a hypocritical report. Maybe then we face the truth that, for all our talk about fundamental rights, we have had people on the streets of Bulgaria for months against a corrupt ruling party, fat on EU money. We have migrants left to rot and fester in camps, while boats of pregnant women and children are pushed out to sea by state forces in Greece. We have migrants raped with the branches of trees by state forces in Croatia. We have Muslims hounded in France. And, yes, we have parliamentarians in prison in Spain. So this is your Europe, and the choice is clear. We either waffle on in generalities about fundamental rights or we have the Charter implemented. Ten years on, I’m very clear what side I’m on.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the Members of Parliament for the focus on strengthening fundamental rights, and the rapporteur Ms Daly for her work on this Annual Report.  The Commission will propose in December a strategy to strengthen the application of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Over the past decade, the Charter has led to a greater promotion and protection of people’s fundamental rights in the European Union. It has triggered new legislation directly protecting and promoting certain key rights. However, as proven by recent developments, fundamental rights, democracy or the rule of law cannot be taken for granted. They require EU citizens and ourselves to constantly stand up for those principles. Allow me to reflect on several issues raised by the report. First, on the importance of a comprehensive approach to combat discrimination, exclusion, prejudice or hate speech and hate crime. The Commission has renewed its efforts to ensure the correct transposition of the framework decision on combating racism and xenophobia. The commitment to tackle serious manifestations of racism is one of the main pillars of the Commission’s Anti-racism Action Plan adopted on 18 September and we have to go further.  By the end of the next year, the Commission will take an initiative to extend the list of EU crimes under the EU Treaty to all forms of hate crime and hate speech. This will give us a legal basis for legislative action. In parallel to strengthening our legal framework we need to fight stereotypes and bias and promote diversity and inclusion policies. One cannot succeed without the other.  The plan for the actions that need to be taken by the Commission and the Member States are reflected in our strategic documents adopted since the Commission took its mandate which were: Gender Equality Strategy; LGBTIQ Strategy; the already mentioned EU Anti-racism Action Plan; and on the reinforced EU Roma Inclusion Strategic Framework. And we are working on strengthening media freedom and pluralism as addressed during Monday’s debate on the Adamowicz report. The Commission is currently finalising a European Democracy Action Plan, which will focus on elections integrity, media freedom and media pluralism and tackling disinformation. When delivering on the Democracy Action Plan we will explore the issue of strategic lawsuits against public participation and present in 2021 an initiative against abusive litigation targeting journalists and rights’ defenders.  The Commission is aware that civil society and rights’ defenders are facing pressures and obstacles in certain Member States. Ensuring an enabling a supportive environment for these actors is one of the focal points of our upcoming strategy to strengthen the application of the Charter of Fundamental Rights in the EU. We welcome the increase in the budget of the rights and values programme in the Multiannual Financial Framework, which will be useful in that regard.  The Commission shares your concerns about the protection of the most vulnerable people, such as children in poverty or people with no access to adequate housing. We will continue to support Member States in their efforts. The forthcoming EU Child Guarantee and EU Rights of the Child Strategy will address the special needs of the children in 2021.  With regard to your concerns about the situation of migrants and the push-backs at some borders, I would like to underline that the Charter applies to Member States when they are implementing EU migration law. It is imperative that measures taken by border guards to protect the external borders are taken in respect of fundamental rights and international law, in particular, the principle of non-refoulement and the access to asylum procedures. It is necessary also to show solidarity to the Member States on the EU’s external borders, whose concerns need to be heard and discussed. The new Pact on migration and asylum presented on 23 September strengthens the protection of fundamental rights and ensures that any allegations of breaches are properly investigated.  Adherence to the principles is strongly reflected in our new Action Plan on integration and inclusion, which focuses on both migrants and EU citizens with a migrant background. It aims to ensure effective integration and inclusion as it is a social and economic investment that makes European societies more cohesive, resilient and more prosperous. Last, but not least, I would like to underline that the Commission is committed to upholding the rule of law in the Union by all the means at its disposal. It is a precondition for the respect of fundamental rights. We fully agree with the European Parliament with regard to the importance of strengthening the EU’s capacity to monitor the respect of the common values on which the EU is founded.  On 30 September we presented the first annual rule of law report at the centre of the new Comprehensive European Rule of Law Mechanism. One of its objectives is to strengthen interinstitutional cooperation on the rule of law matters and to trigger an inclusive debate at European and national level. We are ready to organise further discussions with the European Parliament on this report, including on individual country chapters.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the opinion voted on in May, the Committee on Constitutional Affairs wanted to highlight the founding values of the European Union: respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality and the rule of law, of which we have mentioned, is the cornerstone of the independence of the judiciary from politics, a principle that is sometimes at risk in some countries of the European Union. I cannot fail to recall how Ján Kuciak, a Slovak journalist whose murder caused a deep political crisis, culminated in the resignation of the Prime Minister, was killed in 2018. A few months earlier, Daphne Caruana Galizia had been murdered in Malta, with the involvement of government circles, which also led to the resignation of the Prime Minister. Defending the rule of law also means defending the freedom of the press, anytime, anywhere. Today, the health and economic crisis caused by COVID-19 is putting a strain on European citizens by threatening other fundamental rights, from health to work and freedom of enterprise. Only if we start from our fundamental values, leaving no one behind, will we be able to live up to the task we have at this historic stage. We have seen how fragile the European Union is. It is our responsibility to ensure that projects soon move on to concrete action, families and businesses can no longer wait. I hope that, as in the case of the Conference on the Future of Europe and the agreements with the United Kingdom, the stalemate in which Europe finds itself will soon be overcome.

name: Yana TOOM
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. – Mr President, if there is a place in this House where we can see exactly the expectations of Europeans, this is in the Committee on Petitions. This is the place where we receive more than 2000 petitions every year, and I have to say that Europeans are pretty much aware of their rights, obligations and possibilities.  And there is a document to which they refer fairly often and this is the European Charter of Fundamental Rights. But, during my six years in the Committee on Petitions, I can barely remember only one or two petitioners who were aware that the European Charter of Fundamental Rights is pretty much limited by Article 51, which means that national governments have to follow the Charter of Fundamental Rights only if they are implementing European law. If it comes to national issues this is not the case. It is very sad that again and again, we have to write to petitioners and say, look, we understand your problem, we see that something is wrong, but we can do nothing because of Article 51 in the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  I believe that in this House, it is high time to start this debate and I know that several years ago, there was already a resolution in this House that we have to think about Article 51, but it never happened, unfortunately. And I believe that this is not right. The second document to which they refer also a lot, is the European Pillar of Social Rights, which was adopted exactly three years ago on 17 November 2017 and is still not implemented. We have to move forward, otherwise, if we do not meet the expectations of Europeans, I do not predict a bright future for the European Union.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, after the fall of totalitarian and undemocratic regimes, Europe has come a long way in the protection and promotion of the fundamental rights of all citizens. Our human rights standards are today, with little doubt, the highest in the world. Violations of those rights, however, still exist in many different areas, especially among vulnerable groups such as women, children in poverty, and people with disabilities. Our responsibility is to clearly address this and suggest ways to improve their protection 10 years after the entry into force of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. This annual report is meant to monitor the progress of fundamental rights in Europe, showing how the Charter has been taken into account, but also identifying current trends and areas for further improvement.  The protection of universal human rights should certainly not be a point for ideological battles. Personal political convictions should not overshadow an inclusive and objective evaluation of human rights in Europe. A good example of this need for a universal and comprehensive approach is the issue of migration. We need to strongly support the fundamental right to seek asylum, but we cannot ignore the need to fight human smuggling or the need to comply with international and Union law. The protection of human rights should not be a topic for divisions on policy differences. On the contrary, this should be an opportunity for a strong and broad commitment to inalienable human dignity, otherwise we risk undermining the importance of human rights protection systems.

name: Evin INCIR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I must admit that I actually prepared two different speeches. While I hoped that I wouldn’t need to give this specific one, I need to do it out of necessity, after the speech of the rapporteur. When we are negotiating important reports such as this one, it is of most importance that we weigh every word, we double-check all the facts, and we don’t choose what to include based on political self-interest: rather, out of total necessity due to the reality we are faced with during the period the report concerns. Otherwise, we undermine the trust in the report. I was therefore happy when the rapporteur and we shadows agreed on some overall structures: to only name countries where we can lean against the judicial process or decision – otherwise we risk to end up with a country catalogue rather than a report with a focus on fundamental rights breaches. And that we have the right balance between social and civil rights, because one should not forget that the right to housing is equally as important as the right to, for example, an independent and free judicial system. Our EU citizens need them both to be fully free. Furthermore, no EU citizen should be limited in living a happy life through being faced with discrimination or racism, which we unfortunately see more and more of. LGBT-free free zones, attacks on independent and free media, demonisation of migrants and people of migrant backgrounds, shrinking space and limitation of women’s rights to their own bodies are some of the attacks on fundamental rights we are seeing in our Member States, in some much more than others. Finally, in the political family I belong to, the outcome of discussions and negotiations is important. If we don’t agree, we highlight it in the negotiations, to give a heads-up, because we know that negotiations are all about giving and taking. To sneak in issues in the Explanatory Statement that one has no majority for, as rapporteur, is for me not working. This is not a game, this is real people’s lives we are talking about. With that said, I hope that we will be able to vote ‘yes’ to this report without too many amendments, which would change the important element in this report and might have consequences for the final vote.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to stress that the Renew Group has worked constructively on this report on fundamental rights, because its defence, the defence of the democratic rule of law, is at the heart of who we are as a group. We have worked without fainting, like the Socialists, like other Members, to have an acceptable text for approval. And it has not been easy, because the text was based on ideological biases and, moreover, because, as the Socialist Member has said, things have to be shown to her face and not try to do tricks.  Let's try to get a text that is up to what the House requires, with majority, with firm reasons. The report adopted in committee calls for the constant monitoring of fundamental rights against abuse and discrimination, in our societies, by state or non-state powers.  Emphasize the right to non-demeaning treatment of migrants who come to our territory, to ensure the most vulnerable , especially children – and the right to health of the most vulnerable women, because all socially unfavourable conditions and stigmatization make them the pasture of predators or discrimination, such as in Moria.  Go our commitment to discrimination against women in the Roma minority, or to the chapter on freedom of expression, because hate speech is normalizing in our societies and is polarizing undemocratically, and there is a lot of masked populism and there is a lot of attack on journalists.  I am pleased to have included in this report the mention of the victims of terrorism , although there are some groups that intend to eliminate it – their double victimization: the tribute to the terrorists for having been. And as the Renew Group, once again, we talk about the democratic rule of law and put the impass, because the identity populist pathologies take away from us, they intend to take away from us, the rights to Europeans, also in substatal entities, although falsely they appear as victims.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the The report on the situation of fundamental rights in Europe is an important report, but unfortunately it was not dealt with by the competent LIBE Committee. Because then the LIBE Committee should not have given the report to Clare Daly. Clare Daly was expelled from the Labour Party because she was openly Trotskyist militant. Even in the Socialist Party, to which she then joined, they did not want to have her later – not even there. We therefore have a rapporteur who has been or is a supporter of Trotskyism, that is to say, the most extreme form of communism, which is already the most extreme, which clearly stands for anti-democratic, anti-pluralist and anti-freedom regimes, and who has thus openly fought against the European values that this report is about for decades. And such a person is serious about becoming rapporteur on the situation of fundamental rights in Europe? You can't imagine it! And so is the report: a collection of left-wing commonplaces, unproven claims and overt lies. A report that makes no mention of the infiltrated Muslim terrorism, as if the mass murders of recent years are not the most fundamental threat to European fundamental rights. A report that spit spat spat in the face of all Jews when it pretends that Islam and anti-Semitism have nothing to do with each other. A report that seriously treats housing shortages and unemployment as violations of fundamental rights, but does not want to see an attack on freedom of expression in the Muslim attack on Charlie Hebdo or Samuel Paty, in the nice murders. This report is a document of failure – by Clare Daly, but also by the LIBE Committee, because Daly's failure was foreseeable. This report is left-wing, and above all it is a disgrace. Just as well, a rapist could have been made the rapporteur on the situation of women's rights. But that may still come in this House.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr! Now that you have attacked the rapporteur personally on several occasions, I would like to give her the floor for a personal statement.

name: Clare DALY
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, can I just thank the colleague who was an appointed shadow and, unlike the previous speakers, never once attended any of the meetings or had any input in this report at all. I was an elected Member of the Irish Parliament for eight years. I was one of 11 people elected by the people of Ireland to come here, and to compare me to a rapist because you don’t like my report is absolutely reprehensible. Every reference in it is sourced and credited to an official report and, while we’re at it, can I say that the explanatory statement snuck nothing in. It was a matter of public record for nine months.

name: Diana RIBA I GINER
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the Treaty on Union says that it is based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. But the report we are debating today shows that fundamental rights cannot be guaranteed in Europe. The text warns of rising levels of poverty and exclusion, attacks on women's rights and lives, hate speech against minorities, and reminds us of our obligation to respect the rights of those who come to Europe in search of refuge or a more dignified life.  The report also highlights democratic setbacks that concern us. It denounces the violation of basic rights such as freedom of expression or assembly, and calls into question the separation of powers and judicial independence of the Member States. We are or might be comfortable with this text, but at the same time we are concerned about important aspects. On the one hand, the large groups continue to block any mention of the Member States in this report, and in addition, the president of the LIBE Commission, at the request of some parties, has removed the rapporteur's explanal statement, in which he referred, indirectly, to police violence in Catalonia and to the imprisonment of Catalan leaders, a decision that has been taken overnight and for reasons of domestic policy. A explana course reflecting what has already been denounced by the United Nations Working Group on Arbitrary Detention, the Council of Europe Commissioner for Human Rights and Amnesty International, among others. We regret that, precisely when we are debating a report on fundamental rights, we must condemn an act of censure and an exercise in political cynicism like this within the European Parliament. After all, it may be true that no State needs to be named: they alone are singled out. For all this, I call on the President of Parliament to review what has happened and to protect the freedom of political expression of Members of the European Parliament in the exercise of his mandate. Finally, I propose that the report include an amendment which, as international law does, recognizes the right to self-determination as a universal right. Too often conflicts of sovereignty lead to suffering. The 21st century European Union must actively work to promote solutions based on peace, dialogue and democracy.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This report, one could say, has unfortunately become a left-wing manifesto. Of course, we support the values on which the European Union is founded, but it is difficult not to see that left-wing circles – political circles, including here in the European Parliament – want to dominate their beliefs and worldview over others, bending European laws and procedures to this end in order to achieve their ideological goals.  This is demonstrated by the numerous references made in the report, e.g. to reproductive rights, sex education or judicial systems. However, the Treaties clearly state the scope of the Union's action and the limits of its competences. Fundamental rights are not reserved only for some, they apply to everyone and cannot be freely extended. They must not be abused to impose a left-wing narrative promoting a specific interpretation of fundamental rights, recognising and promoting even alleged rights that do not exist, such as the right to abortion. In a moment, perhaps even the right to euthanasia or surogation.  We need dialogue on an equal and just basis, respecting the letter and spirit of the Treaties. I am convinced that this is in the interest of all the peoples that make up the European Union.

name: Sira REGO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, after reading this magnificent report, anyone who could wonder how fundamental rights in Europe are going, doing so honestly, answering honestly, should recognise that they are losing. The origin is well known where it is: austere policies; but it is also booming in the far right, and not only where they govern, but also here, every time they manage to set their political agenda. All you have to do is look at immigration policy. All you have to do is see Lesbos or the Balkan border, the Mediterranean, you only have to see the Canary Islands, different places, same effects and consequences: human pain, violation of rights. Perhaps taking advantage of the view that we talk about this report, we should look at ourselves: don't you think the guarantor of these rights should be the EU? Us?  My feeling is that we do not act as we should, that we even buy the delirium of the far right: to defend the European way of life. Remember. Thus we begin by buying the story of an avalanche that does not exist, because you know—like me—that the figures denies that statement. We know this because the International Organization for Migration tells us that fewer migrants arrive in Europe every year, and they know – like me – that Lesbos and the Canary Islands are the consequence of the blocking policy, of keeping them trapped in the places of arrival, which is also unfair, moreover, to host populations, such as the Canarian population, because they are very often overwhelmed after years of cuts. We also know, because this is credited by a journalistic investigation, that Frontex is involved in hot returns; I remember: it is an illegal action that contraviates international law and human rights. That is why, in the face of this report, we have two disjunctions: to amend it, to put it in a drawer and therefore to silence our consciences, or to face it as an opportunity to offer solutions.  These include legal and safe ways to end mafias: solidarity sharing between EU countries, compliance with international law, civilian public rescue bodies at sea and economic resources for reception sites.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is founded on common values and fundamental rights that form the legal and political basis of peaceful and inclusive societies. No Member State is exempt from threats, but the means to prevent, correct and sanction attacks on the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights have, unfortunately, often proved inadequate. The need for an impartial monitoring and evaluation mechanism, country by country, to combat the violations of values on which the European project is based is therefore always relevant. The full enjoyment of social, political and economic rights remains problematic for the most vulnerable groups and cannot ignore the fight against unemployment, gender inequality, discrimination, poverty, intolerance, xenophobia, unequal access to goods and services, corruption, organised crime and terrorism. It is imperative for the European Union to place human dignity and fundamental rights at the centre of its action, so that the full development of the person contributes to strengthening democracy, freedom and cohesion of our society.

name: Peter POLLÁK
text: – Mr President, the annual report for 2018-2019, which we are discussing today, lists many areas, such as persistent discrimination, uneasy access, the rise of racism and xenophobia, poverty and migration. Year after year, we say the same thing, not only do people feel that the responsible institutions cannot cope, the situation is even worse, even though we have both legal and financial mechanisms. We must bear in mind, and the current pandemic has confirmed that individual freedom ends where another's freedom begins. For example, wearing a mask, it is not about whether I like it or not, but about a responsible approach when, by wearing a mask, I protect not only myself, but also my surroundings. We cannot therefore exercise our right by denying the right of the other. The Union cannot have ambitions to be a leader in digitalisation, artificial intelligence or the Green Deal if it forgets vulnerable and vulnerable groups. The poor, the elderly and the socially excluded cannot be denied the right to a dignified life. No child can be denied the right to education. The Union will only fulfil its ambitions if we get rid of the threats of terrorism. People will be safe on the streets, in schools or churches. The Union must find a way to prevent disinformation and hoaxes being exploited by extremists. Our ambition must be to change not only in the writing of reports. These are connected areas, complex solutions, and I would therefore like the text of this report itself to be more balanced.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Our common values and fundamental rights are described in Article 2 of the EU Treaty: respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, respect for human rights, including the rights of minorities. Article 3 identifies the promotion of these values as an objective of the EU.  The reality: In Germany alone, a woman is killed every third day by her partner or ex-partner. Too many women are denied full access to reproductive health services. LGBTI people are increasingly experiencing discrimination and violence. There are reports of brutal pushbacks at our external borders. Vulnerable people do not have legal access to Europe and all too often have to endure in inhumane conditions in reception centres. Principles of the rule of law, such as the separation of powers, judicial independence and equality before the law, are being trampled underfoot in some Member States. Governments are abusing public institutions and the media for their own power. The reaction and consistency of the Council and the Commission? The Commission's new annual Rule of Law report covers respect for fundamental rights only indirectly. The EU's accession to the European Convention on Human Rights, including six years after the ECJ ruling? Not done! And Article 7 procedures are ensaming in the Council. As the European Parliament, we will continue to remind the Commission and the Council of their role. They must promote fundamental rights and take firm action against their disregard. Our values and fundamental rights must not continue to degenerate into empty words. Create new confidence in our democracy, in our Europe!

name: Fabienne KELLER
text: Mr President, more than two thirds of European citizens face false information at least once a week. In crisis situations like the one we are experiencing, rumours, false information and truncated or unverified information are multiplying at breakneck speed. This is especially true online. Based on the doubts and fears of citizens, they contribute to the distrust of our fellow citizens towards institutions and are a real poison for our democracies. Madam and Commissioner, this is one of the conclusions we draw in this annual report on the situation of fundamental rights in the Union in 2018 and 2019. The freedom to inform and be informed is enshrined in Article 11 of the European Charter of Fundamental Rights, which we are celebrating this year's 20th anniversary. Today, there is an urgent need for action, as the protection of journalists, especially investigative journalists, is not sufficiently assured in all Member States. Let us give ourselves the means, including legislation, to effectively combat the creators and broadcasters of false information. Let us financially support free and independent media throughout Europe, including local news organizations close to our fellow citizens. The challenge, ladies and gentlemen, is to affirm the right of every citizen to have quality information to form his own opinions.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mrs Keller, and many greetings to Strasbourg, where we should be and where we would like to return, if circumstances permit.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report on the fundamental rights of the European Union genuinely seems to be a programme of a left-wing party, indeed, to put it all, of the extreme left. There are passages that frankly are really partisan and embarrassing. I will just tell you a few of the many that I have been able to read. You are talking about a European Union that has witnessed the spread of racism, Islamophobic sentiments, hostility and intolerance towards Muslims, but you say nothing, and I say nothing, about terrorism, about the victims of attacks, about those who hate us Europeans, our way of life, our culture and our values. On the contrary, you go so far as to say that anti-terrorism policies must not lead to discrimination. It is absurd and shameful! On the immigration side you take issue with those who defend borders, security and national sovereignty, such as Matteo Salvini. You talk about the criminalisation of solidarity, against rejections against the law, about racist policies that violate human rights, but no words of condemnation against human traffickers, against those who promote illegal immigration, against NGOs that systematically violate national laws, and not even anything against those who, through the business of reception, profit on migrants to enrich themselves. There is even a passage in the report against police officers and their abuse. You say that the use of force must be restricting in order to avoid disproportionate reactions, but not a reference to the violence that men and women in uniform suffer every day. That is intolerable! In short, this European Union is now just a pathetic concentration of propaganda. Then, in short, do not be surprised if the citizens have less and less confidence in you.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: – Mr President, respect for fundamental rights is under threat, especially in times of crisis and especially regarding minorities. We often address the discrimination and violations regarding the LGBTI community and ethnic minorities, and we rightly do so. But we should also take a strong stance towards the grave violations at our external borders – people who are not our inhabitants but who are under our control and depend on our rules and behaviour. We know the situation on the Greek islands, for instance. People are held there in deplorable circumstances and I think that we should share this responsibility. Other people, who try to reach our territory, try to find their way to protection, are treated without dignity, denied access to an asylum procedure, and pushed back to third countries without getting information or any individual assessment on their need for protection. Let me be clear: this is not by accident. This is by systematic behaviour and even policies – Greece, Turkey; Poland, Belarus; Spain, Morocco; Hungary, Serbia – and in some countries – Croatia – they even face torture, humiliation and sexual abuse. It’s important that the rapporteur, in her famous explanatory statement, describes these circumstances. Although Frontex must monitor and promote respect for fundamental rights at the border, we recently learnt that this agency is complicit in pushbacks. Silence is implicitly approving these violations. The Commission must ....  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report is a manifesto of the so-called 'woke' ideology, which is so fashionable: a criticism of the citizens of the European Union for their retrograde culture, for their racism, for LGBT homophobia, for their Islamophobia, for their lack of solidarity with migrants. I had hoped that in this report there would also be a word about the right to pray in a church, or to be able to draw a cartoon, or to be able to teach in a school without risking being beheaded. On the other hand, with regard to legal immigration, is it not also a fundamental right to the security of European citizens, often guaranteed by those police officers unjustly criminalised in the report? Not to mention freedom of political initiative or thought, often suppressed on charges of violating the rule of law. Professor Kleinermann is right, saying: 'I have fled communist Romania and today I find myself fighting in the West against the same ideology'. Here, we're with him.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, we would like to denounce the fact that at a symbolic gathering in honour of the popular uprising of the Polytechnic University in Greece, with a common admission of all protection measures, the ban on the assembly of more than three people was activated, an of repression, the dissolution of a concentration, MAT, auras, the pre-election of Members, as well as a prosecutor's intervention in the presence of political leaders. All this from a government that moved 6,000 police officers without any protections, beating labour, popular rights, with criminal responsibilities for hospitals innocently, with tragic shortages of ICU, staff, infrastructure, workplaces and public transport hotbeds of overtransmission.  These are a strategy of the European Union, because its will prohibits the right to strikes, demonstrations, trade union action, the rights of refugees, and even to photograph arbitrariness by repressive forces such as in France, while tracking applications are activated. The Greek government's bans were cancelled in practice. The people in their determined struggle demonstrate that, as they know how to protect their health much better than governments and the European Union, they will also do so for their rights.

name: Lena DÜPONT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has Politics begins with the consideration of reality. This is also served, among other things, by the annual reports on the state of fundamental rights in the European Union. This one takes up different topics and, yes, puts his finger in the right wound at different points. What bothers me, however, is that the report is partly skewed, partly oversubscribed, and the Union sometimes arrests for things that are either not solely in its power to shape, where the Union is struggling intensively to improve or where the Union has already agreed on decisive improvement. In so doing, the report gives the impression of an inescapable fate, of an immutable state of affairs, and thus plays into the hands of the very actors who are directed against Europe anyway. At the same time, it accepts to further restrict the scope for action on essential issues.  Take the example of security, an issue that has not only moved our citizens to the European elections, which – without having to look into the glass sphere – has certainly not lost its relevance in 2020. In the report, the subject appears mainly from the point of view of freedom and data protection. However, this is a slippery slope, because we cannot play security off against data protection. We need a balance between these important goods. Terrorist content online, the protection of children from abuse and the spread of online representations, abuses on the Internet, hate speech and the resulting acts are just the latest examples of this. Data protection must never become the protection of perpetrators.  Politics begins with the consideration of reality. And this reality is never one-sided and tendentious, it is complex, complex and differentiated. Our ambition should be no less than that. I want a Union that tackles, that provides answers, that takes seriously the concerns of its citizens, a Union that strives to reconcile security and freedom, sustainability and growth, personal responsibility and social responsibility, a Union that is committed to shaping, that is aware of its weaknesses and strives every day to turn them into strengths.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, the report examining the situation, problems and challenges facing the fulfilment of the European mandate for respect for fundamental rights was approved by the committee which I have the honour to chair, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, last week, by a majority of 34 votes against 23. These 34 votes included the votes of the Socialists, the Greens, the Liberals and the United Left , from which the rapporteur comes, and had the votes against the People's Party, ECR and ID, which are the most conservative groups in this House. I am therefore part of the progressive and European majority's vote in favour of the progressive majority expressing concern about the situation of equal rights, the rights of migrants, compliance with the rule of law, prison rights and the mandate to comply with the European Convention on Human Rights. But something has been said in this debate that I must deny. Article 55(2) of the Rules of Procedure of that House states that, if the statement of reasons has not been agreed by that majority which adopted the Resolution, and is also inconsistent with the content of the Resolution, the President may cancel it. But above all, it must be cancelled if requested by the rapporteurs who worked on this resolution, who add up to the votes of the majority in the Committee on Freedoms. So, that's the assumption. Things have been said in this Resolution that are not consistent with the explanal statement and the explanal statement includes a reference to a situation which is not only the subject of political controversy, but may be demented by political arguments, but the legal argument is that Article 55(2) orders the ... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Lopez Aguilar. I would like to point out once again that you must make speeches on a point of order one hour in advance and that we do not have blue cards or a catch-the-eye procedure. I am very sorry.

name: Jean-Lin LACAPELLE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as usual, this Parliament, called upon to vote on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union, is ruling on the defence of minorities, LGBTI, asylum, migrants, in short all visible minorities favoured by the system. On the other hand, too little too little about the right of a child to grow up in safety and dignity and to be able to reach adulthood normally. Indeed, I would like to remind you that our society has a duty to protect our children and I would particularly like to draw your attention to the sexual crimes against children who are victims and which are on the rise. This Parliament, in defence of fundamental rights, must set clear objectives on the protection of our children. Firstly, by setting a European age of sexual consent which will de facto lead to a single definition of rape of minors in the Member States. Currently, depending on the country, this sexual majority varies from 14 to 18 years, so there is a need for harmonization of the age of consent. Secondly, the European Union must rule against the correction of cases of rape of minors. In France, as in many Member States, several paedophile acts against minors, which are crimes, are reclassified as a misdemeanour under the charge of sexual assault allowing the victim's consent to be invoked. Under no circumstances can a child under the age of 15 be considered consenting. Finally, like a file of perpetrators of terrorist acts, a European file of perpetrators of sexual offences and violence against children must be created, which would enable European police to cooperate better. Colleagues, I therefore invite you to follow these recommendations to ensure the well-being and future of our children.

name: Gwendoline DELBOS-CORFIELD
text: Mr President, in crises, always and almost always, our governments seek to reduce rights and freedoms in order to concentrate power in their hands, under the pretext of efficiency. It is forgetting that democracy and civic engagement are powerful tools to face difficulties. These deprivations of rights and freedoms first affect the most vulnerable among us, because our societies are very unequal and social protections are inadequate. Minorities, especially Roma populations, migrants and the poor have suffered greatly from the disease, the increasing misery, the discrimination and the still great exclusion. Women have suffered increased economic and social violence, but also physical and moral violence in their own homes, because our societies still favour the patriarchal model and male oppression remains widely regarded, legitimate. Children have sometimes been deprived of school, have sometimes been abused, but again the disparities are significant between those who have access to a garden, a corner of nature, access to knowledge, culture, and those who are locked up, prevented from going out, in tiny, stifling spaces, in families devoid of everything. Our children have not experienced the same health crisis.

name: Patryk JAKI
