text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will consistently unscrew the lie in this report about the alleged LGBT-free zones that exist in Poland. Well, such zones do not exist. I would like to tell you that the only thing that exists is the declaration by several local authorities of the affirmation of the traditional family model, of affirmation exactly as one of the founding fathers of the European Union saw it, or as the Polish Constitution sees it.  Since when is such a view prohibited? On the contrary: what do the Treaties say? Article 3 of the Treaty states that the European Union respects its cultural diversity. Since when does this point not work? Secondly, the declaration annexed to the Treaties on the Charter of Fundamental Rights states: The Charter does not in any way affect the right of Member States to legi law on public morality or family law. Since when does this passage not work? In your view, the rule of law that you mention in this report is to break the Treaties where you do not like the provisions of those treaties. This is not the rule of law, it is a violation of the rule of law.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: – Mr President, let's talk about fundamental rights. Today, in Spain, the president of the Parliament of Catalonia celebrates eleven years in prison for having allowed a parliamentary debate. The members of the Catalan Government, of which I was a member, are serving ten years or more in prison, up to thirteen years, for organising a referendum. The leaders of major civil society organizations serve nine years in prison for participating in a peaceful demonstration.  Yes, some of the rights discussed in this report are seriously infringed in Spain today. And what do some in this Parliament do about this? Censor, delete the phrase from the explana motives of this report where this reality is denounced. So, what are you trying to do? Hide the truth? Do you intend us to spend all day demanding that Hungary and Poland behave like true rule of law, but instead give Spain carte blanche to run over the most fundamental civil political rights? If we give carte blanche to Spain, we are giving it to everyone, and without guarantee of civil and political rights, the European project is finished.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Tomorrow, as every year on 25 November, we celebrate international day for the elimination of violence against women. It's a day to remind us how much suffering and harm women and girls face around the world. But it is not enough to remember and look at this problem once a year. And we are saying this very clearly in the human rights report under discussion today. We must fight violence against women and domestic violence every day, at any time, and I would like to emphasise that this is a struggle between all of us, regardless of gender, religion or tradition. Violence against women is evil and there can be no discussion here.  In the fight against violence against women and domestic violence, the voice of men is still too weak, and we still oppose it too little. So from here, as a man, as a feminist and as rapporteur for the decision on the accession of the entire European Union to the istanbul anti-violence convention, I would like to appeal: let us all join this fight without exception, now.  And to right-wing fundamentalists and their absurd narrative of gender ideology, I would like to say: in an open and democratic society, there is no room to justify violence with tradition or religion, as you do. There is no room for pseudoscientiferous gibberish, which you want to explain the worse treatment of women. There are more people who love equality and freedom. You won't win with us, you can't do it.

name: Vincenzo SOFO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is very easy to understand the situation of fundamental rights in Europe. On the one hand, there are you, who invent pseudo-rights with which to destroy the unity of peoples through unbridled immigration and make their identities disappear through multicultural and LGBT witchcraft. On the other hand, there are europeans, who have lost the right to go to church without risking being cut, who have lost the right to claim a family with father and mother because they are persecuted by you in the name of the gender god, who have lost their right to health and are seized by COVID because of the cuts in public health that you have called for in recent years , which have lost their right to work as a result of those relocations and unfair competitions that you have favoured in the name of the market god. Thus, while, under the guise of rights, you are submitting Europeans to your ideologies and taking away their right to dissent, with your perverse policies you are condemning them to poverty, social abandonment and the dictatorship of single thought. So here is your project: to deceive Europeans with the mirage of false rights in order to prevent them from finding out what you are stealing from them: well-being, identity and freedom.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Mr President, it is a pity, although not a surprise, that the report on fundamental rights is once again dominated by leftist ideology, which is not representative of Europe, and by all the fashionable litanies. Countries such as Hungary or Poland or Bulgaria are again singled out for violations of rights when, in fact, they are attacked for not implementing social democratic policies that their electorates do not want. Rights are called for illegal immigrants when they should be called for Europeans run over by immigration, Europeans who have had their right to safe and respected borders taken away. But it is a scandal that they forget the worst dismantling of the democratic state in the history of the European Union, which occurs in Spain, and not because of what that coupista who has intervened before says. Under the social-community government there are undemocratic aberrations that, of course, are hidden here and which we all regret. What is happening at the moment in Spain is a reason to think of article 7, and not that persecution that has been mounted against the two countries... (inaudible words).

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, speaking of fundamental rights, we are actually talking about protecting and preserving democracy.  Any democracy must have the tools to make it impossible for an individual or a small group of people to take all power, it must have the tools to disable dictatorship. In the old years, dictatorships were mostly military; Today we are threatened by a potential financial dictatorship, therefore, in the world, and so in Europe, you have from America to China a small group of extremely wealthy people, billionaires have formed. They get richer as time goes on, we see this crisis has made them even stronger. The individual is richer than entire nations, so you have an individual who is richer than entire nations in the world, several of them richer than billions of people. These people have not only acquired this with their skills, but have this to thank the society in which they worked and developed.  So, I propose to limit the wealth of these people and use this as one of the sources of funding for universal basic income schemes.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr President, the report on respect for fundamental rights in the Union comes up every year. Each time, its content is quite loaded and nothing that should appeal to us, perhaps even worry us. In any case, it never seems to lose its usefulness as many of the fundamental rights are violated, year after year, in some of the Member States of the Union. The report points out that over the past two years, reforms contrary to the rule of law and democracy have been taken. It is impossible to list here all the violations committed on European territory in this area, but to judge them: infringement of the independence of the judiciary and freedom of expression, restriction of action by journalists, attacks on the safety of LGBTI people and migrants, not to mention women's rights and access to abortion, which are increasingly threatened. This report therefore aims to send a clear message not only to the Member States, but also to the Commission. All the more so because being harsh on the situation of fundamental rights is not the preserve of the Usual Suspects of the European Union. At this very moment, for example in France, the question of the Interior Minister's plans on respect for press freedom is raised unabashedly. As such, the Union is not à la carte, but also demanding for all. It must be exemplary and guarantee to all citizens without distinction respect for their fundamental rights.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – Many great words are in this House, words – it would seem – important and necessary. Issues such as women's rights, the rights of religious, ethnic, national minorities, the fight against violence against the most vulnerable are and should be a priority for the European Parliament, but listening to the emotional and exalted speeches of the representatives of the left of the Chamber, I get the impression that important issues are becoming an ideological engine today, a kind of verbal mace to try to model a new great world.  For many members of Parliament, including the European Commission, huxlejowa utopia is becoming an excuse today to point out some countries or governments as a kind of savages who, as in Huxley's novel, must accept these ideological ideas or be punished. Countries such as Poland and Hungary have experienced for decades the boon of communists, communist oppression. And today the ideological heirs of those communists instruct and threaten our countries in the name of a new ideology. There was talk of a delirium engulfing the right on the arguments on the left side of the chamber. Well, I can quote one of the fathers ... (the President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are on the threshold of 2021 and it is very sad that, here in Europe too, fundamental rights are for many but not for everyone. We talk all the time about freedom, justice and equality, but knowing that we cannot guarantee them here either. Even today, even in Europe, thousands of women and children are victims of trafficking in human beings, sold as slaves, killed or forced into prostitution. Why have not all the Member States of the European Union ratified the Istanbul Convention? Is it because not all Member States have the same desire to fight for fundamental rights and to protect women and children? Let us remember that half of the victims of trafficking in human beings come from the countries of the European Union. Prostitution is legalised in some Member States, and it is here that traffickers transfer a large part of their victims for less control. As long as prostitution is allowed to be regarded as a job, and not as exploitation or violence, we would do well to stop talking hypocritically and to admit that economic interests in Europe too take precedence over the rights of women and children.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is sad, but true: this report shows that the situation of fundamental rights in Europe is deteriorating further. We have seen so much in recent months: there is virtually no freedom of the press in Hungary, NGOs are experiencing incredible repression. In Poland, the independence of the courts is gradually being abolished and the rights of Polish women are being further and further restricted. At our EU external borders, pushbacks and violence against those seeking protection are now a sad reality. The report shows that we, as the European Parliament – and this is democracy – are consistently on the side of fundamental rights. What, if not the fundamental rights and freedoms, is what makes our European Union? They form the foundation on which we stand and for who we are. It is precisely respect for democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law that is our legal and moral basis. And that is exactly what we are making clear once again with this report.  One of the logical consequences of this is that we must not give in to the commitment of EU funds to respect for the rule of law. We must not and will not allow countries that for years have systematically dismantled their own constitutional state and seem to want to continue to do so to prevent this historic and so important rule of law mechanism.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, numerous treaties, resolutions and plans are dedicated to improving the fundamental rights of people in Europe, and although these plans are often ambitious, the implementation lacks true conviction, and as a result, not enough progress has been made to secure the fundamental rights in Europe. In fact, a serious backlash against women’s and LGBTI rights has ensued, with anti-gender movements trying to limit sexual and reproductive health and rights. And the Covid crisis has not been helping at all. According to a Fundamental Rights Agency report, nearly 17 million women in the EU experienced either physical or sexual violence over the period of 12 months preceding the survey. Those numbers are absolutely unacceptable, and we must begin to realise that gender-based violence is both the consequence and one of the causes of persisting gender inequalities. Unfortunately, some Member States are champions in maintaining these fundamental inequalities between men and women, and as long as Member States promote campaigns against the Istanbul Convention, and as long as the Council blocks directives on equal treatment of women on boards, I am afraid progress will remain limited. We need firmer action and shared commitment if we want to make a difference in the years ahead.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, allow me, once again, to thank you for the report and to recall that all actors have a role to play to renew our commitment to fundamental rights, the rule of law and democracy, be it at national, European or international level, and that we are fully committed to play ours. The Charter of Fundamental Rights is a symbol of our shared European identity. It reminds us that we all belong to a community of values, a community where fundamental rights are respected, a community where democracy and the rule of law prevail. These rights and values cannot be taken for granted. New fundamental rights challenges have emerged, for instance, also from the COVID-19 crisis, as many of you mentioned in your speeches.  As I noted, in December I will present a new charter strategy to foster awareness and effective use of the charter in the EU, and I count on your support, the support of the European Parliament, to promote it and to play its unique role in the charter enforcement chain.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 25 November 2020. The final vote will take place on Thursday 26 November 2020. Before we move on to the next debate, I give the floor to Mr Boeselager, who has asked for a point of order under Rule 195.

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: – Mr President, I have a point of order regarding the deletion of an amendment that refers to the powers of the European Parliament of being the only competent authority to waive the immunity of its Members. The report we are about to discuss addresses the EU elections in 2019. These have been somewhat incomplete because some of our Members were not able to take their rightful seat in this House: a House that is protected and independent. Oriol Junqueras is one of these Members. Our amendment deplored that he is not present in this House with us, urging the European Parliament’s President to recognise the judgment of our highest judicial body: the Court of Justice of the European Union. The EP is to follow the Court’s judgment, even if the national judiciary does not. This is a case of primacy of EU law. Rule 181 of the Rules of Procedure thus does not apply to make this amendment inadmissible. I am deeply concerned and worried about how technical rules are used for political purposes, and I would therefore like to make a point of order to re-admit our amendment to the report and to have Parliament vote on it.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mr Boeselager. The President was unable to accept the last sentence of the amendment you tabled because he asked to defend Mr Junqueras' immunity, although Mr Junqueras is not currently a Member of the European Parliament. That is why the President is sticking to this decision.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on pascal Durand's report on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs on the stocktaking of the European Parliament elections (2020/2088(INI)) (A9-0211/2020). I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches in all the debates of this part-session and that no blue cards are accepted. It also provides for interconnection from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, so are elections, so is politics, much like all shows: you can choose the corner of the projector. We can decide to shed some light on certain facts, we can decide to leave others in the shadows and finally talk only about what suits us or, on the contrary, what we want to criticize. We have tried with my colleagues in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, and I would like to pay tribute to them, to leave nothing aside and to have a balanced position between what we have enjoyed in these elections and what has made us less satisfied. I'd still like to start by taking a look in the rearview mirror. Where do we come from? It is 2019 and we are talking about the direct universal suffrage election of the European Parliament. We are 40 years after the creation of this Parliament. We are almost at the birth of this parliamentary democracy in Europe. Let us all keep in mind that we are moving forward, that our democracy is progressing, and that this Parliament was originally not elected by universal suffrage and was composed of representatives of national parliaments. So we have taken a very important step and this election has reinforced this progress. The first thing I want to emphasize, of course, is participation. Everyone was pleased with the increase in participation. We have more than 50% turnout in these European elections and, when I hear everywhere that Europe does not represent directly, etc., I say that it is more than 200 million, I mean 200 million European citizens, who voted in the European elections. We all had dark circles a few days or weeks ago, watching American channels to try to find out the outcome of the elections in the United States. We have 30 million more voters who elect our Parliament. So let us not be modest: let us accept the fact that European democracy is strong, that it is progressing and that, yes, citizens are interested in its future, it is very important. It is also very important to note that this turnout has increased, because young people have appropriated this election. And if young people have appropriated this election - this is the point I want to emphasise and I am obviously turning to the opponents of the European Union - it is because they believe that the European level is the right lever to respond to difficulties and crises, but also to address the issues to come. On climate issues, on security issues, on issues of democracy and human rights, on social issues, Europe's youth have understood that we will only be able to resolve these issues through our continental power and not simply in the withdrawals of identity and national issues. And that is indeed very important. However, participation is not equal everywhere and it must be noted that in some states participation is still very low. We must improve this situation, we must continue to communicate, we must ensure that democracy is progressing uniformly throughout the European Union. But, as I said, we have some good news. We also have less good ones. As I said, some countries are not mobilising around the European election, but we also have a whole part of the European population who cannot take part in these elections. I am talking about the weakest people, the people with disabilities. In some countries, it is extremely difficult to vote. I am talking about some communities that cannot freely access the right to vote in some European countries, this is unacceptable, it has to change. We also have to see the lack of diversity in our Parliament. Of course we have to make progress on this issue, there is a whole part of the European population that is not represented in our institutions, that has to change.  This must also change for diversity and gender equality. Yes, there is a progression, from 37 to 41 per cent of women in this Parliament. Yes, it is an increase, but 41% is still far from the 51% or 52% that we should reach. So that's a goal, you have to do it. We must indeed ensure that this Parliament has a real, effective parity between women and men.  And then analysing a situation is good, but I will end by saying that we also have to make proposals. I talked about the good news, but there is a bad one: the principle of the top candidate has not, as it stands, been understood by the Voters. Just 8% of European voters said that this question of the top candidate was at the heart of their vote. We must therefore move forward, reflect on the capacity that parliamentary democracy can implement so that European citizens actually vote for a European candidate. And here we must have the courage to debate all subjects such as transnational lists, the single constituency, is it not Mrs Jourov, it is in your portfolio, these are subjects which we must debate without fear, without fear, simply because they are at the heart of European democracy. There are many other subjects, Mr President, but I will stop there. We have made progress, we still have progress to make.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission welcomes this report and thanks the rapporteur, Mr Durand, for his efforts to present a detailed stock-taking of the last elections, as well as to outline guidance of this Parliament on several key issues of high institutional and constitutional importance. We share the aspiration expressed in the report to strengthen the European dimension of the European elections and to promote broad and inclusive participation in European democracy.  In June 2020, the Commission published its own report on the 2019 elections. The report looked at the conduct of the last European elections and analysed measures taken to enhance transparency, to protect free and fair elections, and to promote the democratic participation of all EU citizens, to strengthen the European dimension of the elections, and to ensure resilient electoral processes. It was based on substantial input received from Member States authorities, in particular from the European Cooperation Network on Elections and the Expert group on electoral matters.  Our findings have shown that young and first-time voters drove turnout figures to a record high, the first increase since the 1970s and the highest in 25 years. It was also an election where the institutions and Member States cooperated closely and effectively to communicate with citizens. A dynamic European debate emerged on a number of topics showing progress in developing a European political dimension. In the report, the Commission announced that it would continue to intensify its communication activities, to support inclusion policies and to engage with the Member States in the framework of the European Cooperation Network on Elections, on best practices in this area, including on data and reporting. The network in fact already touched on these subjects at its most recent meetings in July and September, and also discussed practices and experience in adapting elections and democracy to the post-COVID environment, which was warmly welcomed by Member States and which will continue.  We also indicated some opportunities for European political parties to support the effort to increase turnout, in particular through communications efforts, to increase inclusive participation, and through awareness-raising about the elections, and how the EU works.  In the next week, the Commission will adopt the European Democracy Action Plan. In this plan, we aim to protect our European democracies against today’s challenges and make them more resilient in order to ensure that citizens are able to participate in the democratic systems through informed decision-making free from unlawful interference and manipulation. The Action Plan will focus on safeguarding the integrity of our elections, on countering disinformation and on supporting free and independent media, and also build on the lessons learned from the ongoing COVID-19 crisis.  It will also cover active citizenship and strengthening of civil society. The international dimension of these initiatives is a thread running through the whole plan. It will announce legislative proposals to ensure greater transparency of paid political advertising, alongside non-legislative measures and further initiatives to tackle disinformation and to protect the media. I am glad that the Durand Report focuses also on institutional matters such as the lead candidate. With the upcoming European Parliament reports and the hopefully soon to be launched Conference on the Future of Europe, we will be able to discuss together with citizens and Member States the shape of the next elections. Let me repeat that I remain ready to act as an honest broker in this field where the Commission’s initiative, as you know, is limited. From our side, we are ready to join the debate and to make available legal and institutional expertise, research on electoral processes and insight into interinstitutional relations if this Parliament and the Council deem it useful. I would also like to mention two of the files where the Commission has the right of initiative. The Regulation on the Statute and funding of the European political parties and foundations. As announced in the work programme for the next year, we will propose a revision aiming for clearer rules, for instance on the financing. We will also propose legislation to ensure greater transparency of paid political advertising, alongside non-legislative measures, ensuring transparency and accountability, in particular online, is essential. All this with a view to adoption well in time ahead of the 2024 elections.  To summarise: on behalf of the Commission I can assure you that we will do our best to ensure that citizens’ confidence in our democratic process and decision-making only increases in the years to come.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, dear Pascal, thank you for your work and for the effort you have made to make us all feel comfortable in this report.  The past European elections left important lessons to be learned. For the first time we have seen a significant increase in participation. Contrary to what Eurosceptics say, Europe matters to citizens. However, although moderate and pro-European parties have clearly won the elections, many citizens preferred populist and nationalist options, something we respect but should be concerned about. On the other hand, the main candidate system has failed, because of the Council's refusal to accept as President of the Commission the person who won the elections and because we were not able to defend him. The overall assessment of elections is positive, European democracy works, but there are many things that can be done better.  We all agree that sooner sooner sooner without later, the European Union will have to face its own democratic revolution and, if it does not do so out of conviction, it will have to do so out of necessity.  The world in which we live is very little like the world we knew only a decade ago, when we signed the Lisbon Treaty. Leaving the pandemic aside, in 2000, for example, few could imagine that in the 21st century nationalist movements, populist movements, economic protectionism and political authoritarianism would resurface. Just like a hundred years ago. Few could imagine that, within the European Union, we would have to go out again in defence of freedom of the press, the rule of law, the rights of women or those who are persecuted for their sexual orientation or for their religion. Few could imagine that something as far-fetched as Brexit could happen.  We had taken refuge in the economy, we had left behind principles and values, thinking that others would defend them for us. We were wrong. When authoritarianism is growing in the world, our silence does not make us victims, but accomplices.  Europe is neither a state nor aspires to be a state. If the policy and pressure of national governments does not prevent it, next year we will hold a Conference on the Future of Europe in which all the points in this report will be on the table; for example, Europe's aspiration to become a federation with a representative government and a bicameral parliament of citizens and states. There, We Europeans have a historic opportunity to collectively decide what we want to be and what role we want to play in the future: whether we settle for being just a market or aspire to be something more valuable.

name: Giuliano PISAPIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, elections are always the most sensitive and important moment in the life of a democracy. Since 1979, participation in the European elections has always fallen. Last year, however, the trend reversed: there was the highest participation rate in twenty years. The announced breakthrough of eurosceptic forces has not happened. A new interest in the European Union has developed, it has grown. The citizens of Europe still believed in the integration project and went to the polls convinced that their vote could be the engine of change. It is now up to us to proceed along the path they have shown us. We cannot disappoint those who still look to a united Europe, a Europe that believes in solidarity, in the rule of law, in the ability to face and overcome the great global challenges. Our task is also to rekindle hopes where they had died. Progress has been made in this year and a half. Compared with the last parliamentary term, the number of Members has increased. I appreciate and appreciate the Commission's female leadership, but the road to real equality is still too long. Only 5 % of Members belong to a minority, yet they make up 10 % of the European population. The vote has often been denied to inmates and the homeless. Some 800 000 disabled people were unable to vote because of problems with access to seats. Here, the report on the 2019 elections examines the past and the present, but looks above all to the future. Planning the future is the objective and task of this Parliament. The citizens have asked us to rediscover the path mapped out by the founding mothers and fathers of the Union. We need to work harder and harder. Jean Monnet recalled: 'Nothing is possible without men, but nothing lasts without the institutions'.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I declare the first round of voting open. You can vote until 12.15 p.m. The results of today's first round of voting will be announced at 3 p.m.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We are now continuing our debate on the report by Pascal Durand (A9-0211/2020) (2020/2088(INI)).

name: Sandro GOZI
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Pascal Durand on his balanced and ambitious report. There is, however, one major point: these European elections are still too little European. Despite a higher turnout, the debates remain stuck in a purely national pen in the 27 member countries. Let's be on this election! I'd say, let's put the church back in the middle of the village. For an accomplished European democracy, it is essential to promote a genuine transnational political space. There is no real European political movement today. Yet imagine the impact in terms of strength and legitimacy. It is remember that it was above all to solve these problems that the idea of transnational lists was born. Let us promote a genuinely European debate through the emergence of transnational political movements with visions and programmes on the Union and directly elected by citizens. Let us be ambitious for May 2024 and double the democratic choices of the citizens. They will be able to vote for a national list and a transnational list. It is a question of legitimacy, it is a question of democracy, it is a question of visibility so that citizens understand what they are doing. So, Mr President, let us stop pretending, we want to have leading candidates for the presidency of the European Commission. Therefore, logic would have it that, in order to achieve this objective, it is essential to have lists. The agreement reached at the beginning of this Parliament provided for work on improving the top-of-the-list system, but also for implementing transnational lists. The two go hand in hand: no top of the list, no list, I would say. Our time is running out: implementing the reform of the electoral law in the 27 countries of the Union will take time, we must launch it now in order to complete it on time for a true European and transnational democracy.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: on behalf of the ID Group. Mr President, this report – and I am sorry to assume that the rapporteur will rather take this as a compliment – is for the time being the most extremist document produced by the centralist, federalist and 'Europeanist' elite within this European Parliament during this parliamentary term.  Firstly, the document is bulging with the confusion that is very common in the circles of extremist supporters of the European Union between Europe, the continent, the type of civilisation, the cultural data on the one hand, and the European Union on the other. I call myself a supporter of Europe, a representative of European cultural identity, founded on the added value of the differences. In my view, however, the European Union is only an institution, an organisation and a way of working together agreed by a treaty between independent Member States.  The proponents of pushing a European Union as a comprehensive and as comprehensive unitary state as possible have appropriated the broad and rich concept of Europe, invariably call their European Union 'Europe', and their actions and their expansions of powers invariably 'European', usually followed by a noun: European health care, European single currency, European immigration, European economy, in all cases they call European progress , and today here a real European electoral law.  Of course full of the time-honoured dadas proclaimed here, as if it were the ten commandments that Moses – mr Durand in this case in this case – brought from the mountain. The territory of the European Union as a single electoral definition. One general electoral list – the transnational list. The Member States will be abolished, because in the European Union the Member States will no longer be the Council of the European Union, but a subordinate second legislative chamber, a kind of advisory body of this Parliament. The national political parties are gradually being replaced by transnational European political parties, which will logically have only one programme and may have only one programme later: the programme of further integration of this European Union. In short, ladies and gentlemen, the extremism of the European Union is at a new high today. As a committed European, in favour of a unity of free peoples, I would like to say this in a clear light to warn against it.

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all let me thank Pascal Durand for presenting this very good report, an ambitious report with very good compromises, I think, bringing together most of the groups. I want to remind everyone in this House that this House already decides on laws that affect 450 million Europeans and maybe potentially many more across the world. I hope that at one point this House will also be able to initiate laws and will field a European government, hopefully. This House is already a beacon of European democracy and I think it’s really important that we try to increase legitimacy and that we try to improve the way we are elected into this House, at all times. I think the report shows ways to do this.  First of all, I think it’s very important that we set minimum standards to ensure that there’s a trusted process. That means minimum standards when it comes to the registration of a party, when it comes to the registration of this party for the European parliamentary elections, when it comes to internal party democracy about how to field candidates, when it comes to party financing and fraud control, and when it comes to the election procedures at the actual election date.  Second, and this has already been mentioned by some colleagues, we need to Europeanise these elections. It’s not enough that we all work in our national context to try to put forward European topics. We need to have an actual European debate about European topics and I think there are some ways to discuss this further, as has been discussed for transnationalist Spitzenkandidaten. But we should also try to regionalise and localise the elections so that parliamentarians are closer to their citizens as much as possible, so that people have some people to relate to and to reach out to.  I think we should not shy away from any of these discussions. We should discuss all the options on the table to be able to improve our electoral procedures. When we look across the Atlantic, I think we can see how important it is to have trusted procedures, especially when it comes to the transition of powers. Let us not waste this legislative chance, let us try to improve the electoral law.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, honourable Members, once again the left-liberal majority in this Chamber has made it clear that it is excited and dealing with issues that have nothing to do with the agenda of the societies of the citizens of European countries.  At the moment, citizens of European countries are excited about two things. How will the effects of the health crisis, the pandemic be overcome, and how the economy will be maintained. Against this background, in this Chamber, the European Parliament has consistently continued to engage in imposing diktaticism on small groups that have identified themselves as minorities in societies, to give federalist ideas, to engage in ideas such as, the leading PES candidate, among others, is an example of how the idea of a leading candidate fails. They had elevated a leading candidate, tricked their constituents into voting for him and elected another person to chair the Commission, only showing that double standards are welcome when they come from the left, when they come from socialists, liberals, etc.  I pay attention to you, the agenda at the moment is not how to make a federalist union, the agenda is how to preserve jobs and the lives and health of citizens of European countries.

name: Leila CHAIBI
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you Pascal Durand for this very good report. I wanted to talk to you about my little cousin Clotilde, who's 16. She has participated in all the climate protests for a year and family meals, you can't stop her when she starts trying to convince the whole family of the ecological emergency. Clotilde has a strong opinion about society, but yet, when it is election day, she has no right to speak at the ballot box. I also wanted to talk to you about Lorenzo, who is 16 years old. He's Italian. He has the right to open his own clothing store, he even has the right to be the owner of a restaurant. On the other hand, voting is niente, forbidden at his age. I wanted to talk to you about 16-year-old Tobias. He's German. He has the right to buy beer, he is allowed to go out in a disco with his friends of 16 years, but he is not allowed to vote. I'll also tell you about Carmen, who is 16. She's Spanish. She works 40 hours a week and has the right to get married. Yet she is not allowed to vote, nor is she. Clotilde, Lorenzo, Tobias, Carmen and then the majority of 16-year-olds in Europe get involved. They are committed to the climate, to equality between women and men, but they do not have the right to participate in democracy, they do not have the right to elect the representatives who will decide how life should be organized in the society in which they live. You know, before women had the right to vote, before the under-21s had the right to vote, they were said to be, they were told, to justify their exclusion from political life, that their too low maturity of mind could not allow them to take an intelligent part in the conduct of public affairs. It seems obsolete when you say that, yet these are the same arguments that we hear here about the right to vote at 16. So I would like to ask those who oppose the idea of the right to vote at 16, are you not afraid to end up with a Hemicycle transformed by the arrival in the polls, because of the arrival in the polling stations of Clotilde, Lorenzo, Tobias, Carmen and all the others? On the contrary, I believe that it is high time to restore generational balance by rejuvenating the electoral body in order to match the political weight of youth with its weight in society.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Pascal Durand for his report. On the European elections, two things come to my mind.  First, how the Spanish Electoral Commission first tried to exclude myself and my colleagues from running on the list and then, when that failed and we got elected with one million votes, blocked our right to be MEPs for six months.  Second, Oriol Junqueras, my former colleague in government, is still in jail and was condemned to 13 years behind bars, despite his being an elected MEP. The Spanish Supreme Court did not care about this or about his immunity and violated the rights of MEPs. This is a shame. All MEPs should defend the right of Oriol Junqueras to be an MEP by voting for Amendment 49. Electoral rules cannot depend on Member States. Today it is Spain, tomorrow, who knows? As Mr Durand proposed in his report, we need a European electoral authority that ensures the respect for European rule of law with an effective tool, a new European electoral law.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Senhor Presidente, em primeiro lugar, queria naturalmente felicitar-me e felicitar-nos a todos pela participação eleitoral que houve em 2019. Foi, de facto, uma prova de vida da União Europeia e da cidadania europeia. Queria também cumprimentar o colega Durand pelo seu relatório, relativamente ao qual tenho várias discordâncias, mas no texto principal, no texto que verdadeiramente conta, ficaram em aberto todas as possibilidades.  Isso foi um esforço importante para que os cidadãos na Conferência sobre o Futuro da Europa tenham liberdade para decidir, sim, porque isso é o mais importante. Se nós queremos repensar o sistema eleitoral europeu, se nós queremos repensar o sistema de designação do Presidente da Comissão, não pode ser o Parlamento, sozinho, a predeterminar e a condicionar o debate da conferência que quis abrir aos cidadãos. And here I turn to English. I have to say to all my colleagues that what Mr Gozi has said here is not acceptable because, first, there is a European political force that is already in place and that is the PPE. Probably, this is not the case for Renew.  Second, because there is no federation with a transnational or a single constituency – there is no federation like that – so why should the European Union have it? Finally, when you say that the President of the Executive should have a kind of trans—European legitimacy, I ask what is the legitimacy of the Chancellor of Germany or of the Prime Minister of England? They are also legitimate and they have their single constituencies. So I urge you all to vote in favour of this report, but to vote against Recital T and to vote in favour of Amendment 26, because they are trying to conditionate the freedom of the Conference on the Future of Europe.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Mr President, before I go into the subject of the report, I would like to address for a moment two colleagues who have spoken before, Mr Annemans and Mr Dzhambazki, who keep talking about the evils of federalism in this House. But I would like to tell you that federalism has not caused any war in Europe, and nationalisms, two world wars, so far. Keep that in mind. Going into the question of the report, as has been said - and I share what colleagues have said - the European elections went well, increased participation, increased the participation of young people, pro-European forces , also a reminder - won the elections widely, by 80%, and now what we are trying to do is see how we can improve European elections in the future , because there is so much to improve. One of the elements that can — 'they can', which is what the report says — contribute to a more effective Transnational European democracy is transnational lists. We therefore support the report in its entirety, because we want this debate to open up, in Parliament and at the Conference on the Future of Europe.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, I would like to support both the rapporteur and some of the speakers in favour of this report, but I would like to point something out to Mr Puigdemont, because it seems that there is only one debate here, which is the debate on how to generate victimism, in a clear case of attack on the democratic rule of law in Spain. Because it is not only states that can become iliberal, but also sub-state entities can attack the democratic rule of law. In Catalonia, in September 2017, the separation of powers with illegal acts was overdulled. That's attacking the democratic rule of law. Populism is not just that of Poland or Hungary or that of some forces that are around. There is absolutely exclusionary identity populism in Catalonia. And here we use all the rights that liberal Democrats give them to lie, to attack the democratic state. Indeed, in Europe we need to defend ourselves against populismos and Europe is necessary to do so.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Pagazaurtunda, allow me to make one comment: even if you do not share everything you say, but I think it was such a moment – we often talk about wanting to make the debates more lively, but when someone simply puts the text of the speech he has prepared on the side and responds to someone who has spoken here before, the speeches become more lively of themselves. , there is no need for any amendment to the Rules of Procedure.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the Durand report gives a strange assessment of the European elections in 2019. I agree with him only on one point. Like him, I welcome the increased participation in the elections, which is an encouraging sign of renewed interest in the democratic process. But I disagree on the explanation of this renewed interest. In France, the reason voters have moved is not because the eu's costly and unnecessary 'I vote' campaign has paid off, it is because they have become passionate about the struggle that the two main lists have been engaged in. That of Jordan Bardella and the National Rally finally triumphed over that of the President of the Republic, Emmanuel Macron. As for drawing from this renewed participation the lesson of citizens' accession to the Union, it is very presumptuous, because in the aftermath of the yellow vest revolt, many voters voted instead to show their distrust of the ultraliberalism of the Union, which they rightly consider to be co-responsible for their misfortune. In an aggravating circumstance, the Durand report not only takes stock of the elections, it takes the pretext of drawing the outline of the reforms which, in his opinion, would improve the Union. But the dream he describes is, in my eyes, a nightmare. The report aims to strengthen the Commission's political role, particularly through the consecration of the top candidate system. On the other hand, I would rather remove any political role from the Commission by transforming it into a mere permanent technical secretariat. The report wants to marginalize the Council by turning it into a second chamber, that is, a kind of Senate. On the other hand, I would rather strengthen his role by entrusting him with the legislative initiative. The report aims to transform the European Parliament into a representative of an untraceable European people with transnational lists, unified electoral law and the creation of a European electoral authority. On the other hand, I would rather think about how to make it more representative of European nations. In conclusion, I oppose the Durand report, because it wants to create a supranational empire, while I am defending the project of a Europe of nations.

name: Diana RIBA I GINER
text: – Mr President, today we are debating a report on the last European elections, and it mentions important issues such as transnational lists, reform of European electoral law or gender equality, but unfortunately the report does not include any mention of the violation of the political rights of the Member-elect to the European Parliament Oriol Junqueras or the three empty seats that this House had for months. There is no mention of the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union, which upheld the member of Oriol Junqueras, nor his right to parliamentary immunity. Nor are the irregularities of the Spanish state, which still holds it imprisoned, mentioned. How do you explain that a report on the European elections does not mention that a Member, with all his rights, was unable to set foot in this House? This circumvention is compounded by the decision of the President of Parliament to declare inadmissible a part of the amendment which speaks of Oriol Junqueras. I ask the President of Parliament to rectify this decision. Ladies and gentlemen, looking the other way, we are doing European democracy a skinny favour.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by According to your call, I will not read your statement. And now I wanted to address a colleague who was poleming with a colleague Dzhambazki. Well, it is true that federalism is not linked – because it is not something that has been done – to any processes that we could criticise. But if you recall the history of Europe, we know that there have been situations where the unification of Europe by force, uniformity, the abolition of cultural differences have led to crime. Yes, even to crime. This is the history of Central and Eastern Europe and even the Holy Roman Empire of the German people waged wars.  This integration, which we are talking about, was to be based on different principles, on the basis of respect for peoples, national cultures, differences in political cultures, constitutional identities and so on. Unfortunately, you want to introduce something completely different. And that will end badly for Europe.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to express my thanks to my colleague Pascal Durand for his report. Clearly, it is an input, also a proposal, for the forthcoming conference on the future of the European Union. My delegation shares many aspects of the report, and that is why, quite clearly, we have to state that, although we had the highest turnout in 20 years in 2019, the abstention rate remains too low, at 50.6% of all citizens entitled to vote. The report shows that, therefore, a great deal has to change institutionally and structurally with regard to European electoral legislation, because it is a pillar of democratic participation in shaping the architecture of the European Union today and in the future. I therefore also strongly support the proposal for the introduction of a top-of-the-table system, so that citizens have a direct say in the election of the President of the European Commission and for the introduction of transnational lists for elections to the European Parliament. Gender-balanced electoral lists, a Europe-wide right to vote from the age of 16: these are points that are important for this debate.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Mr President, when we discuss my colleague Durand's report on the European elections, it is very important that we stick to the facts. We really need an honest debate on this election in order to draw the most important and honest conclusions from it. And that honest discussion has to start with the context. And that context of that election was the context of crises, Brexit, the migrant crisis. And in this context, I would like to underline that we have seen a historic mobilisation, a historic turnout in this election. Indeed, after 20 years, it has increased significantly throughout the European Union. In my own country, Slovakia, the turnout was 10% higher than in the past. And that turnout was the mobilisation of pro-European forces, the populists did not win, pro-European forces prevailed, hope for the future of the European project prevailed. And it's important that we keep that hope going. That is why we need to launch a Conference on the Future of Europe as soon as possible and a debate, an honest debate with our citizens and voters, in order to mobilise them further in the context of the next elections, but also in relation to why we have a European project here. The European project is there for the people. The pandemic shows us the benefits of the European project, the added value of the recovery fund, as well as the debate on the health union. All this must be the agenda of the Conference on the Future of Europe in order to further mobilise voters and citizens across the European Union in the context of the next European elections. And we need to go to that conference with an open mind and an open head, not with pre-written election rules. The Union is a union of citizens, the Union is a union of states, and we need to maintain a balance in these principles, including in future elections, we need to consider the elections of the European Parliament in order to maintain the principle of one level mep. Yes, let us strengthen access to elections across the European Union for all voters, but let us not create different classes and different categories in the next elections. This is my comment on transnational lists.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, this evaluation report for the 2019 elections is not intended to be a political assessment of the democratic choices of the people, because they all have to respect them. It is about assessing the functioning of our electoral process and the rapporteur is absolutely right about that. There are two bigger facts to be underlined. Firstly, these were the most popular elections of the last 20 years and, secondly, these elections had an extraordinary participation of young people. This is two excellent news for the European project and for European democracy.  Unfortunately, the rapporteur has not resisted anticipating any of the discussion on the reform of the political and electoral system and transnational lists, which is planned for our Conference for the Future of Europe, and at that point and only on that point, I cannot accompany the rapporteur, because we cannot and should not want to anticipate, from the outset, or condition the discussion we will have at the Conference for the Future of Europe.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the With this report, Parliament is painting the world as it pleases. Higher turnout in the 2019 EU elections is a signal for more integration, and more integration means that voters also wanted more gender balance, more minorities, more political correctness, but no national diversity. It is a pity that turnout was high in some places, and low elsewhere. That is why we need a single electoral law, transnational lists of EU-wide leading candidates, even though this Parliament guillotined its own leading candidate last year and replaced it with Ursula von der Leyen at Macron's behest. Voter turnout in 2019 compared to 2014 rose to 16 and fell in 12 member states after falling for decades – a statistical slip-up to justify the biggest social experiment since Mao. The Chinese have a word for this: Baizuo, a mockery of hypocritical Western humanitarians who are committed to immigration, LBGT, and climate rescue, without knowing real problems, just to satisfy a sense of moral superiority.

name: Daniel FREUND
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I believe that we must be honest with ourselves: what happened after the European elections was not necessarily a great step forward for European democracy. Indeed, we in Parliament have not managed to get a leading candidate through. Ironically, the CDU/CSU, the conservatives, and indeed in the last legislature, voted against transnational lists, making it particularly easy for the Heads of State or Government to ignore their leading candidate, Manfred Weber, and to propose someone who did not stand for the European elections. So if we are serious about European democracy, then in future we must ensure that the basic principle of any functioning democracy is fulfilled, that candidates and parties compete with programmes and that those who then win a majority or tinker with a coalition that represents a majority, then also fill the top posts. That is why – and I can only contradict Mr Rangel on this point – if we want to achieve this, if we want to build this European democracy in this way, then I have not seen a better idea than that all Europeans can also vote for this top post.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: Mr President, this report exudes centralism. This report is at odds with subsidiarity, at odds with the unity in diversity. Transnational lists as well. They will, moreover, damage the public's confidence: you cannot follow these list-pullers, you cannot follow them for five years, nor do you speak the language of those list-pullers. And the election of the President of the Commission on those transnational lists paves the way to a presidential regime. This is at odds with the foundations of the european Union's partnership.  "Unity in diversity" is the motto. Centralism and gigantism go against that. You do not have to be a centralist to believe in the added value of the European Union, based on the values of the Enlightenment.

name: Sven SIMON
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Now the Presidency has changed, but I still believe that we need to improve the culture of debate. We also need more than one or two minutes of speaking time, otherwise we can only take one aspect out. We need a lively debate here. I am now also picking out one aspect – but if I had more time, it would make more sense to go into a few more aspects – the story with parity. Ladies and gentlemen, in a representative democracy, we represent political convictions, constituencies, and identity groups that cannot be defined arbitrarily. Basically, this is disenfranchised the electorate.  Those who think that we need quotas for electoral lists somehow have the idea that Members can only represent interests if they belong to an identity group. That is simply not the case, and it is also somewhat illiberal. It is basically like the meetings of estates that we once had, an identitarian understanding of democracy – gender-based, one should only be allowed to be elected if one belongs to a certain gender, has a certain origin, religion or skin color. I do not believe that this is the model of democracy that we want in Europe. The question of how we organise democracy, we really need to discuss in detail at the conference on the future of Europe. Most of the time, in one or two minutes, only the catchphrase is mentioned here: transnational list. Yes, how is this supposed to work? I have nothing against it. But of course there are also great other transnational ideas: multi-person constituencies – what you can come up with. Then we, as democrats, must promise ourselves one thing: whenever we discuss this issue, it must be fair, because the rules of how we argue with each other must not be disputed in the end, once we have agreed. Then we can take a hard look at the matter. With this in mind, I am happy to cooperate in this new right to vote for Europe. And, after this debate, I have great hope today that we have enough competence and colleagues in this House who have a serious will to take a step forward now.

name: Gabriele BISCHOFF
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The 2019 European elections were a great success and, at the same time, a huge disappointment. This was a great success because more than 50% of the citizens entitled to vote took part in the European elections. This is the highest turnout in 20 years. At the same time, however, the European elections were also a huge disappointment for many of the citizens who went to the polls. They believed in the promise that with their vote they would have a say in the future person at the head of the European Commission. In hindsight, they were taught something better. It was not her voice, but backroom deals that led to this decision. It is precisely this ambivalence that the report makes clear. There is a great need for reform. We finally need a legally binding regulation of the leading candidate principle by reforming the European electoral law. More democracy is the order of the day, also with a view to the forthcoming future conference. Let's dare!

name: Peter KOFOD
text: Mr President! I am here with the report on the 2019 EU elections and I have to say that I was somewhat puzzled when I read it.  The report simply refers to the fact that the results for EU sceptics should be seen as a warning. It completely pulls the mask of this superficial and, I think, undemocratic system. Because instead of listening to those of us who are concerned about a growing federal EU system, we are isolating EU sceptics. We are excluded from the posts in the committees, and we are excluded from political influence and compromises, and, worst of all, we are splashing out on democracy while excluding millions of Eurosceptic voices from being heard and allowing it to be the basis for self-reflection here in the glass palaces in Brussels.  Instead, the only thing that the majority has the imagination to do is demand more and more europe. In everyday life, you can hardly count the number of empty phrases fired about democracy, diversity and tolerance in this house, but at the end of the day, it is not lived up to when it comes to EU sceptics. The majority in this House is behaving in double standards.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Mr President, I fear that the majority has understood nothing of Brexit and that the social democratic pride once again blinds. It is not true that Europeans applaud the European Union again, and that increase in the vote has come because the vote has gone to the parties that defend the nations. The Social Democratic majority, and there I include those who cast right-wing votes in their country to do left-wing politics here, wants a megastate that makes nations disappear and thus the only real democratic control. But nations refuse to disappear. That is why the parties that defend the nation grow non-stop and the parties that want to dissolve it are falling—the majority parties, first and foremost. Despite the colossal propaganda that continues, a third of Europeans already vote for defenders of the nation. In 2024 we will be many more.  That is why the rush to create the megastate through the back door without consultation with the people, who would say no, as they have done in the past.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: – Mr President, in this report we have a thorough analysis of the recent European Parliament elections, and congratulations to the rapporteur for that. I can only regret that in an otherwise very comprehensive text we spent so much political effort trying to revive an idea that this House voted down – and with good reason – and I am speaking about the transnational lists. Parliament is often perceived as a political entity that is distant from the everyday concerns of citizens. Every second colleague quoted already that in the last European Parliament elections turnout was the highest since 1994 and it was 8 per cent up compared to 2014, so bringing Parliament even closer to citizens works already. Making citizens vote for people they do not know, who do not know them, do not understand their culture, do not speak their language, will certainly not represent an impetus for further steps in that direction. In addition, elections without a local constituency would not ensure accountability to voters. It would weaken the link between Members and their electorate and would also favour large Member States and large parties. Elections for Parliament should be made more European, focusing not on electoral engineering and lists, but on proposing truly European answers to European questions, rather than national priorities.  On the other hand, I am very disappointed that the final report did not address vital issues such as electoral thresholds. Colleagues already mentioned the high threshold can be an effective barrier for smaller groups such as parties representing national minorities running in single national constituencies. The report would have been an excellent opportunity to point out various examples of good practices in this regard, such as those in place in Italy or Belgium, where special thresholds apply for parties or regions recognising linguistic or national minorities.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: – Mr President, there is no doubt, and it can be seen everywhere, that democracy worldwide is under heavy pressure. Let’s just look towards the US. But we can consider that European democracy is alive. It has been mentioned before: we saw the best turnout in the last elections for 25 years, with a rise of 8%, especially amongst the young people. So what made the difference? Elections are a cornerstone of the democratic system. We need transparency. We need information. We need communication. And the support of the European public sphere is a crucial aspect when it comes to promoting European elections and this is what succeeded in 2019 and this is what we need to work more upon. Parliament has taken its responsibility very seriously, as have the other institutions. We need, for the Conference on the Future of Europe, transparency and information and we need interaction. It has to be not only us talking to the public but also listening. This will be the big effort for the conference.

name: Helmut GEUKING
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the So what we all lack, and what was not really mentioned today, was that if we make a policy that has been developed on the part of the people, then the turnout will be correspondingly high. In other words, we are in debt here, and we must finally shape the policy to the people. And people do not want to have transnational electoral lists where they no longer have an overview at all. He wants his politicians from his area, who he sends to the European Parliament. And he doesn't want to have lockout clauses. I can only reject this report because Amendment No 162 was rejected in committee. There would have been no point in writing in here – or it would have been a good thing to write in here that blocking clauses are not necessary. Germany, in particular, is seriously violating the right to vote here, repeatedly trying to overturn a constitutional judgment in order to reintroduce the lock-out clause on the back door, because it wants to send nine more members from the major parties instead of nine working members from smaller parties. This is where the rule of law is called for and what we always denounce. And the rule of law is not being upheld here, and that is what this report lacks.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: – Dear Chairman, the record 200 million voters who cast ballots across Europe gave us the confidence to represent them here - in the only elected body of the European Union. That is why we have a special responsibility in addressing the challenges that must be addressed at European level. This is probably more evident in the circumstances of the global pandemic than ever before. In addition, accelerated digital, climate and demographic changes remain, seeking a common response. It is therefore encouraging that the awareness of European citizens, especially young people, of the importance of participating in Europe's democratic life is growing.  Europeans have different perspectives on key European challenges, depending on the generation they belong to, the Member State they come from, but also their personal political belief. All these perspectives must be represented in an open, free and constructive European political debate - both here in the European Parliament, and at the Conference on the Future of Europe, but also in our Member States as well as local communities.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The positive trends identified in the report, such as the highest turnout in 20 years, the high share of young people and the increase in the participation of women in the institutions and bodies of the European Union, are to be welcomed. We should be talking about European electoral law, but in due course.  I am convinced that many of the solutions used in my country, such as the 5% electoral threshold, the quota system on electoral lists and support for people with disabilities, can inspire such a debate. Both proposals are an attempt to limit the role of nation states and were not accepted during the last attempt to reform electoral law.

name: Pernille WEISS

Fortunately, many of us are against it, which is why I can promise that that is exactly the part of an otherwise excellent report, which I am voting against.

name: László TRÓCSÁNYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Self-esteem and self-reflection are important things, especially when it comes to evaluating elections. However, I would be wary of adopting a meaning with a strong ideological content under the guise of self-reflection. This report seeks to pre-eminent the preamble to a federal European Union. In fact, it wants to be embedded in the final outcome of the debate on the future of the European Union. I think there are very serious dangers to this. It is indeed important to talk about the future of the European Union, but I do not think that the emphasis should be on institutional issues. This report is a pre-picture of the debate on the future of the Union in some form. If we focus on institutional issues, we will inevitably go into ideological issues. We'll never understand. Rather, we should be pragmatic and focus on the issues that European citizens are interested in: our place in the global world order, competitiveness, demographics, jobs – these are real issues. But whether it is a transnational list, or even a top candidate system, et cetera – these are pseudo-questions, unnecessary institutional issues that will fundamentally divide us. It carries dangers. Be realistic. I believe that, at a time when our own functioning is in difficulty, when the European Parliament is struggling to make it work legally, let us not focus on issues that are completely out of the realities of the day. We must serve the interests of the citizens, and that is what we have been concerned about, and I believe that there are areas where emphasis should be placed. It is regrettable, however, that this report is not a self-reflection, but an ideological document with dreams.

name: Riho TERRAS
text: - Respectful Chair, today we debate a report that contains a wealth of views that do not make Europe stronger, but is opposed to it and dangerous to it. I am thinking of the report prepared by Mr Durand on the analysis of the European elections. As many good collegiates have already pointed out, I am very critical of the so-called Pan-European electoral lists. Such lists would obviously be too much for the smaller Member States, as candidates from these Member States would not have the opportunity to compete equally against candidates from the major Member States. In my opinion, the voting activity in the European Parliament elections is very directly linked to the possibility for voters from their home countries to choose from their own country the people who are known, known and valued to represent themselves. If you take this opportunity away from the electorate, the European Union will become even more distant and distance itself from its citizens. I am absolutely convinced that playing with an idea such as pan-European electoral lists is irresponsible and dangerous. I very much hope that, in the interests of a better future for the European Union, we will stop discussing this issue and focus on real issues. Finally, I would like to express my opposition to the idea of a single election. While I understand that this is aimed at involving young people, this initiative must come from the Member States and be in line with national electoral law. There must be one election, whether we elect a local council, a national parliament or the European Parliament. The European Union should stop putting pressure on the Member States here.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Mr President, I would like to say at the outset that I wholeheartedly share all the proposals made by Mr Durand, who, as always, has excellent reports. Of course, I share what he says about the gender balance. I also share what he says about the proper organisation of the electoral process, as well as his views on transnational lists, with a single constituency for the whole of the European Union. However, I feel a little out of place when he talks about the need to encourage more people to vote. I'll explain why. I come from a country where this incentive is done through the obligation to vote. We are obliged, in my country, as in two or three other countries of the European Union, to go and vote. I am a national of a Member State where this is not a problem. Compulsory voting is widely accepted. Compulsory voting, even if you do not want to go to the polls, gives you the opportunity to vote by mail. The highest authorities in my country accept postal voting, they do not see this way of voting as a source of electoral fraud, as is the case in some major countries in the Western sphere. I would also like to say that there are many ways to consider, see or glimpse civil rights. I will oppose civil rights, the formula of civic duty. I do not think that our citizens are being asked to go to the polls once every five years to vote for what is essential for our future.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I want to thank you again for a very important and timely report and also for a very interesting debate. Well, we are speaking here today about reflections on the 2019 elections. Let me say what I didn’t say at the beginning and maybe also the reflections from the Commission’s side – how we were preparing for the elections. After the lessons we learned from the 2016 American elections, from the Brexit campaign and from some other elections, we knew that to organise the elections, to be fair and free, and free from manipulation, and free from different new kinds of threat, it wouldn’t be business as usual. We focused in the preparation on three new emerging threats. The first was abuse of private data in political campaigns. After the Cambridge Analytica case it was clear that we had to react. So we mobilised the data protection authorities in the Member States to pay special attention to the possible cases of abuse of private data and micro-targeting in political campaigning. The second threat was disinformation. We mobilised colleagues dealing with disinformation on a national level. We created the rapid alert system to address or to stop a coordinated strong attack from outside Europe – and just to mention that we did not trigger the rapid alert system, but we were prepared for that. And the third threat was the possible endangering of the elections by cyber-attacks. So we again asked the Member States to strengthen their infrastructure to be able to protect the elections against that. To manage all these new threats and to be well prepared, we established the national elections system and network. We had all the Member States, represented by the people who organised the elections, it proved to be very useful. The network is still working and it will work further in the future, because all the measures we took for the European elections proved to be extremely useful for organising national elections. So we are working together with the Member States. Well, the reflections on the elections with regard to the results, are, as far as I see it, quite positive. We saw that especially young people showed us that they are interested in the future of Europe – that Europe matters. This is very good news. And I think that in everything we are doing we should continue to support this trend. We have to invite young people to the elections. I cannot help it, we have to do something which I sometimes call ‘to digitalise democracy’, because young people are not interested in using the old-fashioned methods. So maybe we should consider the possibility to introduce more digital innovations in the methods and in the way we elect in Europe. And we have to start discussions as soon as possible under the Conference on the Future of Europe, which was mentioned here many times – Katarina Barley said that it should be mainly an exercise that involves listening. We should listen to what people see as good solutions for the future of Europe. Now we know that the people care and that we have to open a very wide discussion with the citizens, not only remain in the bubble where we are normally used to discussing these things. So, the conference should start as soon as possible when COVID enables us to move. We can do a lot of things through digital instruments but not everything is possible. Last comment: if we want to change something in the electoral system for 2024, needless to say here that the initiative is on the European Parliament, not the Commission. I have counted the days and months before the elections and well, if we want to introduce changes, we will have to see the initiatives on the table next year.
