So I can only repeat from this place that I am ready to cooperate, the Commission is going to play the role of the honest broker in this process, and I’m very much looking forward to the next debates on this and also the real steps we are going to take.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place today, Tuesday 24 November 2020. The final vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 25 November 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: in writing. – The instruments used by the European Union to deepen federalism have no limits. An example of this is this debate: under the mantle of greater democratization, greater transparency, greater connection between elected officials and voters, the result is more an exercise in attacking democracy than defending it. By advocating the establishment of common lists at European level, with common heads of list, facilitating the participation of European political parties in election campaigns, or requiring the logos of these parties to appear on ballot papers together with those of the national parties, calling into question their independence and trying to impose forms of operation on them, what is being done is to try to transfer competences and sovereignty of the Member States to the supranational level. It should be so clear that what they want is to deepen the federalist nature of the EU but that it has nothing to do with the reality of the Member States and that it is contrary to the need for a Europe of cooperation between sovereign and equal states on rights. It should be seen that, by standardising political representation at the service of the EU and the economic powers that underpin it, rather than bringing it closer, it is further distancing itself from voters and elected representatives, disregarding the sovereignty and specificities of each Member State.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: Writing. – Dear President, we have experienced many unexpected and unprecedented situations this year, in which our ability to react quickly and effectively has been tested. We must ensure that our values are strengthened, not destroyed. This means that, as representatives of the Member States, we must maintain the interests of each Member State and its citizens. The report, which examined the mechanism for future Elections to the European Parliament, proposes the introduction of international voting lists. This report mistakenly sees the term 'harmonisation' as a reduction in the diversity of Member States. Honourable colleagues, this report runs counter to the objective of our work. Our main task here is to represent our Member States and their citizens. We are here to find the best solutions and to ensure that the principle of representation exists in the European Parliament. I strongly oppose the report because it proposes a system in which the citizens of the European Union will not be able to trust the leaders or members of parliament's parties. This poses a threat to the creation of a system that no longer works in the interests of the Member States or of their citizens. In particular, in the interests of the smaller Member States. I call on my colleagues in This House to be aware of this danger: if we follow this report, the fundamental principle of our unity will be lost.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the review of EU trade policy by Bernd Lange on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (O-000070/2020 – B9-0024/2020) (2020/2761(RSP)).

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has It is, of course, now clear that trade policy is shaping the future. Among many other policy areas, trade policy is a material opportunity to shape the future. I believe that we have recently seen very clearly how much these possibilities for action in trade policy have been called into question. We have seen many national singular measures taken, which have acted completely contrary to international rules, national reflexes, unilateral measures. We have seen that in the Corona pandemic supply chains have been in shock, broken off and have caused economic and political consequences. We have seen more and more people asking: who benefits from this trade policy? Is this really in our interest with globalisation or only in the interests of a few? So the values of the European Union are also being asked in trade policy. That is why our question is yes: how can we shape trade policy in the future so that we can get answers to these challenges? We discussed this very intensively in the Committee on Trade and also presented a number of points which should be a step forward for the Commission to review the trade policy strategy. I would also say that this is not a wish list for Santa Claus, even though we are now just before Christmas, but that is already a strategic option with two lines. One line is more the proactive line, and the other line is more the defensive line, the defense line. These two lines are reflected in many points.  Let me just mention four points briefly. I believe that we must be proactive in the WTO in order to supplement the WTO's regulatory framework, supplementing it with the question of state-owned enterprises, with the issue of the protection of intellectual property. Above all, however, we must approach and get the SDGs, the United Nations SDGs, into the WTO, so that trade policy on a global scale also serves the implementation of sustainability strategies. I hope that we can work hard with the United States, with Mr Biden's administration and with Mr Kerry as climate envoy. Perhaps this too may be a starting point for enhanced cooperation in the multilateral system, in order to set more rules here in order to move forward. Secondly, I believe that we also need a clear focus on the issue of supply chains. We see that supply chains are very sensitive, that they are sometimes not robust enough to absorb shocks. However, we also see that supply chains are unfair, that the risk is passed on to the last of the chain. That is why I believe that it is right – and this is also reflected in the proposal – to introduce a binding European supply chain law, which provides for due diligence for companies operating in the European internal market, so that we do not see this cut and go, but a clear strategy to improve situations in the supply chain, the situation of workers' rights, environmental standards. And that is what we are arguing about.  We also need a stronger implementation of the Green Deal in trade policy. In other words, the question of green goods initiatives within the framework of the WTO, but also bilaterally. We need a sensible border-balancing system.  Fourthly, we also need a focus on improving the implementation and implementation of trade agreements. I think we have to defend ourselves here when there are elements that attack us, when there are coercive measures by third countries. That is why we hope that next year we will also have a sensible instrument. However, we must also establish clear enforcement of the agreements.  Since 2013 we have an agreement with Central America. In Guatemala, workers' rights are still not being implemented and human rights violations continue. We have had an agreement with Korea for five years in the negotiation of the enforcement of workers' rights. Something needs to be done here, so it is right and proper to put implementation and enforcement forward. Finally, Commissioner, we are always looking for a motto for a trade strategy. Last time it was called "Trade for all". Maybe this time we can say "People first", people first.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would first like to thank Parliament for this resolution. We will consider it very carefully in our reflections on a new strategic direction for trade policy.  Let me start with recalling the objectives of the trade policy review.  European trade policy is operating in an increasingly difficult environment, marked by growing tensions among major global economies, the rise of unilateralism and economic nationalism, the weaponisation of trade policy for other objectives and a weakening of the rules-based multilateral order. In addition, there are growing and legitimate expectations that trade policy must contribute to the political goals of this Commission, in particular the green and digital transitions. Finally, the COVID-19 crisis is having a devastating impact on our economies and societies, and all EU policies must contribute to sustainable recovery, including trade. The trade policy review will build a new consensus around a fresh medium-term direction for EU trade policy, responding to these global challenges and taking into account the lessons learned from COVID-19. As part of this exercise we launched a broad public consultation which ended earlier this month. We received more than 400 strong contributions from our key stakeholders, addressing all the themes included in Parliament’s resolution.  These included: the need to create more sustainable and resilient value chains; the need to sustain rules-based trade and reform of the rules-based multilateral order; the need for trade policy to contribute to the digital and green transitions, through better integration of our internal and external policies; the need to strengthen the EU’s regulatory impact and to maximise the contribution to the economic recovery, especially for SMEs; and also, the need to manage and develop our key global trade relationships; and the need to further strengthen the implementation and enforcement aspect of our trade agreements, including on sustainable development commitments. All these themes, and many others, will be developed in the communication we plan to adopt in the first quarter of 2021. This communication will outline the direction of EU trade policy for the coming years. The guiding concept is open strategic autonomy: a unique European approach to ensure that we remain open for business and trade, while at the same time becoming more assertive in defending and enforcing our interests, rights and values. This will include a limited number of concrete policy initiatives to translate the direction of trade policy into practice. Of course, this Parliament will be closely involved at all stages of this process. We will work together to ensure the highest levels of transparency and communication with stakeholders and the public. We will publish up-to-date information in easy-to-understand language and engage actively with civil society organisations, business and labour associations and citizens both directly and via social media tools. Trade policy impacts the lives of all Europeans and our transparency and communication efforts must reflect this fact.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it is no secret that international trade has taken a battering during this pandemic. The latest forecast from the WTO now speaks of 9.2% drop in volume of world merchandise trade for this year. But at the same time, the extreme resilience of trade links has surprised everyone, with a forecasted rebound of 7.2% in 2021. Surely now is not the time for business as usual, and my Group welcomes the Commission’s frontloading of the trade policy review in the wake of the pandemic. For us open strategic autonomy must mean a trade policy, firstly, that doesn’t try to repair what isn’t broken. Our new strategy should not make us retreat behind walls of protectionism or paint pictures of glorious self-sufficiency. Decisions on supply chains must always remain in the hands of economic operators. Secondly, it should address the structural weaknesses that were laid bare by the pandemic, such as the lack of diversification in the supply chains, for example when it comes to personal protective equipment during the first wave of the health crisis, and this has as well being highlighted by our chairman, Bernd Lange. Therefore, I call for a strategic diversification fund to be set up to help our companies to be less dependent on one single supplier. Furthermore, the conditions for trade to serve as catalyst for the recovery, must be created, for example by continuing to expand our network of FTAs to help to diversify supply chains but as well export destinations. We also need a strong focus on SMEs. They were the first hit by liquidity crunch under pandemic and they will be key to recovery and jobs, for example by initiatives such as the Access2Markets tool that has as well being asked by the Parliament. Finally, consistency and coherence in all policies and on all levels, hence the new proposals such as the China Task Force, that will help us sing from the same hymn sheet in our relations with China at all levels. This is of utmost importance. (Applause)

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this Trade Policy Review comes in challenging times. The COVID pandemic most probably shall focus on a serious economic and social crisis, maybe the most severe one of this generation. Trade can, and should, play a vital role in the recovery but, at the same time, it needs to be reshaped fundamentally to address the challenges of today and those of the future. A deep and forward-looking reform is necessary. Let me set out the priorities of my political group. Let me start first with the connection between domestic policy and trade policy, which has been referred to by you, Commissioner, and by our Chair. We need it to be both consistent and ambitious. The Green Deal needs to be integral, integrated in trade policy, but also in trade deals. We cannot set high standards for our own production and, at the same time, import products that are produced in an unsustainable manner, ignoring the Paris Agreement, or that contribute to deforestation.  Second, very important for our political group and something that we’ve urged for over many years, the enforceability of the TSD chapter. It needs to be strengthened. We need to move forward on the enforceability of labour rights and environmental standards, and that includes sanctions: no enforceability without clear sanctions.  On the US, let’s start to work with the new Biden administration to tackle the strategic challenges and build a positive agenda on trade. Rejoining the Paris Agreement is absolutely the first step in strengthening multilateralism.  When it comes to China, we do support the negotiations on the Comprehensive Agreement on Investment but, at the same time, let us be extremely clear. Full respect for human rights is needed and products produced in forced labour camps should be banned from EU markets. We call on the Commission to start preparing the negotiations with Taiwan.  The last, but not the least, point is that we urge the Commission to include a chapter dedicated to gender in all free trade agreements. Let me conclude. Commissioner, we count on you to take this Trade Policy Review seriously and to reform EU trade policy so thoroughly that we can see that the Green Deal is an integral part of it.

name: Barry ANDREWS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, the trade policy review provides us with a rare opportunity to build back a better trade policy that endeavours to ensure that the benefits of trade are evenly distributed and distributed sustainably. Over the last five years we have seen the stable and predictable environment necessary for international trade to flourish continuously undermined. The pandemic has highlighted our vulnerabilities and as we search for ways to recover from the economic shock, resilience should be at the core of the next stage of development of EU trade policy. In the current political context it would be easy to lean towards protectionism and indeed we have seen this deeply concerning trend reflected in the debate around trade lately. The phrase open strategic autonomy allows us to balance on the one hand our support for an open global trading economy, while on the other hand charting our own European strategic path. I would like to underline that my political group remains firmly committed to open and rules-based trade. We cannot and should not separate open from strategic autonomy.  My second point is about SMEs. Global markets are a crucial source of growth for SMEs. However, they often struggle to access the benefits of preferential trade agreements. There is huge untapped potential there, and one of the priorities of our new trade policy should be to address this. In particular we should focus on specific digital trade provisions in future trade agreements to benefit SMEs and services trade generally. Finally, Mr President, our trade policy has the potential to contribute significantly to the advancement of our strategic objectives around the green transition and indeed the digital transition. However, is not enough for us to quietly mainstream these objectives, our trade policy should not just contribute to their advancement, but also be seen to contribute to their advancement. I would like to acknowledge the hard work of colleagues on the Trade Committee and their staff and my own staff in preparing this resolution and I recommend it to the Parliament.

name: Saskia BRICMONT
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, you know that we Greens are uncompromising when it comes to defining the issues of European trade policy and for good reason, with agricultural policy, trade policy is probably the area where frictions with the European Green Pact are most important and where the prevailing mindset remains that of the 20th century, when the sustainable development objectives, but also the Paris climate agreement did not exist. In recent years, the leitmotif seems to have been more "everything but China" and this has made us lose sight of the major societal issues. It is therefore time for European trade policy to take a decisive turn. This is what the European Parliament is asking for: that trade policy contribute to the ecological and just transition. We therefore support this text, which is certainly perfectable, but the result of a compromise, and I thank my colleagues for their openness in putting the European Parliament on the path of ambition and feeding the European Commission in defining its Union trade strategy for the next five years. What are we asking for? First, to ensure that all free trade agreements are compatible with the Green Pact, including reviewing existing agreements that are currently under way and already negotiated. Second, to ensure that sustainable development provisions are binding and that their non-compliance by a partner is subject to sanctions. Then, to adopt a binding legislative framework on corporate due diligence throughout the supply chain for EU and foreign companies that are active in the single market. Also, to prohibit market access to products from forced labour and child labour. This would be a strong signal sent by the European Union as part of the International Year on the Eradication of Child Labour in 2021. It is also a recommendation that is echoed in the news revealed by the Guardian, which shows that China, in addition to the Uighurs, uses North Korean forced labourers to produce personal protective equipment for European countries in particular. Finally, Commissioner, involving civil society in the implementation of free trade agreements is essential to ensure compliance with these provisions. This is the role of the Domestic Advisery Groups, whose recommendations seem to be often ignored by the European Commission. It would therefore be an honour for the European Parliament to hear at least annually the members of these groups whose report would undoubtedly contribute to ensuring that our free trade agreements are in line with the Green Pact and contribute to a fairer, fairer and more globalised globalisation.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Mr Vice-President, colleagues, the pandemic has taught us that we must better protect our citizens with sufficient stocks of life-saving resources, by diversifying supply lines where necessary. We also need to think about bringing certain production back to the European Union. But we must not give in to the siren song of protectionism. Protect, yes, but no protectionism. To protect without protectionism. More than ever, the European Union must be at the forefront of open, fair, free trade. I am in favour of strategic autonomy, but it must be an open strategic autonomy, with more free trade agreements, with the Union as an actor in the world – a global actor – with investment agreements, of course with enforcing a level playing field and setting conditions. Finally, Mr Vice-President, I would like to draw your attention to a creeping protectionism within the internal market. You don't have to close your borders to stop goods. More and more companies from small Member States are being forced to move their production unit to large Member States in order to lose them in retail. I've already drawn attention to that. I ask that the Commission act. This undermines confidence in the European Union and undermines the single market.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner Dombrovskis, you have the opportunity today to assure us that you have recognised the signs of the times to reorient the European Union's external trade strategy, fundamentally. What is most important is what the pandemic reminds us of: life. Our trade policy must be geared towards preserving, enabling and improving lives, but not just European lives at the expense of others. A third of the world's population still lives in great poverty and daily hunger, while a small part of humanity is better off, and better and better. Trade policy, I would like to emphasise, has a great deal to do with our production and our consumption. And that is why the Green Deal must not be a green coat of old logic and economic dogma. We must now initiate ecological and social transformation. This requires a paradigm shift, especially in the trading strategy. The success of this Commission will no longer be measured by growth in the EU. All UN countries committed to achieving the 17 SDGs by 2030. This includes overcoming hunger and poverty and climate protection. We will be judged by how far we have come by 2024. Success can only be achieved through international, multilateral and co-operating cooperation with China, with the USA, with Russia, with India, with the African Union, ASEAN and Latin America. Together, place the WTO in this new objective!

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We all know that several million jobs in the European Union depend on our being able to produce, make available, and sell our goods and services in Europe, but sell anywhere else in the world – cars, machinery and much more. In order for our companies to be competitive in global markets, they also need cheap supplier products. So here too we need market access, not only in order to sell our things, but we must also be able to buy the subcontractors freely if possible. Thirdly, in recent years, the world's open markets have created a huge range of products, with a huge choice, also for our consumers, and I think that very few of us today are aware of the lack of supply in our stores if global trade did not exist. However, as many previous speakers have already mentioned, global trade also needs a clear framework. To this end, we need political, legally binding rules on the rules under which trade takes place. But it is very important to me that we still rely on openness. For example, when we talk about strategic autonomy, or when we talk about new rules, such as border adjustment and other rules, we must always be clear: we do this to set rules, but we do not do this in order to close our markets off, to make life difficult for businesses, for consumers, but because we are convinced that open markets need rules. , we as a policy also want to shape the market. And it is very, very important to me that when we talk about strategic autonomy, we are talking about open strategic autonomy. We should always be aware that strategic autonomy has limits. When I read that the world's largest manufacturer of surgical gloves now has to close many of its factories, we can say again: let us produce these things in Europe! But then we come back to raw materials, which cannot then be produced in Europe, and that is why this also requires a little more intelligence than simply retaking production. We must, please, give a comprehensive and comprehensive look at the issue in the coming weeks.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Mr President, trade policy has set out its limitations in this crisis. It must be progressive and have a foresighted capacity to respond to uncertainty and the future. It should empower the European Union to act in a sustainable and resilient manner. The Union's political priorities, such as the Green Deal or trade and sustainable development positions, the protection of social rights or the promotion of gender equality must be reflected in trade policy and, consequently, in trade agreements.  SMEs are structuring european economies and trade agreements must take this into account, but we cannot be out of intention. We must provide for mechanisms that facilitate and ensure their implementation.  Finally, we hope that the opportunity has come to resume transatlantic dialogue and deepen trade relations with the United States.  Finally, I would like to congratulate Bernd Lange on this initiative. This is the right time to influence the ambition of the European Union.

name: Marie-Pierre VEDRENNE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, thank you to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their work. In a world of trade tensions, the European Union must more than ever defend its values and interests, and this requires the construction of our strategic autonomy in order for the Union to take its destiny into its own hands. Three key words for our trade policy. The first is efficiency. To defend our interests, Europe must make reciprocity our compass, use its defence instruments and be a leader in multilateral negotiations. The second is credibility. Europe needs to strengthen its legal arsenal in order to play on equal terms with states that care little about the rules. The regulation for the application and compliance of the rules of international trade is a first step. The new instrument to counter coercive measures is needed more than ever. Finally, the third is ambition. The fight against unfair, social, fiscal or environmental competition must be our priority. Those who want access to our market must respect our rules and standards, it is a matter of fairness and consumer protection. We know the criticisms about the binding nature of the chapter on sustainable development, our agreements certainly concern a reference to the Paris Agreements, but we must rethink in line with the Franco-Dutch initiative, the respect by our partners of our commitments. Commissioner, it is time to consider a gradation in the event of non-compliance with these provisions, which goes as far as sanctions as a last resort. This is how we will help restore our citizens' confidence in our trade policy.

name: Anna CAVAZZINI
text: – Mr President, I said it several times in this Chamber: the EU Green Deal requires a drastic change of direction in EU trade policy. The WTO and the rules in our bilateral agreements set in stone how the international economy works. They are hard to change and that is why it’s so important that the rules of the game are well designed. But so far they are blind on the environment and the climate, they are quite weak on human rights, this is what we need to change and this is why the trade policy review is so timely. 10% of worldwide deforestation is linked to EU imports. A quarter of worldwide CO2 emissions are linked to trade. We need to make urgently all trade, whether multilateral or bilateral, climate proof. We need a climate supremacy clause, rules to phase out fossil fuels subsidies and clear CO2 reduction commitments.  The EU is proud of its sustainability chapters. Yes, I admit they look nice, but looking nice is not their purpose. They need to be effective – and how effective is a TSD chapter if there are no consequences after trade unionist murders in Colombia or when, after nine years, South Korea still hasn’t ratified the ILO Convention on freedom of association for workers? The clear rule needs to be: if there is a breach of a commitment, some of the preferences granted in the agreement need to be withdrawn.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, in trade matters, there is obviously an urgent need to change policy and change the instruments of this policy. I think we need to protect our businesses more, our know-how, our territories, demand more reciprocity in agreements, but also be more responsive. I'll give you an example. Last week a mega-trade agreement was signed between the ASEAN countries, China, but also Australia and New Zealand. So many countries with which we already have agreements, or with which we are negotiating. The logic would be to interrupt the negotiations and look at the consequences for us in practice. I am thinking in particular of the question of rules of origin, which have been very simplified within the framework of the comprehensive regional economic partnership. They are simplified here and there is a risk that products "made in Singapore" or "made in Vietnam" will actually be "made in China" products exported to us without tariffs. So you really have to stop being naïve. President Lange used to say "people first," and we're still a long way from that. There is a need for a radical change in trade policy.

name: Jörgen WARBORN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Now we decide what trade policy we should have in the future. Developments in the world give every reason to be concerned both for our health and for the economy. We must therefore set out a trade policy that can help us deal with the covid crisis that we have in the short term, but also competitiveness in the long term. We must certainly not stop trading with each other or close ourselves to the outside world. On the contrary , we must – and this is perhaps my main message – we must, on the contrary, stand up for free trade, because it creates prosperity, it takes people out of poverty, it enables businesses to grow and it creates jobs. It is also one of the solutions to the climate challenge and can make it easier to get vaccines and medicines to people. There are four areas that I want to highlight specifically, which give us an opportunity right now, a time window. The first is to improve relations with the Us, the new US, administration. The mini-agreement, which I hope we approve later this week, is an opportunity to de-escalate the conflict with the United States. We should hook up with the Americans and take on China with them, because they are playing dirty games on the international market. Secondly, we need to reach an agreement with the UK very soon so that we mitigate the situation and the blow to businesses after Brexit. The third is that it is gratifying that there is now an appetite for large free trade agreements. We see this as the countries of Asia and Oceania have now concluded a major free trade agreement. The EU should go further here and continue to negotiate with several countries and, of course, ratify the Mercosur Agreement. Finally, we see new leadership in the World Trade Organisation. It is also an opportunity. Now we Europeans have an opportunity, a window of time, to stand up with renewed vigour for open, free and rules-based trade.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for his excellent work. If we want a world that is more peaceful, a world that is more social, a world that is more sustainable, better for people and better for this planet, Mr Vice-President, then the reform of the trade policy that you have set out to do is central. But the central point is that we have to define where we stand. We are no longer at the level of declarations of intent, but we are at the level of binding renewals. Yes, we need the sustainability chapter, and we are complaining about sanctions. Yes, we need due diligence as a horizontal obligation so that human rights can be enforced. Yes, we need gender equality, the promotion of women in international trade relations, because only then can we achieve justice on this globe. We want to work with you, Mr Vice-President. But this also means that the European Parliament will have a new role in the debate and in the adoption of the mandate. We look forward to a good cooperation – good luck!

name: Jordi CAÑAS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, in this Parliament we are debating, in this House, a resolution which seeks to define what the main lines are for this House in the future revision of the European Union's trade policy announced by the Commission. You yourselves announced that one of the objectives of this review was to strengthen trade and investment relations with strategic partners on the basis of free and fair multilateral trade, based on reciprocal rules. It sounds great, but the truth is that so far the signals transmitted by this Commission are on the opposite line. I'll explain. This was the Geopolitical Commission, as President Von der Leyen said, but so far the only initiative she has put forward has been to hath paralyzed the largest trade and political partnership agreement signed by the European Union, which is the European Union-Mercosur agreement. This is based on previous doubts about the implementation of some of the agreements agreed. Not bad. But, in parallel, you have negotiated agreements with China on geographical indications, a country that systematically violates human rights. And in this situation the question is: What are the specific demands that the European Union, the Commission, will set for its trading partners? Or will he be weak with the strong and strong with the weak? I believe that we all want to move forward with a trade policy based on reciprocal but equal rules for all, because other words this Commission will give a very negative message, that it is not a reliable partner, that it is not a partner that lives up to its commitments. And this Commission must live up to the commitments and be able to fulfil its objectives, its commitments, for the benefit of all the citizens of the European Union.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Mr President, the concept of open strategic autonomy on which the revision of trade policy is based is one of those concepts which is already beginning to be normalized. The chaos of the desupply of sanitary material during the harshest part of the pandemic knocked us out and offside. Its global impact now leads us to redefine and rethink various issues, such as the concept of strategic sectors and reserves or the European Union's dependence on global value chains.  The European Union needs a change of mindset to act as a geopolitical power. It needs to define its objectives and act strategically and outside of these trade and technological disputes between the United States and China. All sides of open strategic autonomy must lead to reducing the vulnerability and dependence of the European Union and, ultimately, to improving the competitive position of its industry, including the agricultural and fisheries sector, and, of its way, to address digital sovereignty decisively.  The question is whether we have the necessary capabilities and instruments to do so, because trade policy can no longer be thought of in isolation. But let's not forget something: the line between protectionism and achieving strategic autonomy is very thin. We have to be very careful not to pass it on. Fortunately, on international trade, the European Union speaks with one voice and has enormous power of influence. Let's take advantage of it.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, Europe can use its influence on the world market positively, but we have to choose to do so. That has to happen today and not until tomorrow or later. Mercosur's negotiating mandate, for example, has been ignoring new insights for two decades, such as the Paris Climate Agreement, the UN Sustainable Development Goals and the ILO standards that entrench workers' rights. These should be binding in all trade treaties in the chapters on trade and sustainable development. And they have to be enforceable, with sanctions if countries don't comply.  We have heard sufficiently vague promises of improvement from the Commission, including, for example, on the progress of the multilateral investment court. But at the end of the day, it's all about what's in black and white. We must therefore choose climate, sustainability and workers in trade treaties.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, trade is not the same as it was 20 years ago. The world has changed and we have new issues on our plate, but not every problem can be solved by trade. We see a growing appetite in Europe to address every problem through trade agreements. We cannot, however, overload the boat or it will sink. One area that needs attention though is digitalisation. We need to ingrain digital into the DNA of our trade policy. We must have digital chapters in all our new trade agreements. Another priority must be renewing the transatlantic partnership to tackle global trade challenges. Our partner is finally back in the game so we should work on improving the WTO and on countering the growing power of our foreign competitors. The new Asia-Pacific agreement is a stark reminder that it’s already happening: that influence is moving eastward.  We need to act now if we want to continue to lead and set standards globally. To achieve this, let’s re-engage with the USA as a bilateral partner and pick up more ambitious trade negotiations beyond Trump-era mini-deals. It’s time for a real trade agreement with our number one partner.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. As an export-oriented region, it is of the utmost importance for us to be as free and rules-based as possible to trade with our partners. If we impose excessive expectations on them and are not directly related to trading, we will severely reduce the number of people who will be willing to come to the negotiating table with us. And if we continue to abandon our religious ambitions, the world will walk away from us. At the same time, we rightly expect our partners to have a level playing field for our companies, for example in the area of State aid. Let us note that over the next 10 years, 85% of the world's GDP growth will take place outside the EU. Last week, 15 Asia-Pacific countries, including China, signed the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement. The world's largest free trade region is born with 2.2 billion consumers and $26 trillion in markets. There are two things the Union can already do. On the one hand, it makes full use of its existing free trade agreements and, on the other hand, accelerates the negotiation of new ones, helping our companies to enter the market without ideology. The crisis following the Covid epidemic has shaken many European companies, especially SMEs. Our task now is to reduce their burdens, not to sew new ones around their necks, such as the binding code of conduct, 'due diligence'. We need a growth-friendly business environment where it pays for companies to create new jobs. It's the only way we're going to come out of this crisis as a winner. I very much ask the left-wing liberal members of this House, always speaking of moral high ground, not to be the wheels of European competitiveness.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, the trade policy review needs to promote green and digital transformations, social aspects and human rights. For the green transition we need to promote innovations in green technologies by making it a priority to reduce tariff and non-tariff barriers in the WTO by pushing for the resumption of the negotiation on the Environmental Good Agreement and we need to do the same in the bilateral agreements.  To support the digital transformation we need to open and we need to regulate international digital markets. I do prefer good rules over protectionism. We need new trade agreements covering digital rules and market access, including the new WTO e-commerce agreement. We need close cooperation with our like-minded trading partners on standards like future technologies such as AI.  Europe’s digital economy needs digital exchange of ideas with the rest of the world. Unjustified data localisation practices and other forms of technical protectionism are increasing and risk overly fragmenting the world economy. It seems to fit well for the EU to take an active role in developing together rules and standards to reflect important values.

name: Svenja HAHN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the TTIP is prevented, CETA is not ratified, Mercosur is being fought. Free trade opponents like to hide their protectionism behind strategic independence. Meanwhile, under China's leadership, the world's largest free trade pact is being created, with no provisions on climate, the environment, and labor rights. If the EU is serious about multilateralism, it must act, otherwise others will set the tone.  We need to push forward with our partners and show a clear edge against our rivals. We need to reform the WTO as the heart of multilateralism, work with a President Biden to renew transatlantic friendship, ratify CETA, discuss climate change ambitions with Mercosur, advance negotiations with Australia and New Zealand, and strengthen partnership with African countries. Above all, we need to be more resolute in our opposition to countries like China that rely on unfair competition, systematic violations of human rights, and attacks on democracy – with trade defense instruments against unfair dumping and subsidies, and the Magnitsky Act to be created against human rights violators. We want to shape the path to an ecologically and economically responsible future. To achieve this, free trade agreements must include clear provisions of the Paris climate agreement and strengthen human rights. EU trade policy must be a commitment to free trade, multilateralism and our values. If we want to shape the future, we must act in the truest sense of the word.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Mr President, this revision is to strike a balance or it must achieve a balance between a Union open to trade and investment and a Union that safeguards people, businesses and consumers, based on fair rules for all.  As in other European policies, it is time to draw lessons from this phemic crisis and to effectively give answers to why citizens obviously yearn for the high priorities we have set in the Union in the areas of sustainability, climate change, the digital economy and security.  We remain very dependent on third countries, particularly with regard to health, energy, technological matters. This is, therefore, the time to work and mitigate the risks of future crises, particularly in health. Portugal and the outermost regions can benefit from fairer competition from their companies, with more competitive products of added value. This is the time for the Union to safeguard the outermost regions in free trade agreements. We will therefore work to establish, in this review, the improvement of safeguard clauses, stabilisation mechanisms and also financial compensation mechanisms.  This is our duty and that is what we will be working on for Portugal and its outermost regions.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Soon, one of the most important tools of the Union's trade policy will be the border carbon tax, i.e. the customs duty on carbon-intensive products imported into the Union from third countries. The idea of a border carbon tax is very right. If we put ambitious emission reduction targets before the EU extractive industry and heavy ones, we must not allow it to have unfair competition from those third countries that are not particularly accepting of climate issues. This is a very important element of a just energy transition. The carbon tax is to become an additional source of own revenue for the European Union, from which we will finance multiannual budgets and a European reconstruction fund. And it's a significant source. It is estimated that it will bring IN EUR 14 billion per year. We are therefore waiting for the Commission's swift legislative proposal on this tax, while hoping that the countries threatening to veto the EU budget will remember, because without a decision on own resources there will also be no border carbon tax.

name: Jérémy DECERLE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, finally, europe is questioning how it trades with the rest of the world. It was time to start this height-taking exercise to try to cure the source of a well-entrenched evil, which feeds a Euroscepticism unfortunately creeping. Today, the agricultural world to which I belong does not understand that we can ask for all these additional efforts and, at the same time, that we intend to continue to open the floodgates to products that do not respect our production standards, let alone the ambitions we set ourselves, with the Green Pact in response to the expectations of our citizens. I ask you today with some firmness, because farmers and citizens no longer understand. Through this ongoing review, will Europe finally commit itself to offering a little more equity and consideration to the women and men who feed us? It is as if the mandates for trade negotiations and those of our domestic policies were written by people who never talk to each other. Will Europe finally be able to show consistency between its agricultural and environmental agenda and the demands it sets for its partners in the rest of the world? Will Europe finally have the courage to safeguard its agricultural and food heritage by refusing to use it as a bargaining chip? I believe that I am confident in our ability to reinvent ourselves.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, first of all I appreciate your valuable comments and questions raised during the debate. It is clear that we share the same objectives. We want EU trade policy and investment policy to effectively support a quick and sustainable economic recovery to create opportunities for European businesses and maintain the stability and predictability they need to facilitate green and digital transitions, and to ensure that trade is responsible, fair and sustainable in line with our EU values.  I look forward to further exchanges on these issues with the European Parliament. I will come back to the Committee on International Trade to present the new communication on trade and investment policy in early 2021, and I very much look forward to hearing your views.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: In accordance with Rule 136(5) of the Rules of Procedure, a motion for a resolution has been tabled*. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 26 November 2020. ___________ * See Log.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. – The common trade policy is one of the main pillars of the European Union. The conclusion of trade agreements with third countries is extremely important for economic growth and the creation of new jobs. However, citizens of the European Union are offered products imported from outside the Community bloc which do not meet the safety requirements laid down in the European Regulations. If we remain only in the area of the Common Agricultural Policy, we can obsess that farmers in the European Union will have to face new ecological requirements, while imports from non-Community countries will continue under the old trade agreements, where quality standards are not always guaranteed and respected. The crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic demonstrated that some medical and protective equipment from outside the EU did not meet quality standards. The European Union must remedy the situation in order to help combat current and future crises. In an increasingly globalised world, the European Union must have adequate tools in place to manage trade relations on product quality with non-member states. The interest of the European citizen must be paramount. That is why a more rigorous legislative framework and controls are needed at the EU's external borders.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The next item is the debate on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the escalation of tension in Vanosha following Turkey's illegal action and the urgent need to resume negotiations (2020/2844(RSP)).  I would like to inform you that, in all the debates of this part-session, there will be no catch-the-eye procedures or blue card questions.  Distance interventions are being made from our Liaison Offices in the Member States. Let us then begin our debate with the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Josep Borrell, whom I would like to greet and thank for his presence.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let there be no doubt: respecting the status of Varosha, as set out in the relevant United Nations Security Council resolutions, is of paramount importance. Our Heads of State and Government have made this point. The European Union Foreign Ministers are following the situation closely, and the United Nations Security Council has held a closed hearing to the same effect last month. We are all deeply concerned about developments on the ground.  On 13 October, I issued a declaration on behalf of the European Union on a call for the immediate reversal of recent actions and respect for the relevant United Nations Security Council resolutions. Like the United Nations, the European Union holds Turkey responsible for the situation on the ground. These recent events around Varosha - when I was young it was called Famagusta - including President Erdogan’s visit and his statements, come at a time when attempts are underway to create a space for dialogue on Cyprus settlement issues and on the wider Eastern Mediterranean. We are passing this message clearly to our Turkish interlocutors. I have also passed it personally to the new Turkish-Cypriot leader in a telephone call I had with him immediately after his election.  This is the time to support United Nations Secretary-General Guterres in his efforts to resume the Cyprus settlement talks. Spreading distrust and more contentions will help no one. On the other hand, the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Cyprus must be given full freedom of movement in Varosha to monitor the situation in accordance with its mandate.  Mr President, honourable Members, you can be sure that European Union institutions are fully committed to a comprehensive settlement of the Cyprus problem and to the reunification based on a bi-zonal, bi-communal federation with political equality, within the United Nations framework and in line with the principles on which the European Union is founded. We stand ready to play an active role in supporting these negotiations and finding lasting solutions. For us, a stable and secure environment in the Eastern Mediterranean and the development of a cooperative and mutually beneficial relationship among all partners in the region, bilaterally and multilaterally, are in our strategic interests.  As you know, the European Council will assess the situation in the Eastern Mediterranean and our relations with Turkey in December in light of the mandate to pursue preparatory work on the text set out in the European Council conclusion on 1 October.  To finish with this short intervention, Mr President, honourable Members, you may therefore rest assured that Varosha / Famagusta is and will remain high in our collective agenda, in order to help ensure that the United Nations Security Council resolutions are respected in full by all actors.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I’m speaking on behalf of my colleague, Kris Peeters, who could not make it.  With the opening of Varosha, relations between Turkey and the EU are reaching a watershed moment. Incident after incident, step by step, the Turkish President continuously moves away from European values and standards. EU—Turkey relations are at a historic low point.  This unilateral and illegal move not only inflames EU—Turkey relations, but it also negatively affects the lives of the Cypriot population. It fuels the tensions and division embedded in the society of the Cypriot island. This violation of the UN Security Council resolutions will never contribute to a comprehensive solution. It only serves the internal politics of the Turkish President at the cost of the Cypriot people. A two—state solution will never solve the conflict.  The opening of Varosha is not just a standalone incident. Two months ago, this European Parliament condemned Turkey’s illegal activities in the continental shelf of Greece and Cyprus. Earlier, we condemned the Turkish military operation in North—East Syria. Recently, we witnessed how the Turkish President used the murder of Samuel Paty in France for his own political goals. The list of incidents is long, and it seems that it has not yet come to an end. Two days ago, there was the Irini mission and a German ship that was prevented from searching the ship. I think we need a stronger mandate for Irini. Perhaps you could work on that. A clear signal from the EU is needed. Therefore, I urge the European Council to consider well—targeted measures while continuing the dialogue.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, well, Mr Borrell, here we are in what we might call the usual debate on Turkey. If I may irony, we could almost create a section in each House that talks about Turkey's foreign policy, and that is, the Government of Turkey really makes it very easy for us, because acting as it acts always gives us reason to have on the agenda its activity, which we sometimes call 'assertive' and I think we could start calling it 'aggressive' without any major difficulties. Because they are premeditated and unnecessary actions. Actions, moreover, which are part of an election campaign, which is surely the worst way to put something on the public agenda, and which, in this case , may I remind you of something differential , there is no attempt to justify. In Turkey's positions on the Eastern Mediterranean there is some attempt to justify it. In this case, it is a flagrant violation of international law, without even the slightest narrative to try to say 'we are right', but it is only a question of supporting ⸻ as Mr Gahler said⸻ that very dangerous solution of the two States that no one had ever put on the international arena up to this point. And I believe that this policy of consummate facts, indeed, as Mr Gahler said, must be answered by the European Union. Contrary to what Mr Gahler did say, I would like us to focus on Varosha. Because the problem is that the maremágnum of relations with Turkey in the end leads us not to isolate every matter. I believe that Varosha, as Mr Borrell said, deserves to be on our agenda on its own, without trying to be another matter of the many conflicting issues cited by Mr Gahler. That is why I would ask colleagues to support a very essential agreement, in the resolution which we will put to a vote tomorrow, if I am not mistaken, in which, of course, we condemn this activity, we ask for a reversal of the situation and we remember, Mr Borrell, the pendens of possible sanctions, and that the only way to avoid sanctions, as the Council has said , is to completely change attitude and return, as we all propose, to the framework of solutions to the cyprus fundamental conflict within the framework of the relevant United Nations resolutions you have mentioned.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, tensions in the Eastern Mediterranean have been high for a month, and the partial reopening of Varosha fits into this very regrettable pattern. Turkey’s unilateral actions in the region highlighted the old paradox about how fragile stability really is, but it also reminded us that we have a responsibility to preserve it.  The resolution we are about to adopt will contribute to this. Without meddling in the affairs of a sovereign country, our job is to demand that international agreements are upheld, that the rights of local citizens are respected under all circumstances. The people of Cyprus, regardless of their background, mother tongue or identity, should not be held hostage to President Erdoğan’s nationalist and revisionist playbook. This is an agenda that we have come to witness far too often, an agenda of conflict and division designed to fan the flames of hate instead of looking for solutions and building consensus. And the EU must send out a strong signal to Turkey that violations of international law and violations of the sovereignty of EU Member States are not tolerated.  This is why we are calling on the Council to consider targeted sanctions against Turkey if President Erdoğan refuses to settle the issue through constructive dialogue, because Cypriots on both sides of the country deserve much better than this.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for almost 50 years now Turkey has occupied a part of the territory of a Member State of the European Union, Cyprus, in a totally illegal and scandalous manner. Today, Erdogan takes a new step by asking for the outright partition of the island. That should make us think. The more you try to soften it, the more it interprets it as weakness, the more docile you are, the more aggressive it is. The European Union is paying billions of euros, it is dumping thousands of migrants. It is given exorbitant economic benefits, it supports Islamists and multiplies military actions in Libya, Armenia and sometimes on our doorstep. We must also put an end to a European Union relationship with Turkey which is totally confiscated by Germany, Mrs Merkel has totally failed. Germany is a great economic power, but it does not have the necessary diplomatic and military power. And today, it is a failure that has led to our European civilization, our European nations flattening themselves in front of the Sultan of Ankara, this is an unacceptable situation. So the solution is simple: it is the firmness, the sanctions, the retaliatory measures, to call into question the customs union, the European funding, to put an end definitively with the accession process, to question also the seat that Turkey occupies today in the Council of Europe and within NATO. As is often the case in politics, the problem is not the means. The means we have are the will that is lacking.

name: Sergey LAGODINSKY
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, what is true leadership in times of COVID, economic decay and global instability? What would true leaders do to give their citizens what they need most – prosperity and a healthy environment? True leaders would start with trade, not confrontations. True leaders would unite, not separate, both at home and in the neighbourhood. True leaders would engage instead of invading; they would rule by law instead of oppression; they would release from jail people who stand for the political diversity of their country, for the intellectual wealth of their country. Their names are: Osman Kavala, Selahattin Demirtaş, Cihan Erdal, Ahmet Altan, Figen Yüksekdağ. They would listen to them instead of imprisoning them. True leaders would not provoke their neighbours, they would de-escalate. Leaders would set a vision, a vision in which their country is part of a family of democracies, part of Europe and not an alien country, an oppressor surrounded by fearful neighbours.  It was my conviction all the time that Turkey deserves such a vision, that Turkey deserves to be such a leader, a leader in this region and on our common continent. What we have been witnessing in the Mediterranean, in Cyprus and now in Cyprus and Varosha are not signs of this leadership, they are signs of weakness. It is a risky game that endangers such leadership and quite frankly a membership – someday, a membership of Turkey in Europe. This resolution is our last call to change the trajectory of our bilateral relationship. We are saying to the Turkish Government: we are not just listening to your words, we are watching your actions and quite frankly your actions are discomforting, they are sobering and they are disappointing. We are out of last chances to put our relationship back on track. Please help us with this, our last chance.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, honourable Mr Commissaryu and honourable members, Varosha in translation means old town, Varosha is the old town of Famagusta and Famagusta belongs to Cyprus and the Greek Cypriots. Varosha was illegally occupied by Turkey and continues to be illegally held by dictator Islamist Erdogan.  And when it comes to the crimes of the Islamist dictator Erdogan, there are excuses in this room what strategic partner he was, how much we had to maintain relations with him, and during that time he bought Russian missiles and trained to target THE PLANES of THE UNITED STATES with them. It's such a partnership, it's so mind-to-mind in some chapters. Perhaps he should use these missiles against a NATO aircraft to understand in this room that this man is not an ally of either NATO or the European Union.  And just as it was disgraceful when dictator Erdogan waged war against the first Christian Armenians, transferring Islamists, transferring fighters, and now we continue to turn a blind eye. This is not the time for declarations, it is time for real action, it is time to stop the funds, it is time to say that Erdogan is a dictator, and Famagusta is a Cypriot city and belongs to a single Cyprus and the Greek Cypriots.

name: Giorgos GEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Mr Borrell, Famagusta, the most eastern city in the European Union, was occupied by Turkish troops in August 1974. Since then it has remained a silent, uninhabited city, a ghost town, a black spot for the history of the whole of Europe, but a city alive that has been waiting for its inhabitants for 46 years to return. Instead of its inhabitants, they went the day before, not by chance, November 15, the anniversary of the proclamation of the pseudo-state, Mr. Tatar and Mr. Erdogan for a picnic. It was a provocative act that provoked both the wrath of both the living and the dead. Many of our Turkish Cypriot compatriots have protested this action, as well as Erdogan's attempt to assimilate them, calling for democracy and freedom. The ghosts of the dead inhabitants of Famagusta roamed among the uninvited visitors.  The challenge of Erdogan and Turkey in Cyprus and Varosia is unbearable. With the opening up of part of Varossia and its threatened settlements, which will of course also be a difficulty in resolving the Cyprus problem, they undermine the effort of the UN Secretary-General. They're already talking about two states. Dozens of declarations, reports and resolutions such as the United Nations' 550 and 789 call on Erdogan and Turkey to hand over the city to its rightful inhabitants. Erdogan's provocativeness is not being buried. Apart from Libya and Syria, he extends his hand to Nagorno Karabakh, curses European leaders, challenges France, provokes Germany yesterday and we say that Turkey should either come to its own reasonable ourselves or should be subject to targeted sanctions.  The problem in Cyprus can only be solved if the negotiations resume from where they left off in Crans-Montana, on the basis of the bi-social bi-community federation, with political equality, in a way that will share on the basis of international law the wealth of the peoples of the region, so that the country and the region can pacifize and, moreover, the European Union can salvage its credibility, which Mr Erdogan is provocatively undermining.

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Mr President, I tend to agree with the assessment that the opening of Varosha by Turkey and any reference of Erdoğan to a two-state solution only contributes to the increase of tension and must be reversed. But let’s not make the same mistake as a few weeks ago when the conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh was on the agenda of the European Parliament and when some MEPs thought it’s a war of religion or some clash of civilisation yet others mixed in their feelings about Erdoğan or Turkey into the subject. Let’s realise the historical context of this conflict that underlies 46 years of division on the island and also the nature of this conflict. There are two indigenous peoples – Turkish and Greek Cypriots. Any solution that leaves one or the other out or disenfranchised is not a solution and is a grave mistake. There is a federal solution of reunification to this problem. It is high time to dust off the Annan plan, rejected by the Greek Cypriots in 2004, when a divided Cyprus was allowed to enter the European Union.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, today we are discussing Turkey's criminal activities against my city, Famagusta. Turkey, a country that continues to lead all criminal, illegal, expansionist, aggressive actions from the Caucasus to the Mediterranean. To date, the European Union has not imposed a single sanction in this country and continues to tolerate and finance it. As a European citizen, as a staunch defender of the European idea and of the European Union, as a Member of the European Parliament, today I am very ashamed that the European Union has not seemed worthy of its history, because the European Union has not respected its principles and values and has shown unacceptable tolerance towards the criminal activity of Erdoğan and Turkey.  I would really and honestly like to know today how you feel and how you feel, Mr Borrell, how the European Commission and the European Council feel. You know that yesterday and not today Turkey's customs union with the European Union had to be suspended, pre-accession aid had to be stopped and you had to ban the European Union's war industry from giving turkey a single bullet, because you know that these bullets will be used against Cyprus, Greece, Syria, Libya and our Armenian brothers in Ngorno Karabakh.  Famagusta is my own city, it is the city I was born in, it is the city of my dreams, it is where we built our future, it is the city with 36 centuries of Greek and Christian history and no Erdoğan, no Turkey can really deprive us of it. But this city we are discussing today, Famagusta and Varosia, is also a European city, it is also your city. That is why I call on you to defend our European city, our own European legal residents and to force Erdoğan to hand over this city to the rightful inhabitants. It is unacceptable, and I shall end, and it is challenging in 2020 for Erdoğan and Turkey to deprive myself of my inalienable right to return to my ancestral homes, my right to operate my churches and to worship the graves of our ancestors. How many other crimes will the European Union tolerate in order to finally impose those sanctions, which you avoided mentioning today, Mr Borrell? (applause)

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, I was fortunate enough to be born in Famagusta, Varosia. We left to escape the Turkish troops and it was not our choice. Since then, too much has happened. There was the summit agreement between the two leaders of Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots to return the city of Varossia to the rightful inhabitants. Resolutions 550 and 789 followed and I remember my mother packing her bags to go back to Varoshi, believing that international law would prevail. They have made fun of it, just as Turkey is making fun of the entire international community, as Turkey continues to mock the European Union and in order for Turkey to stop making fun of all of us, strict sanctions must be taken against Turkey. Return of the city of Famagusta to the rightful inhabitants!

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: – Mr President, the division of Cyprus is not new and dates back a long time. The island was divided already before the Turkish invasion in 1973. What is new now is that Turkey seems to have given up on a negotiated solution. The decision to open up Varosha is a provocation against all those wishing for a peaceful settlement and a reunification of the island. We saw and noted the brave protests from Turkish-Cypriots against Erdogan’s visit to Cyprus. And we know very many Cypriots on both sides want a solution.  I really hope that the UN-led negotiations can be restarted and finally, after decades of talks, be guided to a successful conclusion.  Mr Borrell, we must be honest, it is shameful that we still have a divided country in Europe. The benefits in economic and political terms of a negotiated solution will benefit all Cypriots alike, on both sides.  As a Belgian, I know that federal structures can be complicated, that compromises demand a lot of political will, but I’m also convinced that Cypriots on both sides have the ability to reach an agreement, unify their country, and live and prosper together, with added stability for the whole region. This is what Ankara and Erdogan should work for, support and focus on.

name: Bernhard ZIMNIOK
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Erdogan's speech in the Cypriot ghost town of Varosia is another building block of his expansionist policy of provocation and military confrontation. Whether in Syria, Libya or Nagorno-Karabakh, Erdogan is increasingly intervening in other states in violation of international law. It provokes clashes with Greece and Cyprus in the fight for gas and oil and puts pressure on the EU with waves of refugees. He has been very active in Europe for many years, financing the construction of mosques in which he indoctrinates the Muslim youth, raises them against the West and its values, and thus establishes his fifth column. The EU's response to this provocation? As always weak and helpless. This is already shown by the title of today's item on the agenda: the much-needed resumption of talks. Have we learned nothing from history? That an appeasement policy will not succeed with megalomaniacal dictators? Should we seriously reunite here every few months to talk again about provocations and wars, to lament About Erdogan, and then urgently seek to talk to him again? Erdogan understands only one language: hardness. The EU accession talks with Turkey must be brought to an immediate end, NATO membership must be called into question and, above all, we must impose sanctions on Turkey. Or do we want to continue to be very devot in our approach to this Islamist troublemaker? We don't!

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr This resolution is the twelfth in a series of toothless angry letters. I can imagine what you said during the negotiations: 'We have to write an angry letter', said the Social Democrat. "Yes," said the green gently condoning. "We must ask the Council to impose strong sanctions," said the Christian Democrat. "No, no, no," the liberal said. "It's way too tough. Perhaps we should ask them to consider the possibility of imposing targeted sanctions." Yes, those who would rather bark than take concrete action against Erdogan won. It was another angry letter. We could freeze the customs union with Turkey for six months, remove pre-accession aid, secure the border and stop paying Erdogan for our border control, end the membership negotiations. But you're against that. A Turkish proverb reads: "The dogs bark but the caravan continues." The caravan is Erdogan's and it is neo-Ottoman.

name: Özlem DEMIREL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The latest provocation from the palace in Ankara is "picnic on Varosia" and implies the two-state solution for Cyprus. In order to gain his share of the eastern Mediterranean, Erdogan provokes and haggles like on a bazaar. But we are not in a bazaar; it is about the future of the people of Cyprus. And the future of Cyprus can only be achieved by the people of Cyprus, taking into account the different population groups and respect for minority rights, but certainly not by the autocrat.  What Erdogan is doing is one thing. But the other is that the EU has been suspending the resolution of the Cyprus issue for decades. However, as long as the problem is not solved in a sustainable way, the polarization between the two sections of the island's population is progressing, because nationalist forces are also fueling it, Erdogan has every opportunity to provoke. As you know, Erdogan is on the wall in domestic and foreign policy. But the EU gives it room for manoeuvre. Let us stop doing so and ensure that there is a sustainable, democratic and peaceful solution in Cyprus as well.

name: Dorien ROOKMAKER
text: Mr President, I fully share the indignation of my colleagues here. Perhaps we should admit that the Turks and the Turkish Cypriots, led by Erdogan and Tatar, are a size too big for the EU. Erdogan is playing high stakes in securing resources in the Mediterranean and near Nagorno-Karabakh. Tatar violates all international agreements and has taken de facto Varosha, which is off limits.  It's completely out of control. It's angry eating pears with government leaders or local politicians flouting all the rules when it suits them. It cannot be explained that we treat an Erdogan or Tatar differently than, for example, Putin. The EU should push for firm international action against Turkey and thus against the Turkish government in Cyprus. We support the resolution, but we fear that tougher measures against these gentlemen will prove necessary.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Unfortunately, we have to deal once again today in plenary with Turkey's aggressive behaviour. Let me be clear at the outset: the Turkish approach in Varosia is unacceptable. As the European Parliament, we stand by Cyprus and strongly condemn this further unnecessary provocation by Mr Erdogan. For us in the European Union, the benchmark for the future of Cyprus is the relevant united-nation Security Council resolutions. There must be no activities that are not in line with these resolutions.  Turkey's plans for Varosia will seriously undermine the prospect of a solution to the Cyprus conflict; Many previous speakers have pointed this out. They are, in my view, another destabilising Turkish action after illegal drilling in Greek and Cypriot waters, the bilateral agreement with Libya and the escalation in Nagorno-Karabakh and Syria.  High Representative Josep Borrell continues to deem our support in seeking de-escalation in the region. A solution to all contentious issues can only be achieved through dialogue between all parties and on the basis of international law. However, for such talks to take place, Turkey must at last refrain from unilateral provocations. Otherwise, further sanctions will, of course, remain an option for the European Union. Instead of constant confrontation, our relations with Turkey should be characterised by dialogue and cooperation, but to this end Turkish policy must finally change substantially.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr President, any change to the status quo at Varosha is in violation of the relevant UN Security Council resolutions and we strongly condemn the latest action by Turkey. Instead of contributing to the agreement, these actions negatively modify the situation on the ground and undermine mutual trust. The only solution is to relaunch negotiations on the reunification of Cyprus, under the auspices of the United Nations Secretary—General, as soon as possible. Here we urge Turkey to commit concretely to this end. I support the joint text of the resolution and the agreement to focus on Varosha. There will be an opportunity for the Parliament to address overall relations with Turkey in a country—specific report. What has been a strategic partnership for decades is turning more and more into strategic provocation by Turkey. Therefore, the European Union will need to unify its voice and protect its interests and the territorial integrity of its Member States.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, after the failure to reach a comprehensive settlement to the Cyprus issue in Crans-Montana in 2017, both sides are moving further and further away. The European Union has unfortunately failed to be an objective broker in Cyprus. We have lost the momentum and we should not be surprised that we are facing much harder rhetoric these days. Today the hotspot is Varosha, but if we want to avoid any further unilateral action that could raise tensions on the island, the EU should play an active, constructive and objective role in promoting cooperation and reconciliation between the two sides.  Turkish Cypriot people spoke at the recent elections and stated that all alternatives for settlement should be on the table, because a settlement on the basis of federation has not been possible for 50 years due to Greek Cypriot unwillingness to share power and prosperity with the Turkish Cypriot side, as declared by the UN Secretary-General in the Annan Plan and his report of May 2004. Of course in order to move forward all unilateral activities in the Eastern Mediterranean must be immediately ceased and replaced by diplomacy, cooperation and dialogue. A regional conference on the matter, which includes the Turkish Cypriot and Greek Cypriot sides as co-owners of the hydrocarbon resources around the island, Turkey, Greece and all the relevant parties should be convened as soon as possible.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the This recent appearance in Varosia, in the Turkish-occupied part of Cyprus, is just the culmisocity of a long series of provocations and aggression by Turkey against Member States of the European Union. Of particular importance here is the demand for a secession of the Turkish-occupied part. This is a very clear and direct attack on the territorial integrity of a Member State of the European Union.
