And if there is no clear answer from the European Union as a whole, then European solidarity is just a hollow phrase. That is why, firstly, I call for an immediate end to the accession negotiations with Turkey, with this, of course, the cessation of all payments to Turkey, such as pre-accession aid or development cooperation funds. Secondly, the threat of massive sanctions against every part of the Turkish economy should aggression not be stopped immediately. Thirdly, Turkey must finally recognise the territorial sovereignty of Cyprus. If Turkey is not prepared to do so, then all agreements between the EU and Turkey, and in particular the trade agreements, must be terminated. It is high time to finally show the Teeth of the Turkish aggressor. It is time to act, and when I say action, I mean a vigorous and determined action against a brutal and unscrupulous aggressor.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today's debate shows us that the historical disputes between the two concepts concerning the situation and status of Cyprus remain valid: the concept of enosis and taxi is now applied by the method of facts made. Today, Cyprus, a Member State of the European Union, is divided by a border resembling the border between North and South Korea, and the capital of Cyprus, Nicosia, remains the only capital in the world divided by a wall after the fall of the Berlin Wall. Warosza, called before 1974 Copacabana Mediterranean, a beautiful city, today resembles a ghost town.  We must do everything we can to ensure that this dispute is resolved peacefully in accordance with a UN Security Council resolution, and the rights of the inhabitants of this beautiful city, expelled more than 46 years ago, find fair reparation. Fair – that is, giving the rightful owners ownership.

name: Ioannis LAGOS
text: Mr President, Turkey has taken courage and behaves in this way by taking advantage of the passive attitude of a raging Europe, which does not even dare to react. We have seen Turkey over the years pursuing the same foreign policy and this is not an Erdoğan issue, but it is itself, Turkey's single foreign policy. So as long as Europe is submissive and accepts what the Turks are doing, expect nothing else. With regard to the sanctions you are talking about, it is not possible to stop Erdoğan and Turkey through some signatures, which may also be collected if everyone agrees. The solution to stop Turkey behaving in this way is the immediate interruption of funding, is the immediate cessation of the pre-accession discussions that are taking place and is the immediate withdrawal of the occupying troops from our occupied Cyprus. That's the only way the Turks can understand.  Nor can I understand how it is possible for a Turkey, which is collapsing economically, to find support from the European Union and from Germany more specifically. We see that in recent times the money given to Turkey is incredible and a state that would have collapsed, really, you are preserving it in order to stay alive and then challenge you. And, finally, I want to show a picture showing here the visit to Varosia of Tayyip Erdoğan. Next to him is a particular person. This person is called Kenan Akin. He's the killer of Cypriot Solomos Solomos in 1996. There is an international arrest warrant for this gentleman, which is not executed, in violation of all international rules and you will now go to (the President removes the floor from the speaker) and actually silences him. This is unacceptable and this alone shows the extent of humanitarian hypocrisy (the President removes the floor from the speaker). Unacceptable.

name: Vangelis MEIMARAKIS
text: Madam President, the recent and extremely provocative actions of the Turkish President, with the illegal attempt to open and colonize the Varosians, are finally the drop that overflowed the glass. This new and direct challenge by Turkey is a flagrant violation of international law and is directed against the sovereignty of the Republic of Cyprus, the decisions of the United Nations, and is an aggressive challenge to the European Union.  Erdoğan's supposed Europeanisation in recent days because of the meeting and the European Council now in December is pre-formal and should not fool us. If he really wanted to follow a Western course he would have already cancelled his decision to convert Hagia Sophia into a mosque, had he already suspended and withdrawn Oruç Reis from the Aegean Sea and suspended illegal NAVTEX, apologised to European leaders for their offensive characterizations and, of course, much more would not have dared the fiesta in Varosia and even talk about two states in Cyprus.  The tolerance of such provocative statements is a legitimacy of the occupation and therefore a loss of European territory, because Cyprus has joined the whole of the European Union. So because none of this has done enough with Erdoğan's hypocrisy. On 11 December, the Council must decide on tough sanctions on Turkey, an arms embargo and even a break in the customs union. Any further postponement on our part will further crush Turkey and be detrimental to the prestige of the Union itself.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, the greatest issue before us is that this resolution clearly sends two messages to Turkey about its illegalities in Varosia. Firstly, we are calling for the transfer of the area to its rightful inhabitants under the temporary administration of the United Nations and, moreover, we are asking Turkey to withdraw its occupying troops. That is what the UN Security Council resolutions have been calling for for decades. With the withdrawal of the occupying troops there will also be the application of the rules of European Union law throughout Cyprus and this will form the basis for a comprehensive solution that will bring peace, security and prosperity and allow everyone, Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots, to have a common future.  Mr Borrell, I am addressing you quite a bit with resolutions and agendas. As long as you insist on the failed policy of appeasement in practice, no matter how much you deny it in words, you are at a stand-off with the principles and values of the European Union, but also with the majority of the citizens of the European Union, because the European Union is not only arms trade and trade in things with Turkey. Our greatest interest is our values.

name: Filip DE MAN
text: Mr President, the European Union likes to be a champion of human rights, but when Turkey behaves like a rogue state, it even abandons its own Member States. Muslim brother Erdoğan is allowed to occupy half of Cyprus – an EU member state – with impunity, violate Greece's territorial waters, take part of the Mediterranean to steal gas and petroleum. He can blackmail us with a massive influx of refugees, to which we will offer him another EUR 5 billion. He is allowed to make election speeches here, set up mosques en masse and was allowed to threaten the French and German navies with impunity during his arms deliveries to the Muslim brothers in Libya.  Therefore, stop those naïve and expensive accession negotiations. Billions of euros have already been squandered on Sultan Erdoğan. Turkey, by the way, has not threatened us. We are not economically dependent on them. Turkey has a GDP of about Switzerland and their military muscle shows, of course, ridicuul compared to the European clout. But the EU remains lax and cowardly.  Turkey has always been a threat. The Ottomans have led millions of Europeans away as slaves for centuries and still occupy part of eastern Europe. Because remember: Constantinople, President, is ours.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: Madam President, hello to all of Strasbourg, the seat of the European Parliament, where I am today. Month after month, Mr Erdogan's Turkey provokes the European Union and its Member States, stirs up all the conflicts in our neighbourhood, from Libya to Armenia, and violates UN resolutions in the eastern Mediterranean and now in Famagusta. European indulgence has lasted too long. I reminded us here a few weeks ago that when a Member State suffers blatant infringements of its sovereignty, we owe it full solidarity and not mediation. There can be no neutral mediation. There may be a dialogue, but neutral mediation cannot take place with such a provocateur vis-à-vis the European Union. Of course, Turkey is and will remain a great country and a great neighbour with its own interests, which do not always coincide with ours. We have other problematic neighbours who have a lot to do with Turkey, too. But diplomacy must help find reasonable compromises. Where is the will for reasonable compromise in Ankara? There is only a repetition of aggressive provocations. We must also be clear-headed that today Erdogan's claims go far beyond traditional nationalist postures. There is also a strong ideological dimension in this constant agitation, an Islamist inspiration that we cannot ignore. This is profoundly incompatible with our values, our worldview and our way of life. This should therefore lead us to take targeted sanctions, but also to put an end to the myth of the possible Turkish accession to the European Union, which is a dangerous game of dupes.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Madam President, at the October European Council you supported the adoption of a 'positive' agenda for Turkey. Before the ink of the conclusions dried up, Turkey continued its provocations and illegal actions from the Eastern Mediterranean and Libya to the Caucasus and Ngorno Karabakh. Colleagues, in Varosia, have had their doors and windows open for 46 years, waiting for those who were violently persecuted to return, leaving behind their ancestral homes. Security Council Resolution 550 of 1984 called for the return of residents under the temporary administration of the UN, giving hope to hundreds of Greek Cypriot refugees to return, a hope that Mr Erdoğan, with his hate picnic with his chosen Mr Tatar, wants to erase forever, even renaming the main avenue after the Turkish general of Attila , serving the disastrous plan of partition.  Erdoğan despises international law and you ostrich. So instead, Mr Borrell, once again expressing your concern and solidarity, take decisions that protect the dignity of the peoples you represent. Sanctions are now a one-way street, it is now a one-way street to stop any sale of European arms to Turkey, as Parliament has asked you to do. And lastly, Madam President, today is a day of shame for the European Parliament for giving the floor to someone who the Greek judiciary has condemned (the President removes the floor from the speaker) to criminal (the President removes the floor from the speaker) murders. Shame!

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Madam President, during his visit to Cyprus on 15 November, the Turkish President clearly took a hostile but now recurrent position on the fait accompli. On this issue, as on all the others where the hand of the Islamist Erdogan is placed, we make a mistake by not summoning history. This is not an intellectual coquettishness, but the only way to understand Erdogan's attitude and thus to counter it. It was all a matter of demographics, and the Ottomans had already understood it well. It is a Turkish settlement policy that allowed the military occupation of the north of the island in 1974 and still justifies it today. Cyprus has become the fixed aircraft carrier for Erdogan's ambitions in the eastern Mediterranean. The pseudo-northern republic, which only it recognises, allows it to challenge international maritime law and flout the sovereignty of an EU member state. Thanks to the splendid inaction of the European states, Ankara has even given itself the luxury of redesigning the map of maritime zones with the Tripoli government. Erdogan's Turkey sees the world and history with a long view, we look at it with a microscope and you are so lax, always unable, after so many provocations, to take appropriate sanctions measures. I will conclude by recalling that while we are talking, in the south of the Caucasus, Armenians are experiencing the bitter experience of Erdogan's manoeuvres and his conquest of religious and ethnic undertones, which converts basilicas into mosques, in the greatest guilty silence of Europe.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, imagine a beautiful town deserted by its inhabitants, who were violently forced to leave their homes and their little paradise. This town can be anywhere – in Bosnia and Herzegovina, in Syria, in Nagorno-Karabakh. This time we talk about the case of Varosha. We have heard many times from refugees who have escaped war zones that they will only find peace when they return to their homes in order to reconcile their memories between the two lives they lived – a normal life before and the life as a refugee, a displaced person.  According to United Nations Conventions that we support in this Parliament, every refugee has the right to return and no one has the right to take somebody else’s property. On a few occasions in recent months, we have had to deal with a candidate country that claims to aspire to membership of the EU, while it upholds an irresponsible and aggressive behaviour, causing clashes in the eastern Mediterranean, making inflammatory speeches and helping the violent conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh. Now the country continues to divide European countries and breaks with United Nations Security Council resolutions by digging deeper wounds in the already traumatised memories of Cypriot citizens. It is high time to redefine our strategy towards Turkey and to set our border for the defence of our partners. Here we are united around values that respect dialogue and tolerance and despise bullying and aggression. It is time to show an exit strategy from historic mistakes and to stop the bullying in and around the European Union.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: – Madam President, it is an honour to speak for the first time under your presidency. Mr Borrell, the voice of the Parliamentarians has been heard today. I think we all agree. Our voice is heard loudly, but who is screaming, who is crying out for sanctions is Turkey, it is the Erdogan regime, and we are not listening.  What has happened in Varosha, the arrest of thousands of political activists, the challenge for NATO members using Russian weaponry, granting citizenship to members of Hamas and the Muslim Brotherhood, confronting all countries and getting into all the conflicts around them: with Israel, in Iraq, in Syria, in Armenia, in Egypt. How long are we going to tolerate this situation? And above all, most important of all: attacks, aggressions to two Member States of the European Union, such as Greece and Cyprus. We cannot continue to tolerate this situation and these sanctions must now be imposed.  We want to work together, Parliament with the Commission, to get the Member States to that conclusion at a forthcoming European Council.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, Turkish aggression is growing. We see the Erdoğan regime fighting Greece and Cyprus, against Artsach, in Syria and Libya. He's even testing S-400 missiles Russia. The resolution now before us says that we must enter into dialogue with Turkey, with diplomacy, real cooperation, with negotiations in a spirit of goodwill.  Mr President, what a joke! If Turkey doesn't want something, it's talk. Turkey has been pressuring the EU for years. And, of course, he knows that he is dealing with large Turkish communities in many Member States. He also knows that he can cancel the migration deal with Europe. So don't give way to blackmail. Mr. Borrell, strong the flaccid hands, firmly the nodding knees. Take action against Turkey. Sanctions, now!

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the Members for this debate, at some moments passionate, and I understand the reasons, but you know I am in charge of trying to look for solutions and I am trying to do so. Nobody is bowing but we have to continue reaching out to Turkey. The European Union Council, at its next meeting, will have to take important decisions about our relationship with Turkey. They decided to do so at the last meeting. Certainly, we are at a critical moment in our relationship with Turkey, but you can be sure that the European Union is on the side of Cyprus. Greece supports the speedy resumption of Cyprus settlement talks under the auspices of the United Nations, fully committed to a comprehensive settlement of the Cyprus problem based on a bicommunal, bizonal federation with political equality as set out in the relevant Security Council resolutions. This is our position and we will continue engaging diplomatically with Turkey in order to try an attitude that could contribute to this objective.  This is my role – I am being paid for that! – and though the European External Action Service works in this direction it doesn’t mean that we are bowing, we are just trying to engage in diplomatic activity and prepare the European Union Council, and the leaders will have to take a decision. It’s not up to me to say now it is going to be this, it is going to be censure or not – it is the European Union Council which will discuss and I will work hard to prepare this discussion in order to take the decision that politically the leaders of the European Union will decide to take, and we will continue discussing it for sure.

name: Anna-Michelle ASIMAKOPOULOU
text: Writing. Mr President, Mr Borrell, Turkey's recent provocations in Varosia, accompanied even by solemn events, have not come as a 'lightning bolt in the air'. And unfortunately these objectives have so far been achieved. Turkish challenges and violations of international law are directed not simply at EU Member States, but at Europe itself, with the aim of harming its prestige, power and role. The opportunities given to Turkey to comply with the decisions of the Summit were obviously seen by Erdoğan as weakness and sluggishness. Turkey has taken advantage of the EU's tolerance and has taken new unacceptable, provocative actions. If we continue in the same pattern, it is certain that Turkey will not be accompanied. On the contrary, we would encourage Erdoğan to continue his destabilizing tactics. Let us finally take immediate and drastic measures that will permanently halt the revisionist ambitions and put an end to Turkey's provocative actions and violations of international law. Let it be Varosia, the "beginning of the end" of Europe's timidity towards Turkey.

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: Writing. – I belong to the generation that experienced Turkish barbarism in my country and I saw with my own eyes thousands of my compatriots taking the path of refugees and to this day no one has returned. I had the blessing of the people of Cyprus to elect me as a Member of the European Parliament and I swore that I would do everything possible to rid my country of the Turkish invader. The violation of human rights and the violation of the principles and values of the European Union are blatant. But some insist on pardoning the fascist Erdoğan and content themselves with verbal complaints. Of the ones Erdoğan reads and laughs at. To save the dignity of the European Union, one is the way. The path of strict sanctions and the imposition of measures on Turkey, to pay Erdoğan and every Erdoğan who mocks our European family that such behaviour is not tolerated. Do so even now, even the twelfth, to save the prestige and dignity of European construction.

name: Julie LECHANTEUX
text: In writing. Today's debate focuses on "the escalation of tensions in Varosia, following the illegal measures taken by Turkey, and the need to reopen urgently" talks" between the Republic of Cyprus (EU member state) and its northern part, occupied since 1974 by the Turkish army: the self-proclaimed Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus (RTCN). It's a real-false debate! For the European Union does not have the courage to discuss the real substantive issue: the Turkish military occupation of the northern part of Cyprus, in total violation of Cypriot sovereignty and international law. On Sunday, 15 November, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, on his way to Varosia (an abandoned district of the Cypriot city of Famagusta) to celebrate the 37th anniversary of the Turkish military occupation, gave a further demonstration of the arrogance and aggressiveness of his international policy. The European Union must stop bowing to the wishes of Sultan Erdogan! We must stop financing it with tens of billions of euros from the European taxpayer (especially French, since France is a net contributor) and immediately stop the unlikely process of EU membership.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. – Turkey's escalation of tensions in the Aegean and Eastern Mediterranean continues to cause deep concern, culminating in Turkish President Erdoğan's recent unprecedented illegal actions against the city of Famagusta. In the European Parliament I will not stop condemning in all tones and by all means the criminal attitude of Turkey which deliberately refuses to comply with UN Security Council resolutions, violates international law, disregards European values, the rule of law and human rights and bluntly blackmails the European Union with words and deeds. The Position of the European Parliament has been clearly reflected in the recent resolutions on Turkish challenges and threats. That is why I am calling today once again for the strict stance of the EU and for the immediate imposition of sanctions on Turkey for illegal violation of European territory, among other things. The Union must halt without further delay any new attempt by Erdoğan to create fait accompli on European soil. Otherwise, he will be complicit in an on-going crime committed against two Member States, Greece and Cyprus, with unexpected consequences for the whole of Europe. It is our duty to guard our sovereign rights and unity.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, once again the tragic impasse of equal distance tactics and appeasement, which has followed over the years in the case of Turkey, is proving. All this strategy has achieved is to fuel the aggression and grandioseism of a country that systematically and consciously tramples on international law without any qualms. It is a disgrace that so far the EU has not imposed severe sanctions on an authoritarian regime that threatens peace throughout the Eastern Mediterranean. The continuation of this tolerance not only goes against Europe's very principles and values, but undermines the image of the Union in the eyes of millions of European citizens. Famagusta is a European city that belongs to its rightful inhabitants. If the EU does not react today, it will be both complicit and accountable for Turkey's criminal activity.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you very much for having this opportunity to address you today on a very important issue, an issue on geopolitical implications, which are the recent agreement between Israel and the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and recently Sudan, and maybe many more in the future. On behalf of the European Union I have welcomed these announcements, for three reasons. First, because we believe that these agreements help to establish new formal relations between countries that have decided to put their differences aside and to engage in a peaceful, bilateral cooperation. Secondly, we welcome these agreements because they can potentially enhance relations in areas such as technology, tourism, energy, trade, health, for regional cooperation. And third, because we believe that they could have a positive effect on other countries as well as more broadly on regional stability, which the European Union has consistently tried to promote. However, although these agreements bring positive developments, it’s clear that they all focus on the broader regional picture. Israel did commit in the context of the normalisation deal with the UAE to suspend its plans for annexation of occupied territory in the West Bank. This was a positive step and we celebrate it and we welcome it, but the agreements themselves do not address the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and the Israelis’ annexation plans still need to be abandoned, not suspended temporarily. Abandoned, abandoned altogether. We have always said there will not be sustainable peace and stability in the region without a comprehensive settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict and in particular the Israel-Palestinian conflict on the basis of a negotiated and viable two-state solution, built upon the internationally agreed-parameters. In this light, we should explore ways to apply the logic inherent to the normalisation process to generate a direct and positive impact on the situation on the ground and to create the conditions for a meaningful political process between Israel and the Palestinians. In the last weeks we had informal exchange between the Palestinian Foreign Minister Mr al-Malki and the European Union Foreign Ministers by video conference. I stressed the importance of re-engaging in a meaningful political dialogue. I also emphasised this to the Israeli Foreign Minister, Gabi Ashkenazi, when we spoke by telephone yesterday. Last week we saw the positive news that the Palestinian Authority will resume economic and security cooperation with Israel. We had actively encouraged this as the European Union, but at the same time the situation on the ground remains very worrying, notably due to continued advancements of illegal settlement construction and a significant spike in demolitions. The recent decision by Israel to open tenders to build a new settlement in Givat HaMatos, the first new settlement in occupied East Jerusalem in 20 years, is of huge concern, and yesterday in my phone conference with Minister Ashkenazi I expressed this concern and our condemnation of this initiative. We must work urgently to find a way to rebuild trust and confidence between the two parties. We must avoid unilateral actions that undermine peace efforts. The launch of negotiations remains essential. We will therefore continue to work with members of the international community, including, I hope, with a new administration in Washington, to uphold international law, to end the conflict and to ensure equal rights for all. Only by working together will we be able to end the current dynamics of perpetual confrontation and mistrust.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Mr Borrell, I am very grateful for your initial words of support for these agreements. Too bad 80% of the speech referred to settlements, and to conflicts between Israel and Palestine, as I imagine most of my left-wing colleagues will do in their speeches. I hope not. Let us all unern in the joy of the moment, the moment when we have a historic agreement between rival nations that did not even recognize their right to exist. Between the United Arab Emirates, Israel, Bahrain, Sudan and others that can be added together. Let's put the European Union at the forefront of this. We're out of this. That is why my group wanted us to talk about these agreements, because of the lack, really, in some European institutions, and especially in some political groups, of emotion about this issue. As we speak, thousands of Israeli and Emirati workers and entrepreneurs are flying and working, helping to bring greater economic prosperity, job creation, to creating security. Why can't we join this? Let us do so in a positive way, without obviating the themes that have been proposed; nobody does. I also welcome the sit-down of Palestinians and Israelis again, that Israel is talking to Lebanon again, after decades, about territorial disputes. It is not only the economy: there are also positive political factors, which I believe that we Europeans have to collect from these agreements. And I hope that the political groups will join this effort and we will all be positive and have the European Union at the forefront.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the signing of the Abraham Accords has indeed created a momentum for advancing relations between countries in the Middle East, as the current situation is unsustainable. Nevertheless, what the real impact will be remains to be seen. We cannot ignore the reservations of some other Middle Eastern countries, nor the voice of the Palestinians. But we need to support every agreement that is a step forward towards sustainable stability in the region as a whole.  We also take note that the Abraham Accords have been accompanied by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s commitment to suspend the planned unilateral annexation by Israel of occupied Palestinian territories in the West Bank against international law. However, we call again for these plans to be cancelled once and for all. Key objectives remain to put an end to the occupation of Palestine and achieve lasting peace between Israel and its Arab neighbours.  On a more general note, we must place the Abraham Accords into the broader context of geopolitical dynamics in the Middle East, in particular with regard to Iran, Saudi Arabia and Turkey. This is where the European Union should also use the momentum and take a more prominent role as a global leader in promoting peace and security, especially given the political change on the other side of the Atlantic.  Having said that, this might be one of the rare dynamics that should not be reversed from the Trump era’s legacy indeed but which should be managed in a different, responsible way with regard to both their geopolitical implications and their impact on Palestinians. Let’s use this opportunity to achieve more stability and prosperity in the region.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Land for Peace! That was in 2002 with the Arab Peace Initiative, the condition of the Gulf Arab states for normalising ties with Israel. The Abraham Accords have changed the condition for normalised relations with Israel, without consulting the Palestinians. Land for Peace became Peace for Peace, but between countries who actually didn’t have conflict. Don’t get me wrong: in a region beset with conflicts, dialogues and closer ties should be welcomed. I always favour dialogue over silence. Yet we should not ignore the circumstance in which these deals were agreed. De facto annexation by Israel continues, not to speak about the demolition of Palestinian structures, including EU-funded structures. The Abraham Accords may affect the chances of reaching a two-state solution if they legitimise and consolidate the status quo, while the status quo we all agree on is not the solution to the conflict. That, colleagues, that is what worries me. Dear High Representative, the two-state solution is close to being dead and buried. It’s time to do more than declaring we remain firmly committed to it. The Arab Gulf States and the EU must prevent the consolidation of the status quo and revive the two-state solution. We must act, you must act in defence of the two-state solution. You have our support.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the way in which First of all, I would like to express my delight at the agreements concluded with Israel. Any move that can reduce tensions in the Middle East is to be welcomed. Many Arab countries find it extremely difficult to reach any understanding with Israel, as the Palestinian issue is always at the heart of the debate. However, the agreement shows that relations can also be placed on a constructive level, provided that the political will is there.  I, too, am convinced that a general fatigue has set in, given the uncompromising attitude of the Palestinian leadership. Moreover, some Arab countries have recognized that Palestine cannot forever remain the focus of alignment of their relations with Israel. Having said that, the agreement also seems to me to be clear proof of a well-known proverb: "The enemy of my enemy is my friend." If we accept this premise that Iran is a crucial power in the region, an alliance between Israel and the Gulf states and Sudan seems politically sensible. The United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia are engaged in a proxy war against Iran in Yemen. They also share with Israel the widespread skepticism – except in Europe – about the nuclear agreement signed with Tehran. That is why the Abraham agreements are an advantage for the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain, and indirectly for Saudi Arabia – they bring more security. One final point: the signing of the agreements may open up better access to US weapons for all parties, which could be a deterrent against Iran.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain have opened diplomatic relations with Israel. Yesterday, Benjamin Netanyahu – though not officially confirmed – visited Saudi Arabia. In a region that has been suffering from conflict and confrontation for decades, such a dialogue between former antagonists is a good sign, and yes, this region really needs such good signs.  Therefore, one could actually wholeheartedly welcome the Abraham Accords if – and that’s the thing – they would live up to their stated goal to build peace. But – and that is also true, Mr White – recent developments are worrisome. The UAE has advanced a major arms deal with the USA as part of the bargain, as if we needed more weapons in the Middle East. Israel has stepped up its settlement policy against Palestinians and the human rights violations in Bahrain continue rather unnoticed. So a deal that only serves to build alliances against other neighbours or to arm the region even further is neither going to build peace, nor should it be supported by the European Union. But, on the other hand, every step that the UAE, Israel, Bahrain and hopefully many, many others take towards de-escalation and peace should have our full support.  So, very much in line with what you said, Mr Borrell, I think it’s time for a reality check. Let’s take the signatories at their word and use the new regional dynamic and the change in the US administration to initiate a new EU-led initiative to work towards an inclusive Israeli and Palestinian peace deal.

name: Witold Jan WASZCZYKOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. In the summer of last year under the auspices of American diplomacy Israel signed agreements normalizing relations with the Emirates, Bahrain, in the perspective are agreements with Sudan, Oman, Comoros, Djibouti, Mauritania, perhaps even with Saudi Arabia. This is accompanied by economic agreements on aviation cooperation with several countries. The conclusions are: the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is no longer the main conflict seen as a source of all instability, of all conflicts in the Middle East and the Persian Gulf. It seems that at least some Arab states are no longer hostage to the Palestinian cause. Can we also not be held hostage to this case? After all, the Palestinians were offered half a State of Palestine in 1948 and have systematically rejected different agreements ever since. Abraham's agreements are a success for American diplomacy and Israel. We have heard from Mr Borrell words of encouragement, but where does the European Union work, where is the Geopolitical Commission? We are part of the Quartet, but what role does the Commission play now? What do we initiate in the Middle East? How do we encourage the Palestinians to come back to an agreement or even negotiate with Israel? Will we engage in talks with the Americans, with the new administration, to maintain these agreements, or even to extend them?

name: Manu PINEDA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Mr Borrell, I will make you sincere: we do not understand this joy at peace agreements between the Israeli regime and the feudal monarchies of the Gulf, countries which were not at war with each other. In this I have to give the reason to Mr López-Istúriz. We don't celebrate this. If the signatory parties to these agreements stand out for anything, it is because of their contempt for human rights and a bellicose policy, which is resulting in an escalation of the arms trade. We are talking about countries that bomb Yemen or Libya and that are fully responsible for the destruction of the Palestinian people and the war in the region.  Curious peace agreements that are sold to us as an improvement for the Palestinian people, as a brake on Trump and Netanyahu's decision to annex an important part of the West Bank to Israel, but the reality is another. Palestinian society, which has not been consulted but is affected, has opposed agreements that bury any aspiration of a state of its own and, therefore, the burial of the two-state solution.  The annexation remains relentless every day. This year, the historic record for new settlements has been broken, irreversibly disconnecting areas such as Jerusalem or Bethlehem. And to all this, the extortion is added to Sudan, which, to get off the US list of countries that finance terrorism, will have to pay the United States $335 million and sign this shameful agreement with Israel. Mr Borrell, in the face of this diplomatic offensive, it is necessary to courageously defend the position of the European Union, recognizing the Palestinian state, urging Member States to do the same, increasing funding for UNRWA — a vital agency for Palestinian refugees, with which Trump and Netanyahu are trying to end - and promoting the international peace conference within the United Nations.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Solana, the Abraham agreements have been described by many observers as an historic agreement, a turning point towards peace, security and prosperity for the whole of the Middle East. These agreements have enormous potential to pave the way for dialogue in the region, but they have a very serious limitation: they make no contribution to resolving the element that has destabilised it for several decades, namely the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. These agreements certainly do not constitute a peace treaty, which is always concluded between war-going parties; they actually look much more like an alliance in anti-Iranian function, so not a pro-something alliance but against someone. For decades, many countries have used tensions between Israel and the Arab world to advance their personal geopolitical agenda. From 1967 to today, the world should have learned that the situation in the Middle East will not improve until the Palestinians see their rights recognised. Mr Solana, the worst enemy of peace in the Middle East is surrendering to the status quo and hate education. Let us not, as Europe, allow the next generations of Palestinians and Israelis to be victims and not beneficiaries of these agreements.

name: Gheorghe-Vlad NISTOR
text: – Madam President, Mr High Representative, distinguished colleagues, the Abraham Agreements can be a useful step in stabilising the Middle East, a stage in a comprehensive process aimed at ensuring cooperation and possibly peace in the region. The United States has played a key role in this process and I welcome its constant effort to find a negotiated solution.  The positive potential for regional cooperation exists. Through its limitations, however, the agreement could also have destabilising effects. The development of tensions between Arab states cannot be ruled out. There are differences of approach between countries that have been at war with Israel and those that have not participated directly in past conflicts.  The content of the Arab League's 2002 Peace Initiative, reactivated in 2007, should also be taken into account. The failure to include the Palestinian Authority in the talks is damaging and not only for the peace process as a whole, but also for the intra-Palestinian fatah-Hamas balance. Future negotiations must be open to all parties involved in the confrontation with the policy adopted by the European Union, which aims to adopt the two countries' solution.  In order to maintain its global relevance, the European Union must abandon its eminently reactive position, act strategically and assertively on geopolitical issues and take the lead in order to produce tangible results, in particular when targeting the region in its wider neighbourhood.

name: Elena YONCHEVA
text: Madam President, the Abraham Accords could have the potential to promote peace in the Middle East. They can become historic and I hope that they will also succeed in generating concrete achievements in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. In recent decades, the Union's approach has been to separate the Israeli-Palestinian conflict from the regional context and to focus on bilateral relations. Now the agreements give us an opportunity to rethink our policy and I firmly believe that Europe's involvement in strengthening Israel's regional normalization does not imply the withdrawal of the two-state solution. On the contrary, it is a factor in reviving the standardization process. In the coming months, it will be crucial to maintain encouraging talks between all parties. Therefore, instead of observing from afar, Europe should start to take the lead in promoting this regional dynamic.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Madam President, welcome to this perch, three peace agreements signed in six weeks between Israel and Arab countries. The sequence is historical, the word is not overused. The United Arab Emirates, therefore, Bahrain and Sudan are seizing The hand extended by Israel to establish security, prosperity and, at the end of the road, of course, peace in the region. And this bet, this hope, must continue, must continue this virtuous domino effect. There are already shudders in Lebanon, Oman, Kuwait and, of course, Saudi Arabia where Benjamin Netanyahu visited this weekend, or not, but we know that he spoke with Crown Prince bin Salman. Three-dimensional agreements: political, economic and social, with a reality already being observed on the ground: direct maritime transport lines between Haifa and Jebel Ali, near Dubai, the first plans of an oil pipeline between Eilat and Ashkelon to bring Emirati oil to Europe, the exchange of good practices, especially environmental, the question of desalination of water to face together shared challenges , all this while some thirty weekly flights already cross the skies between Tel Aviv, Abu Dhabi and Dubai. Abraham's accords are a response to those who advocate hatred and boycott. A reversal of logic, a paradigm shift. Bypassing conditions, blockades, bidding to build peace with the Palestinians, but not just first with them. To conclude by quoting the Emirati Prime Minister: this is a new impetus for the two-state solution. This opportunity must be seized by the Palestinians who, it is good news, have returned to the negotiating table and by the Israelis who must keep their promises and effectively stop the annexations to the West Bank.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, the Abraham Accords will no doubt have some consequences for the Middle East. But the key question is what effects they will have on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, which greatly affects stability in the whole region. And I am afraid they won’t be positive.  In a moment when there is no real peace deal in sight, and when the harsh reality of the occupation of Palestinian territories intensifies, this move might be another incentive for Israel not to really engage in a lasting solution to the conflict. For the truth is, Israel consolidates ties with some Arab nations without making compromises on the Palestinian front. And if it were true that preventing the formal annexation of the West Bank was the counterpart of the agreement, well, let’s remember that there is a de facto annexation with grave consequences on the daily lives of many Palestinians and which hinders the possibility of a settlement based on the two-states solution.  And to conclude, it is not that the EU should disregard these new developments in the region, it’s rather about taking them as an opportunity to re—engage with the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in a more vocal and active way. Hopefully, we can do that with the new Biden Administration.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: Mr President, the Abraham Agreements make one thing very clear, namely that Europe does not yet play any significant role in the peace process. After all, it was the US that pulled the cart. And what does the EU do? Continue to make unilateral criticism of Israel. Many Member States go so far as to deny Israel even the right to continue to call the Temple Mount the Temple Mount. My own country, the Netherlands, is also participating. I say it with vicarious shame.  The one-sided criticism really needs to change. Get rid of that finger of the finger! Let us take a more account of the complex situation in Which Israel finds itself. And let us make it clear to the Palestinian Authority that it is now really their turn to recognise Israel's right to exist and to come to the negotiating table. Then great things could happen, both for the Jews and for the Palestinians and for the whole region.  Mr Borrell, do you agree that it would be nice if the EU did play a serious role in this?

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Madam President, thank you and good to see you in your new position. The signing of the Abraham Agreement on 15 September could open a whole new chapter in the dynamics of relations between Israel and Arab countries in the Middle East. It creates a chance for peace to finally take the place of hostilities in the region. As a result of the agreement, the first visa waiver agreement between Israel and an Arab country could be reached, along with a number of banking and investment agreements, which is indeed a historic event. Both the UN and the European External Action Service described the agreement as a very positive breakthrough, as two Arab countries have normalised their relations with Israel. It hasn't been like this in a very long time. It is regrettable that it is only after this time that we have put the discussion on this subject on the agenda here in Parliament. On the EU side, it is time to focus on positive cooperation in the region, as opposed to passivity so far. The EU cannot afford to become a more weightless player in the region, since only peace and stability in the Middle East can prevent new waves of migration from moving towards Europe.

name: Evin INCIR
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the High Representative for his statement. I’m a firm believer in dialogue and cooperation. The creation of the EU is a concrete example of how we built peace in a region torn in pieces because of wars and conflicts. Looking at the Middle East, we see the urgent need of more cooperation, more dialogue for the sake of the people. However, all cooperation and agreements must be assessed through the lens of building peace and bringing prosperity. At the first glance I welcome the agreement between Israel and the UAE and Bahrain, but it is as important to look at the content, because only then we know if the ingredients for a wider peace are there. First and foremost, there is no reference to ending the occupation through a two—state solution between Israel and Palestine based on the internationally-agreed parameters. Secondly, the deal includes, to a greater extent, the matter of weapons sales. The people of the Middle East do not need more weapons; they desire more peace, democracy and prosperity. So ‘yes’ to cooperation and deals in all its glory, but let us not fool ourselves by claiming that the current Abraham Accord will bring peace to the region without adequately referring to one of the longest ongoing occupations we know: the occupation of Palestine.

name: Nicola BEER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In 2020, at a time dominated by isolation and setbacks in the shadow of the pandemic, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, and Israel are moving forward – toward innovation through cooperation.  If it was impossible to join forces so far, the Abraham Agreement broke old blockades. The focus is finally on common ground. Potential and creativity are thrown into the balance. A common tourism sector, cooperation in energy and security, joint research on the Corona vaccine: this is how the future works.  It is also good that an alliance of resistance against Iran is now being formed here, Mr Castaldo, the country whose government is constantly reaching out for more influence, which is also trying to undermine Europe. At the same time, this is an opportunity to reconsider the human rights situation in one's own country and to involve civil society in reforms.  I am also saying this, Mr Borrell, with a view to further agreements with Lebanon, Morocco, but also – and especially – Saudi Arabia. In this process, I am building on a strong role for the European Union in the future, firmly alongside America and the two governments for a two-state solution.  I cannot conclude without assuring that the European Parliament is no less aware of Palestinian interests and continues to maintain a fair solution for all parties involved in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. But the way to get there – out of the current impasse – also calls for the cooperation and sincere commitment of the Palestinians.  Let us start taking a step towards each other in the delegations of this House, albeit online, in the spirit of the agreement.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: – Madam President, recently the EU and most of this Parliament were alarmed about the plans of de jure annexation that, I quote: ‘could not go unchallenged’. But then Netanyahu signed the Emirates deal without a mention of Palestine. Since the deal, Israel has advanced 6 200 new settlement units, accelerated demolition of Palestinian homes as well as EU-funded schools and structures, and while the Trump administration effectively recognised Israel’s de facto annexation, no protest came from the Emirates or others. But annexation must not be normalised. The EU is rule-based; we must respect international law. The EU and the EU governments are complicit in violations of human rights as long as we don’t act in order to stop Israel’s apartheid policy. Stop romanticising this agreement, enforce differentiation policy, review all EU agreements with Israel, and push for Palestinian elections as soon as possible.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Madam President, thank you also to the high representative for his presence and for his statement, which the Socialist Group supports, and myself. I believe that there is, many colleagues in the House, too, expressed some ambivalence in the face of the signing of these agreements. On the one hand, it is positive that two Arab states, traditional enemies of the State of Israel, have established relations with the Hebrew state. At the same time, objectively, it weakens the Palestinian cause and the resolution of the two states, because clearly there was the Arab initiative, which, as you will recall, blinded Israel's recognition of the two states' resolve and the resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The European Union must therefore make an additional effort, it has been said, that we need a European peace initiative in the Middle East, with the support of the Americans, perhaps a second peace conference in Madrid, to reach the two states' solution as soon as possible.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Madam President, Mr Borrell, I would like to thank mr Borrell for his work on I too welcome Israel's Abraham agreements with some Arab countries, because they consolidate Israel's security. On the Arab side, these agreements are a change of course. It used to be said to Israel: "Agree with the Palestinians, then we will also come together". This link between the two elements has now been cut, but this does not remove palestinian reality. Israel, which is now strengthened, now has two options: either triumph and push ahead with settlement policy, or renounce annexation in a binding manner, yet seek compensation. We Europeans will continue to invest in the two-state solution. It will also be important to persuade the Palestinians to achieve the necessary democratic renewal.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the search for peace and stability in the Middle East is a difficult and delicate operation, in which we have unfortunately learned not to take anything for granted. The definition of the Abraham agreements is certainly a significant step in which historical mistrust falls, a clear convergence of economic and political objectives between Israel, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain is established. I think that the construction of bridges and alliances should always be welcomed, and this must also be the case here. I believe, however, that two points need to be added: the first is that these agreements must in no way make us lose sight of the Palestinian question, the enormous difficulty in which Palestinian refugees find themselves today and the need not to take second place to the solution of the two peoples-two states and the full recognition of a state in Palestine. The second consideration is that the peace agreements and processes are positive if they do not turn into alliances against them and the European Union cannot simply look at what is happening in the Middle East. We need a new and renewed leadership that will help to take difficult and never obvious steps in the right direction.

name: Mounir SATOURI
text: Madam President, Mr High Representative, this agreement offers a double victory for Israel. First, because it strengthens its international relations, but also because it enshrines the Trump plan and its desire to bury ever more the possibility of a viable Palestinian state. Let us not hide our faces, the mention of the cessation of colonization in this agreement is only there to allow the United Arab Emirates to present a victory to its mute population. Colonization does not stop in fact. If countries sign with Israel, it is because they have chosen the strong in the face of the weak, the force in the face of justice. This has never been the choice of the European Union in this conflict and I hope it never will be. It is up to us Europeans to continue to choose the law, the fight against illegal occupation, against annexations, against political imprisonment, for a just and lasting peace. It is up to us to play our part and stop letting the solutions we defend flouted. It is up to us to carry a peace process based on the law that makes and must continue to make our DNA.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, thank you, and I would like thank all of you for this exchange of views. You know, this complex reality can be perceived in different approaches, but for the European Union, the normalisation of relations between Israel and the countries of the region is, all in all, a welcome development which represents a positive hope for the future. But as I said, and I repeat at the same time, a just and lasting peace in the Middle East will require also progress in relation to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and there, further actions will be involved. Our role is to continue reaching out to the parties in the region. Yesterday in my conversation with Minister Ashkenazi, when the Foreign Affairs Minister of the Palestinian Authority came to the Foreign Affairs Council, we encouraged both to re-engage and have also signalled our willingness to move ahead in our bilateral relations with both. We continue thinking that a two-state solution is the only viable – difficult, but the only viable – solution, and a lot of work is still required in order to bring, at the same time, security to Israel, freedom to the Palestinians, and peace and stability to the region as a whole. These deals and the normalisation of their relations have to be considered in the complex reality of the zone. Well, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain have never been, technically, at war with Israel, so to call that a peace agreement without having had a war may be an exaggeration. But as I said, in any case it’s a positive approach that reflects a somewhat transactional rather than transformative approach, and it has to be understood in the context of the growing strategic rivalry between the Emirates and the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and Turkey, and the wider tension in the Eastern Mediterranean, and maybe this strategy will reflect a deeper polarisation in the Arab world, where mostly Sunni Arab states consider Iran, along with political Islam, as the more serious threats in the region and are thus likely to engage in a deeper cooperation with Israel. In this context, a new regional paradigm has been emerging, where a peace deal is no longer a precondition to normalisation, and both the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and the Emirates have developed a narrative which describes normalisation as a driver in the Israeli-Arab confidence-building process, creating a more conducive environment for a two-state solution. On the other hand, it is clear that this normalisation comes after other strategic considerations, such as gaining military (F-35 fighters for the Emirates) or economic advantages, economic deals with the Emirates and Bahrain, or for Sudan, a major gain to get out of its international isolation by being taken off the list of state sponsors of terrorism, which is a major win for Sudan. Its economy is on the verge of collapse and badly needs outside investment. All these things, for sure, have been taken into consideration in these kinds of agreements. About the demolition by Israel of Palestinian structures: yesterday I had the opportunity, as I said, to talk about it with the Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel. For sure I didn’t convince him, and he didn’t convince me with their arguments and reasons, but we have reiterated that we consider these activities illegal from the point of view of international law. We reiterated our call on Israel to halt such demolitions. This confirms a regrettable trend of confiscation and demolition since the beginning of the year, which constitutes, for sure, an impediment towards the two-state solution but also to the improvement of the bilateral relations between the European Union and Israel. I am working on the prospects of holding again meetings of the Association Council that has not met in the last eight years, but for many Member States, these kinds of activities – demolitions, settlements – are strong impediments to this meeting taking place. Israel knows very well the position of the European Union, and I reiterated it yesterday in my talk with the Foreign Affairs Minister.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: in writing. – I welcome the Abraham Accords signed on 15 September 2020 between Israel, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain. This is a fundamental step for the stabilisation of the Middle East, the Red Sea region and the Horn of Africa. In this context, I also welcome the United States’ efforts to facilitate a solution and help restoring peace in the region.  I think we all welcome Israel's commitment to suspend plans to unilaterally annex parts of occupied territory in the West Bank. In the complex reality of the region, it is equally important to pursue a negotiated and viable two-state solution to end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. We should use this momentum to work on this fundamental issue.  I call on European diplomacy and on the international community to remain committed to the resolution of the long-lasting conflicts in the region. We should keep advocating for a   two-state solution and more actively pave the way for dialogue and cooperation in the region and, if necessary, by rethinking EU's strategy.
