name: Didier Reynders
text: au nom du vice-président de la Commission/haut représentant de l'Union pour les affaires étrangères et la politique de sécurité. – Madame la Présidente, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, permettez-moi tout d’abord de vous remercier pour cette opportunité d’échanger avec vous ce soir sur la lutte contre l’impunité en matière de crimes à l’encontre de journalistes à travers le monde. Je voudrais intervenir en lieu et place du haut représentant Josep Borrell, bien entendu, en plein accord avec lui sur ce que je vais vous dire. As the International Day to End Impunity for Crimes against Journalists reminded, in some countries the already difficult situation for journalists is being exacerbated by the use of the pandemic as a pretext for additional restrictions on media freedom. Journalists play a fundamental role in the functioning of democracies. They help ensure accountability of those in power through the provision of timely and factual information. The Commission has said many times that democracy is fuelled by information. In other words, without information, democracy cannot work. Unfortunately, across the world journalists face intimidation, violence or abuse, often putting their lives at risk. Disturbingly, impunity for abuses and crimes against journalists and media workers remains widespread, reaching 90% of cases in some countries, according to a UNESCO report in 2019. We follow with concern reports of journalists being placed in detention without trial, the closure of media stations, and internet shutdowns in many countries. In this troubling context, the EU has stepped up its action. In all relations with other countries we have always been clear on the key role of unrestricted media and civil society and the need to protect human rights defenders, many of whom are journalists. Our EU delegations around the world have strengthened their response to attacks against journalists. A handbook on journalists’ safety has been distributed to all delegations. The delegations are producing or coordinating public statements and social media interventions to give visibility to EU support, observing court cases, identifying cases requiring special protection. In the last 12 months the EU has supported over 425 journalists with emergency grants, temporary relocation or support to their respective media outlets. Dedicated programmes have been operating in many regions for some time, with a total amount of support beyond EUR 180 million. One example is the programme Save Journalists, run by Western Balkan journalist associations. Recent programmes include COVID-19 response in Africa to gather available information, which brings together organisations such as Deutsche Welle Akademie and Reporters sans frontières to build resilience of journalists in Africa. Similar programmes are being finalised for Asia and Latin America. The safety of journalists is at the centre of EU advocacy for media freedom in intellectual fora and bilateral dialogues. We keep recalling the obligation to protect and promote freedom of opinion and expression and offering collaboration. We also work with the Council of Europe, OSCE and UNESCO, and we want to intensify this cooperation. In a similar plenary decision last year some priority areas were mentioned, on which we are making progress. As regards media freedom monitoring, the EU supports the projects of the Centre for Media Pluralism and Media Freedom and of the European Centre for Press and Media Freedom, including its rapid response mechanism. As regards opposition to strategic lawsuits against public participation (the so-called SLAPPs), EU services are formulating a common approach. The next steps are to establish, first, a network of lawyers and media specialists to exchange practices and know-how regarding SLAPP cases, and second, a focus group on legal and financial aid to identify legal and practical solutions. On a more systematic fight against impunity, apart from the already-mentioned support, protection of media independence and journalist in the Member States was a key factor in the analysis that we did in the first annual rule of law report, which is at the centre of a new rule of law mechanism. Support to the reform of justice systems and the rule of law remains key in our external cooperation in over 70 countries, with more than 2.76 billion spent between 2007 and 2017 – in 10 years. In the future we will keep on working on ending impunity for crimes against journalists with two important tools: the EU action plan on human rights and democracy for the period 2020-2024, and the forthcoming European democracy action plan. As you can see, this topic is paramount to our work on the protection and promotion of human rights, and as the examples I mentioned clearly show, we totally agree, and join forces, with your Parliament on such an issue. And I want to add that, of course, it is very important – I have said about the rule of law annual report – to do the job at home to be able to organise our action outside of the European Union. Thank you for your attention, and I’m looking forward, of course, to your debate and maybe also to your remarks and proposals.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, in a world where the truth of the facts seems to be losing its importance, it is imperative to affirm the necessity of it. To protect journalists is to affirm this need, to protect the truth. In a world where information and misinformation circulate with the same intensity, investigative journalists support democracy. They denounce corruption and embezzlement and they are an invaluable support for peoples kept in the dark by authoritarian regimes. For their acts of denunciation, they are threatened and put in danger. Reporters Without Borders reports that more than 250 journalists are in detention and 40 journalists have been murdered in 2020. This is unacceptable. In addition, this new form of violence against journalists must be recognized: the use of strategic legal action that drives journalists and the media into bankruptcy. Our duty is to defend freedom of expression, freedom of the media and journalists. The perpetrators of crimes against journalists must be sought, convicted and punished. Impunity is not acceptable. The powerful officials of this world, guilty of crimes against journalists, cannot continue to enjoy all the privileges they have arrogated themselves and, moreover, clothe themselves in the cloak of respectability. They cannot be allowed to roam freely in our countries and take advantage of poorly stocked bank accounts. I am convinced, Commissioner, that putting in place a powerful mechanism in the European Union such as the Magnitsky Act is also an indispensable step in protecting journalists who risk their lives to reveal the truth to the world.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, to say that freedom of the press is a cornerstone of democracy is a common place that I would like to avoid, but that reality forces us to repeat to exhaustion in the face of the constant attacks we have witnessed, including in some of the so-called consolidated democracies.  Elyas Dayee, Virgilio Maganes and Israel Rangel are the latest casualties recorded in the UNESCO Observatory's long list of murdered journalists, which tells us that, in the last decade alone, nearly 1,000 journalists have been murdered in the line of duty. In addition to these, many others have been victims of threats, intimidation, smear campaigns, arbitrary detention and torture.  The Council of Europe Platform for the Protection of Journalism and The Security of Journalists in 2020 has issued more than 180 alerts in 31 countries.  If these numbers are high, impunity even greater. Only one in 10 perpetrators of this type of crime is brought to justice.  These data leave us a clear message: freedom of the press requires permanent construction and vigilance in the protection of those who fight for it and in the punishment of those who wish to destroy it. Declarations of repudiation and the constant affirmation of the defence of democracy, the rule of law and human rights are important, but they are not enough for those who are dismayed for justice.  It is our obligation within the European Union, but also in dialogue and cooperation with third countries and in the multilateral framework, to combat impunity and to build tools to help protect the right of journalists to speak freely before the various powers, to investigate abuses, to contribute to public debate, to freely exercise their profession and to protect the right of citizens to have access to reliable information.  Initiatives and mechanisms for support and monitoring and protection of press freedom need to be expanded and deepened.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, on 2 November 2013, Ghislaine Dupont and Claude Verlon, two French journalists reporting in northern Mali, were abducted and murdered by jihadists. Seven years later, neither the killers nor those responsible have been brought to justice. On October 16, 2017, Daphne Caruana Galizia, a Maltese blogger, was the victim of a bomb attack while investigating corruption. The trial of his alleged sponsor has not yet taken place. On 25 February 2018, the Slovak journalist, Jen Kuciak, was shot dead along with his partner while investigating possible embezzlement of European funds by the mafia. Although the two shooters were convicted by the Slovak justice system, no client is now behind bars. It would take me much more than two minutes to name the 800 journalists killed in the last 10 years for simply trying to inform the public and get the truth out. According to Reporters Without Borders, whose work I would like to commend here, in 2019 alone, 49 journalists have been killed worldwide. In 9 out of 10 cases, these murders go unpunished. Each time, it is not only a human life that we have taken, each time it is a voice that has been silenced, a testimony that has been gagged, a truth that we have buried. In December 2013, the UN General Assembly paid tribute to Ghislaine Dupont and Claude Verlon and made 2 November, the date of their deaths, the International Day to End Impunity for Crimes Against Journalists, calling on states to bring to justice the perpetrators of crimes against journalists and media workers and to ensure that victims have appropriate recourse. Commissioner, much more needs to be done to ensure that this resolution does not go unheeded. We must at all costs prevent the dying of others Claude Verlon and other Ghislaine Dupont.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, freedom of expression is under attack and the European Union is closing its eyes, too often. Commissioner, you came here to talk about freedom of expression and you did not even mention Charlie Hebdo. He did not mention them despite repeated attacks at their headquarters, they are forced to have a editorial staff working hidden, out of fear. Commissioner, you came here and did not even mention Samuel Pati, the professor beheaded in France because he was not free to explain to his class what freedom of expression was, what we are talking about today.  But they're not the only cases. In Italy, too, we have journalists threatened with their own ideas, such as Magdi Allam, a journalist converted to Christianity who is to blame for carrying out investigations into the spread of Islamist hatred. You see, terrorism aims to restrict our freedom, it is violence against our culture, our values and our traditions. They want us to cancel, to fear, to back down. Unfortunately, they also succeed, thanks to your good will, because, you know, for fear of offending Islam, you talk more about Islamophobia than about Islamic extremism. We can no longer pretend anything, we cannot trample on our identity out of fear, we must not be ashamed of our history. Ideas cannot be suffocated with blood.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, journalists expose what others want to conceal. They shed light on situations that others want to keep in the dark. So a climate of impunity for crimes against journalism is as if we switch that light off and wander in darkness. But it doesn’t always need a murder to silence a journalist’s voice. Authoritarian, and sadly even some democratic, regimes and governments have found other ways to muzzle media freedom. They are silencing journalists by anti-terror laws in the Philippines, by state interference in corona coverage in Tajikistan, or by the denial of permits and the withdrawal of accreditations, as in Belarus. These crimes may not be as obvious as killings, but the effects are very much the same: killing the freedom of the press, depriving people of their right to information and silencing critical voice after critical voice. That is why I want our EU institutions and each and every one of our Member States to make sure that there is no impunity and no way for these governments to get away with these laws and restrictions. Commissioner, support is good, but I also want to see severe consequences if support is not changing anything. I want to see that within Europe and in each and every corner of this world.

name: Lucia ĎURIŠ NICHOLSONOVÁ
text: for the ECR Group. – Madam President, I will first of all focus on the space in the European Union. Tell me who in Central Europe hasn't used Soros as an ani-European conspiracy to raise his hand. Hungarian Prime Minister Orbán or Slovak expletive Fico, as well as other politicians in the very middle of the European Union, create such a hostile climate towards journalists as third world countries, and yet they themselves often spread hoaxes. According to studies, disinformation websites in the European Union receive more than seventy million euros in ads every year. More and more people trust them, because the Member States are doing very little to improve media literacy. We often criticise the situation in Belarus, Turkey and Hong Kong, and yet we ourselves have a major problem with the protection of investigative journalists. The evidence is the murders of Slovak Ján Kuciak as well as Daphne Galizia. Despite the contribution of journalists to society, we are failing to protect them effectively, they often face physical threats and hate speech, and it is women journalists in particular who are often vulgarly insulted by vesidy politicians. We need to protect journalists effectively. The European Commission should also unequivocally add media freedom and the protection of journalists to the monitoring report on the rule of law.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, 49 journalists have been murdered in the last year, according to Reporters Without Borders.  In the last decade, according to international organizations, about 1,000 journalists have been murdered. We are not even talking about those who have been arrested, those who have been assaulted, all over the world.  This is a fundamental issue for democracy itself and it is a question of impunity that has to end. Only one in 10 crimes against journalists are tried and it is democracy itself that is at stake.  It is not just a violation of fundamental rights, it is not just an attack on one's own life, it is not just about attacking freedom of the press or freedom of expression. We are talking about a reality that prevents us all and everyone from having access to the very foundations of what is our society.  It's not just the rest of the world. In the European Union itself, we have seen this. While this European Parliament was investigating crimes of corruption, fraud, tax evasion, tax avoidance, money laundering, we are witnessing the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia, who is yet to understand exactly the conditions and to have the real consequences of this heinous crime. We also witnessed in this Parliament, while we were working on these crimes, the murder of Jan Kuciak.  That is why, Commissioner, we must fight impunity and not only make statements towards the rest of the world, but realise that, within the European Union, there is much to do and we also continue to attack democracy within The European territory itself.

name: Sabrina PIGNEDOLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when we talk about impunity for crimes against journalists, we think of the perpetrators of murders, beatings and threats, but there are ways of silencing journalists on a daily basis in general indifference. They are called reckless lawsuits, or baseless defamation lawsuits, with exorbitant claims for damages. Even if the journalist is acquitted, he still has to pay the lawyer, who has to face the law firms of multinationals or important politicians. The situation becomes all the more serious when we consider that more and more journalists work as freelancers and have very little or no legal protection. The most immediate result is that the journalist stops writing uncomfortable inquiries and in some cases less than ten euros gross are paid. The conclusions of the CRIM Special Committee called on the Member States to decriminalise the crimes of defamation and slander for those reporting corruption, organised crime and money laundering. I believe that we need to take up this step again and also apply it to journalism, in order to encourage those investigations that are so necessary for our democracy.

name: Leopoldo LÓPEZ GIL
text: Madam President, on the occasion of the last International Day to End Impunity for Crimes against Journalists, it is necessary to remind the 1,628 media workers and journalists killed in the last twenty years for simply exercising the right to freedom of the press. According to the UN, in nine out of ten cases the culprits are not prosecuted, thus undermining their societies for the covert impunity of serious human rights abuses, corruption and crimes.  Independent journalism that keeps citizens informed and holds governors accountable is as crucial to a strong democracy as elections themselves, free and fair. Freedom of opinion is one of the inalienable values on which the European Union is based, thus enshrined in Article 11 of its Charter of Fundamental Rights. In addition, the protection of freedom of expression and media pluralism fall within the priorities of the Union and its Member States in external relations.  In any case, it is prevailing to remain vigilant, both outside and within our borders, where these crimes also remain unpunished. The pandemic presents challenges to fundamental rights around the world. It is clear that we must not justify limits to democracy with Orwellian measures such as the ministries of truth, anti-hate laws or the promotion of censorship within our own continent or on any other continent. What will the Commission do to prevent this?

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, dear Didier, I propose an express round-the-world tour of the press non-freedom. In Latin America, there has been a terrible increase in the repression of journalists criticizing both government corruption and unequal social and environmental policies. The Asia-Pacific region is the most dangerous region for journalists and bloggers. We had the opportunity in the Committee on Human Rights to welcome Ms. Ressa, founder of the Rappler news site in the Philippines, who was accused of cyber-defamatory, just for disseminating information. In Vietnam, the situation is not very clear either. Blogger Nguyen Trung and freelance journalist Pham Dung were arrested as we ratify the EU-Vietnam trade agreement. In sub-Saharan Africa, again, freedom of expression is being undermined, as in Nigeria, where there have been 115 cases of abuse of journalists this year. The situation in the Middle East, with the assassination of Khashoggi, or in North Africa, with the arrest of Khaled Drareni in Algeria, is not very clear, is not very gratifying either. In Bangladesh, several journalists and bloggers, such as Shahidul Alam, have been imprisoned and tortured under the draconian Digital Security Act 2018. I could continue this express round-the-world trip by stopping in Europe, for example, where, as has already been said, the situation is not pleasant either. So, Commissioner, violence against journalists is not only an attack on the physical and moral integrity of those who inform us, it is also an attack on the very foundations of our democracy and the rule of law. And so I'm not asking what we're doing to protect journalists, but how we're using our tools to make sure that these situations can no longer continue in the countries with which we have ongoing dialogues.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, journalists are seekers of truth and guardians of our most valued freedom of expression. Their work worldwide is a major disturbance and irritation to those rejecting democratic principles of openness and transparency. Freedom of opinion, expression and access to information constitute an essential part of the universal human rights index, which determines the quality of democracy worldwide.  The extent and tendencies of crimes to silence journalists and to limit media freedom around the world is alarming and increasing. Examples of crimes committed against journalists are disturbing – intimidation and harassment, as constantly faced by journalists in Venezuela and Russia; online harassment, as fought by Pakistani women journalists; threats to family as incurred by Iranian journalists working abroad; exile and expulsion as experienced by a Congolese journalist, Gaël Mpoyo; abduction, as of dozens of journalists currently held hostage in Syria; detention and imprisonment, like in China, which is the world’s biggest captor of journalists; physical attacks and torture like that suffered by a Bolivian journalist, Rene Guarachi; and barbarian killing as with Jamal Khashoggi, a critic of the Saudi Arabian Government.  We need to ensure the safety of journalists by deterring and holding the perpetrators to account. We need to establish an effective framework by adopting the EU Magnitsky Act.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, with all due respect, one hand cannot come here in favour of press freedom while with the other billions of euros are given in media subsidies supporting governments. You know what this is? These are the covers of my country's main media, paid for by the Government, on 25 May 2020, where "we were said to be "stronger". Today Spain, with more than fifty thousand dead, has a permanent and illegal state of alarm and the streets of Spain are devastated. It was the government that violated press freedom by paying millions and leaving citizens who want free and truthful information unsert. The truly free media does not receive grants, nor should these private data verification agencies that are in the service of power receive them. If you want freedom of the press, defend independent professionals, precisely from that subsidized press, and precisely from the data verification agencies that then impose censorship, blockades, through their large technology centres. Finally, Commissioner, a truth committee has been set up in Spain, you know. How is freedom of the press guaranteed when the Government itself says what is true and what is a lie?

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: Mr President, i would like to thank you for your comments. Please! Mr President, you have broken the Rules of Procedure. Please read the Terms and Conditions. Posters and posters must not be used in the plenary room. I draw your attention to this.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Madam President, there is a direct link between a free society and the ability of journalists to do their jobs freely. The work of journalists is important because they do it for the people, not for politicians. Journalists are an organic part of the power balance and in the country, and promoting honest journalism is particularly important in these challenging pandemic times. At a time of growing hoaxes and disinformation, we must also support independent journalists together in Europe. In recent years, we have witnessed a number of crimes against journalists, even the most heinous ones, such as the murder of a journalist. In the Union, we have experienced huge shocks in the murder of Ján Kuciak or Daphne Caruana Galizia. It is extremely important what happens in such tragic moments and how democratic and free societies will react, what are the demands on state institutions. As we can see in the case of the murder of Ján Kuciak, it is really important to investigate not only their executors, but also the orderers and the link to state power in the case of crimes. The work of journalists is in many ways a mirror of the political regimes in which these journalists work. Journalists do not do their job in a spirited way, the whole media must be free.  It is therefore important that all crimes against journalists, from the most serious, such as murders, to more trivial ones, such as extortion or intimidation, are investigated. This is what we are also asking of countries that are on a European path and who are entering or discussing accession to the European Union. The clearer we will show within the European Union that we are punishing crimes against journalists, the clearer the signal we will also send to our partners in the European Neighbourhood and the Western Balkans that journalists need protection and justice in the exercise of their profession.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Mr President, free journalism is vital. Especially in times of crisis such as the current corona pandemic, the careful reporting of independent journalists is indispensable. But we all know that no authoritarian regime would ever waste a good crisis.  One example. For years, Morocco has seized every opportunity to undermine honest reporting on the legitimate demands of hirak protesters in the marginalized Rif region. The Moroccan government is prosecuting Hajar Raissouni, Omar Radi, Omar Naji and indeed any journalist who is brave enough to speak out about the Hirak. Protest leaders like Sakharov Prize candidate Nasser Zefzafi throw it in jail for 20 years. Now Morocco is using the corona crisis as a cover to crack down on freedom of expression under the guise of national security. Let me be very clear: the best way to safeguard national security is not by prosecuting journalists but by protecting them.  Commissioner, in countries where freedom of the press is under pressure, this is always accompanied by human rights under pressure. Combating impunity for crimes against journalists must mean holding governments to account. And that is what I expect from the European Union.

name: Assita KANKO
text: – Madam President, Thomas Jefferson said: where the press is free and every man able to read, all is safe. But today, in too many countries, including in European countries, the press is not free and journalists therefore are not always safe when they express what they think. Hate speech online, intimidation, the spread of disinformation, arbitrary detention and sexual violence towards female journalists all create a shrinking space for free speech. In the past 15 years, close to 200 hundred journalists have been killed. In nine out of ten of these cases, there is no conviction. Impunity emboldens perpetrators. It also points to a bigger problem within our societies and justice systems. A free press speaks truth to power. It criticises, satirises and holds us to account. It sheds light where others have sought to shore up corruption, wrongdoing and mistruth in darkness. A free press is one of the great pillars that hold us up and our democracy safe, and by protecting journalists we help protect the path to truth and freedom.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: – Dear Chairman, 1419 journalists from 1993 to the present day, worldwide have been killed, according to the UNESCO Observatory. The same data shows that in nine out of ten cases, killers go unpunished.  Impunity encourages perpetrators, which in an atmosphere of fear and unprotectedness, leads to a loss of courage and motivation of journalists and the importance of journalistic calling in our communities. Journalists in some parts of the world are on the last line of defence of democracy. That is why we need to put special emphasis on the education and training of young journalists, as well as on improving media literacy. Fifty-seven journalists were killed worldwide last year according to United Nations figures. Although these brutal statistics are changing and the curve is taking a downward trajectory, in the first nine months of this year three female journalists and 39 journalists were killed. This is the lowest death toll in a decade. Public debates have certainly contributed to this, focusing high on this topic as an insistence on security mechanisms to protect journalists. But we still have to ask oursself questions, what is the price for a written or spoken word, what are the justice and security systems in countries where such violence is present.  Colleagues, this is a question that must be asked by all of us commissioners and each one separately, so please take care that journalists have the right to expose and talk about what some would prefer us to remain silent about.

name: Didier Reynders
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you first of all for this debate again held in plenary on a subject of fundamental importance. And I think it is very useful that many of you have recalled the long list of journalists who have been victims of violence and attacks in recent years, in recent months, in recent weeks, including in the European Union. Protecting journalists is a long-term task that requires clear objectives and coordinated action. I mentioned two instruments that will now guard our efforts: the new EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy for 2024, which sets out clear guidelines for a coordinated and effective approach, and the upcoming European Democracy Action Plan, of which media pluralism and freedom are one of the looters. I also want to add that the EU sanctions regime remains a key political priority. As you know, the new regime will not replace existing geographic sanctions regimes, some of which already address human rights violations and abuses, for example in Syria, Belarus or Venezuela. The new global sanctions regime will provide the EU with greater flexibility to target those responsible for serious human rights violations and abuses worldwide, no matter where they occur or who is responsible - and, of course, who are the victims, including journalists. I am pleased that good progress has been made in the discussions on the proposals at the technical level in the Council, and let me recognize the long—standing support of the European Parliament for such a regime. Everyone involved continuing working towards its adoption in the near future, and hopefully before the end of this year. The European Parliament's contribution is crucial if we are to achieve our common objectives. I would also like to add that, as I said earlier, if we are working to protect journalists through all international contacts, we must also do this work within the European Union. And, I recall, the first report we published on 30 September on the rule of law in the 27 Member States of the Union has four chapters. One of these chapters concerns the freedom and pluralism of the media, with particular attention paid to the attacks on journalists in recent months, but also to the measures that have sometimes been taken in the Member States during the emergency period linked to the health crisis we are experiencing. I would also like to add that, as Commissioner for Justice, I regularly remind Member States, as well as international partners, of the need to fight impunity when violence, abuse or attacks are committed against journalists. I would therefore like to end by thanking you for your commitment to freedom of the press, guaranteeing you the Commission's determination to continue very active work in the Union, as well as outside the Union on this subject, and to strengthen the protection implemented against journalists, whether in the Member States or in third countries.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Ioan-Rareş BOGDAN
text: in writing. – The press, through its representatives, plays a fundamental role in the functioning of democracies. Unfortunately, around the world journalists face acts of intimidation, violence or abuse, often putting their lives at risk. The safety of journalists lies at the heart of the concerns of the European Union, which continues to take all measures to protect and promote freedom of opinion and expression. We all need to understand that by supporting journalists, we are practically protecting the truth. That is why we must do much more to defend journalists and to ensure freedom and pluralism of the press in all EU Member States. Because if journalists can't do their job freely, then our democracies will cease to be democracies. Therefore, any attempt to silence critical and independent media must be condemned. Freedom of expression and independent journalism are key to the proper democratic functioning of the EU and its Member States and it is our duty to protect journalists around the world.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " On average, between 50 and 90 people are killed every year around the world - reporters, investigative journalists, war correspondents. Some die because they track down corruption, organised crime groups or try to show the true face of authoritarian rule. Unfortunately, this is also the case in the countries of the European Union.  Jan Kuciak was a Slovak investigative journalist. He dealt with tax fraud by businessmen with links to top-level politicians. In February 2018, he and his fiancée Martina Kušnírova were shot dead at their home in Velka Mača, Slovakia. The 27-year-old Kuciak was the first journalist murdered in Slovakia since independence. His murder sparked mass social protests and a political crisis.  Let us not forget Daphne Anne Caruana Galizia, who reports on political events in Malta. It pointed to corruption in the government, accusations of money laundering and links between the Maltese online gambling industry and organised crime. She did not give up despite threats and processes. In 2016-17, she revealed sensitive information and allegations related to a number of Maltese politicians and the Panama Papers scandal. She was murdered near her home. She was 53. According to the UN, only 10% of cases are punished against journalists.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. – Turkey is on the list of countries with the most imprisonments of journalists and media workers. The media crackdown has intensified in recent years, with newspapers shutting down and journalists condemned under anti-terrorism laws for exercising freedom of expression. This is institutional repression because the judiciary is a political tool in Erdoğan's long arm. When journalist Hrant Dink, of Armenian origin, raised questions about the attitude of the security forces, he was killed, while the authorities were reportedly aware of the threats against him but avoided acting. Such crimes involve the "Grey Wolves", Erdoğan's other long hand. Will you promote the pan-European ban on 'Grey Wolves', or their dependent organisations, because they are dangerous and operate against our values and principles as the EU? However, I would also like to highlight the issue of 'Euronews' in Turkish. The repression of freedom of speech in Turkey and the intervention of the Turkish government, through the state television "TRT", in the news editorial of "Euronews-Turkey" are data. Without a mechanism for assessing the impartiality of the editorial team, a commitment to a "European perspective" on the content of the channel's news is not guaranteed. So who is the sponsor and producer of the news in Turkish on "Euronews-Turkey"?

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – Over the past year, the COVID-19 pandemic has led to many restrictions, closures and changes in people's daily living arrangements. Unfortunately, there has also been an increasing increase in the fact that journalism cannot be quite as free as it is used to be, also here in Europe. In different countries, the free press has been attempted to put pressure on it by justifying it by taking action against COVID-19, or without justification at all. The European Parliament is clearly of the opinion that even in these mixed times, the press has a very important role to play. Among other things, there have been cases where the government or the government community sees the public media as a voice tube. At this point, it is a good reminder that public broadcasting is not government radio or government television, but must provide access to everyone. The owners of large social media platforms also need to take a more serious look at what is being disseminated on their platforms. If there is a clear lie and a dangerous lie, such as on human health, the steps must be much faster and more effective in order to ensure that such lies do not spread very easily. It is also worth taking this kind of attention to freedom of the press in Europe in Estonia.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – Without journalism, no democracy. This might sound indisputable but today criminals for 22 murders of journalists have still not been condemned for their acts in Europe, according to data from the Council of Europe. Beginning of this month was the International Day to end impunity for Crimes against Journalists. Such issue never stops to have first-importance place on the political agenda. Attacks on journalists constitute a threat on democracy itself. It is essential to defend those who risk their lives at work by upholding the right to inform and by expressing critical views, online and offline. These abilities are vital to a healthy democratic debate. This is crucial especially in the context of so-called infodemics and fake news, which became of always-greater importance in 2020. With the Partnership for Information and Democracy launched in September 2019, Malta has committed with 38 other countries to promote access to reliable information from free and independent media. Such commitment means that journalists and media workers, in the course of their function, must be protected against all forms of violence, threats and discrimination. I believe that this goes also hand in hand with a European framework for whistle-blowers’ protection, for which new EU-wide rules will kick in in 2021.
